PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin The Hon S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the House last met when the question of the application of the sub judice convention to proceedings in the so-called Easton royal commission in Western Australia became an issue, there has been a significant development in respect of those proceedings. This new development has led me to reassess the position which the chair should take in respect of that particular royal commission and also in respect of royal commissions generally.

PARA.TAB: On 5 September Commissioner Marks outlined the issues which he believed the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) may possibly be facing in the royal commission's inquiries. For the information of honourable members, I present a copy of the statement of possible issues regarding Dr Lawrence identified by the royal commissioner. The identification by the commissioner of these issues has made it clear that the inquiry is now explicitly investigating the propriety of the actions of Dr Lawrence. This had not been previously spelt out as such and could not have been so specifically interpreted from the terms of reference of the royal commission. Previous rulings of the chair were based on the earlier situation and, in my view, have been substantiated.
House of Representatives Practice indicates that there is not a blanket prohibition on the discussion of matters before a royal commission. Page 491 of House of Representatives Practice states:

SPEECH.PARA: Proceedings before a royal commission or judicial inquiry shall not be referred to in motions, debate or questions where the matter inquired into concerns issues of fact or findings relating to the propriety of the actions of specific persons.

However, as indicated at page 494 of House of Representatives Practice, the contemporary view is that a general prohibition of discussion of the proceedings of a royal commission is too broad and restricts the House unduly. It is necessary for the chair to consider the nature of the inquiry in each case.

PARA.TAB: Having regard to the new circumstances, I have reviewed the matter to determine whether the chair should allow further references to the substance of the royal commission's inquiry to be made in the proceedings of the House. The question at issue is whether further references to those proceedings would lead to a risk of prejudicing the position of parties and witnesses before the royal commission.

The terms of reference of this royal commission do not provide for it to inquire into whether there has been any breach of a law of the Commonwealth. The issues before the commission have a highly political element. While references in this House may have some influence on the proceedings of the royal commission, the accepted interpretation of the purposes of the sub judice convention—namely, to prevent the possibility of exerting an influence on juries and from prejudicing the position of parties and witnesses in court proceedings—do not apply in this case. Accordingly, on balance I have concluded that there is no reason to prevent further references to the proceedings of the royal commission in this House.

In respect of royal commissions generally, I have to say that I have now concluded that it would be quite wrong to subscribe to the view that has been expressed that the sub judice convention should not continue to be applied to royal commissions. There is a compelling case for each royal commission to be judged on its merits and, in my view, it would be inappropriate to make such a general pronouncement. I am aware that this matter is one that has caused concern to some members. I hope that this statement will help to clarify the issues involved. The difficulties in this case have been compounded by the highly political nature of the royal commission. However, my role is to endeavour to ensure that proper processes are followed in this House. The application of the sub judice convention is always subject to the discretion of the chair, and it is up to the chair to make a judgment in each case.

Honourable members will observe that this statement confirms and supplements my earlier statement on the sub judice convention which I made to the House on 27 June 1994 in response to matters raised by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr Theophanous). The conclusion I have reached has only been made after a very careful examination of all the issues involved, a recognition of the amount of publicity this matter has already received, and it is not inconsistent with rulings given previously in respect of the sub judice convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, I wish to take up the time of the House for a moment to comment on this sub judice convention and, in particular, respond to some of the things that you have said.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, as this is a significant issue, and it was well known—we have made no secret of it—that we thought that the issue should be revisited by you, and given that you have now prepared a statement and made this statement in the House, I am disappointed that you did not see fit to provide us with a copy of your statement beforehand. That may not be the convention, but on this particular issue, if we had had the benefit of the statement even 20 minutes before you delivered it, it would have given us a chance to more carefully and more dispassionately respond to what you have had to say. I believe there to be no reason whatsoever why that sensible and usual courtesy on other matters could not have been followed on this particular occasion. So that is my preliminary comment.

Secondly, we have been very concerned at the earlier rulings and practice adopted by you in respect of the Easton matter in the previous fortnight that the House was sitting. You say in your statement to us that there has been a significant development since the House last sat, and you referred specifically to remarks of the royal commissioner which brought into focus the propriety of actions by the federal Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). You said that the fact that the commissioner had detailed aspects of her behaviour which may reflect on her provided the basis for you to make the statement that you have just made. Quite frankly, Mr Speaker, I would have to say that that is entirely a red herring. In fact, I think that you were quite wrong to say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the member is speaking under indulgence. That does not give him the right to stand up and canvass what ought—if that is his view—to be properly a part of a motion. To make comment on it is entirely appropriate under indulgence; to take it to that extent, I think, is stretching a point.

—Order! I am listening very carefully to the comments that the member for Flinders wants to make. But there is clearly a fine line between making some comments on the statement and then getting into a debate on the issue. I think the Leader of the House does raise a valid point. If you want to do that, there are appropriate forms of the House. But I am allowing you to continue under indulgence.

—You have given me indulgence so that I can comment on what you have had to say. The point I want to make is that during the debate, and particularly during question time on this issue, a point of order was raised by the member for Menzies (Mr Andrews) which specifically went to the manner in which your ruling affected the questions and the response of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at that time. The member for Menzies then quoted to you from page 494 of House of Representatives Practice and, in particular, the explanation of the sub judice rule by former Speaker Snedden. If it were a jury matter and a criminal matter and we were discussing matters in the parliament and that might affect the views of the jury, that would clearly be a breach of the sub judice rule. That is obvious.

PARA.TAB: It is also obvious, as you yourself have just said in quoting page 494 of House of Representatives Practice, that it is not so easy to prejudice a royal commissioner—in this case a former judge who is an old hand at dealing with matters of public issue and controversy and who has experience that allows him objectively to come to his conclusions. That is all common ground.

The point that Snedden made, and that the member made for you at the particular time, though, was that by referring to and canvassing the likely outcome of a commission you could actually set up in the public's mind a view about what is going to happen. If the royal commissioner's conclusion coincides with what has been said in this place should happen, the public is going to be inclined to the view that the royal commissioner came to a particular view not because of his having heard the evidence but because of his having been influenced by what has happened in the parliament. It is that which would be a breach of the sub judice convention.

Quite frankly, that was the whole basis of the Prime Minister's attack on the Marks royal commission—he set out to taint the results of the royal commission. Blind Freddy could see that the Prime Minister does not want the conclusion to be reached by the Marks commission that a minister had lied. He does not want, therefore, the royal commission's findings to be of weighty evidence and persuasiveness to the Australian public so he set out to undermine the commission before it brings down its findings. That is in House of Representatives Practice, and that is the one thing we cannot do. You have said in your statement today there has been a development since we last sat which has given rise to what you have had to say. But the development that has arisen since last time is irrelevant. The Prime Minister set out deliberately to taint and to undermine the findings of the royal commission. We cannot do that. That is a breach of the sub judice convention.

Yes, of course, the parliament as the premier forum in the country can debate great national issues of the day. This is only a convention. In other words, if we want to talk about the level of tax in Australia and there is a royal commission examining tax issues, obviously nothing can prevent the federal parliament from discussing any issue at any time. That must always be the case in a democracy. What you cannot do, though, is use your position in here to undermine, to taint, to prejudice or to devalue the work of an independent royal commission. That is what you cannot do. There has never been any question about that—absolutely none.

Quite frankly, your coming in here today with this statement, which you did not give us the benefit of reading beforehand, is just a mopping up exercise after all the damage has been done. The horse has bolted. The Prime Minister set out deliberately to undermine the royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the member on indulgence is now imputing motives to the Prime Minister in relation to statements that the Prime Minister has made, and matters that the Prime Minister has explained, to make it clear that the royal commission is a witch hunt and a political stunt. I do not believe that on indulgence there should be imputations of that kind made against the Prime Minister.

—Order! The point the honourable member raises applies in this place, as all members know: if there are imputations of improper motives, or whatever, against any member there are forms of the House which you can go to. But the honourable member for Flinders is on indulgence and I think has made that point. I presume he is going to move on.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Reid

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the point of order, Mr Speaker, I refer you to page 1031 of the Hansard of Thursday, 31 August where the Prime Minister said:

INTERJECT.PARA: The burden of these remarks in this transcript and the reason I persist with them are that they show what an iniquitous operation this royal commission is.
The motive is quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders is on indulgence.
—Mr Speaker, I have with me a copy of your reported remarks in the Australian on 6 September which state:

SPEECH.PARA: This meant the only restriction on the Coalition's use of commission evidence to attack Dr Lawrence would be "political judgment".

I am not quite sure where that statement sits now with what you have had to say today. If you are now taking us back to the House of Representatives Practice, which was departed from in the last fortnight's sitting, that is in a sense a worthwhile contribution to make. But I wonder now whether or not that fits with what the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) said on 24 August:

The House of Representatives Practice is quite clear on this. You cannot, under the House of Representatives Practice, go into the detail of consideration of royal commission matters, which have not quite the same level of protection that court matters have, but have liberality only in the areas where they go to dealing with great matters of national policy and national issues of that nature.
When they get into the issues that are directly related to a person's situation in matters before a royal commission, they have commonly been regarded in this House as sub judice . . .

The Leader of the House made that statement which, in his tactics meeting with the Prime Minister, he was very quick to disregard. We then saw the Prime Minister's attack on the commission. The knowing smile of the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) only confirms my speculation.

PARA.TAB: The House ought to comply with its conventions. We have very clear practice in respect of the matter of sub judice. In the past, Speakers from both sides of the House have required compliance with that convention and that practice. In the last fortnight's sitting, that convention went completely out the window. You were happy to acquiesce in as blatant a breach of the convention as has been seen in this parliament. You have now provided us with some further statement, the impact of which I have yet to assess. It is not clear from what you have said today what it is that we can ask at question time today. I will obviously consider that matter over the next couple of hours.

In conclusion, I think the whole episode has been most regrettable. It could not have been clearer that the convention was breached. I do not think it is reasonable to say that things have happened in the interim that affect the way in which we approach this issue. The truth is that the convention and the way in which it should be approached has always been clear. That is why I say to you that what we had in the last sitting was a very clear breach. I would like to see us return to the practice as outlined by House of Representatives Practice, but in a sense we have little say over it. The truth of the matter is that the government will for its own political purposes push the extremes of the convention and practice. Unless you are prepared to stick more closely in the future to House of Representatives Practice, we can only complain; we are powerless to prevent the abuses which we saw last time we sat. I hope it has been a salutary lesson for all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)acknowledges the need for Australian workers to save for their retirement to ensure the burden on the Government and Australian taxpayers is minimised;

(2)as such, recognises the massive imposts under the guise of account and management fees that are imposed on individuals' retirement funds and the disincentive this causes to saving and the subsequent burden which is placed on taxpayers;
(3)calls on the Government to provide policies which encourage savings for retirement; and
(4)opposes any taxes or changes which discourage saving.

I tabled this motion back in February after I had been approached by a number of constituents who had experienced some difficulties with their superannuation funds. Nevertheless, the thrust of the motion is broader than superannuation itself. Today's news of Australians being the richest people in the world per capita should not lure us into a false sense of believing that everything is fine, because quite clearly it is not.

PARA.TAB: The concern of my constituents was that there was no incentive to save—be it through superannuation, bank accounts, investments or wherever. Any benefits that were accrued just disappeared in fees, charges or taxes. I imagine that over the coming months we will probably see new accounts proposed by banks that will have no fees—but they will carry very few benefits with them—to accommodate lower income earners who cannot keep their balance above the minimum level which avoids account keeping fees and the like.

I read today that the chief executive of the Commonwealth Bank has called on the federal government to do something to assist the states in eliminating state taxes on accounts and so on. This motion calls on the government to provide policies which encourage savings for retirement and opposes any taxes or charges which discourage saving. In the big picture, the state taxes and charges on an individual account may not amount to a great deal, but it is still a very real disincentive to save. Why, people ask me, should they try to save when the interest they receive is eaten up by taxes, charges and other associated fees?

I would actually like to see banks go back into schools and have special accounts for students so they learn the saving ethic much earlier in life. Obviously, this would need to be a community service by the banks but if they could establish a fee free, interest bearing account for schoolkids, the kids would develop the saving ethic earlier in life and understand the value of this when they find they want to buy a car or need a deposit for a home. They would need to take considerably more than the 1s 6d that I used to take to school tied up in the corner of a handkerchief. That was in the days when we had the little tins in the shape of the Commonwealth Bank building. I think the government could be encouraging such a scheme as well as assisting the states in scrapping taxes on accounts.

I expect members opposite will probably talk about superannuation. I do not think superannuation should be considered the be-all and end-all of a personal savings strategy—or a national savings strategy for that matter. The following letter is typical of many I have received and which, as I say, prompted me to move this motion. A lady called Claire, a constituent of mine, wrote to me about her son's superannuation statement, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: He is a student but gets occasional part time work. On the latest statement, you will note on September 30, 94 he had a balance $191.44. On October 18th, 94 after a whopping account servicing fee of $49.80 and superannuation taxes of $30.89, he now has $111.20. At this rate by the end of next year, should he get no more work from that employer, he will owe the bank. Some incentive, his hard earned money has helped make the bank wealthier.

We have, since then, had legislation passed which put in place member protection for those employees who had small amounts in their fund, to prevent them being eaten away by fees and charges. Member protection is well and good in that it prevents small accounts dissipating into nothing. However, this motion calls on the government to provide policies which encourage savings for retirement. Member protection does not encourage savings.

PARA.TAB: A recent survey by the Australian Consumers Council showed that 50 per cent of participants in superannuation believe that it is a very poor investment. Another survey found that young people between 18 and 25 believe it is too early to be involved in superannuation, people between 25 and 45 believe they have too many other financial commitments, and those between 45 and 55 believe it is too late to start saving for retirement.

We need a retirement income strategy in place so that, with our ageing society, the burden of looking after the aged in their retirement does not fall entirely on the taxpayer. We cannot expect everyone to simply rely on superannuation, and the government's superannuation strategy should not be considered the panacea to solving the retirement income needs of the aged over the next 30 to 50 years and beyond. Often, we do not look far enough ahead in this country when we are planning—it is a matter of planning from election to election. Another example I would like to quote is from another constituent of mine, Steve, who wrote to me about his super fund:

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the fund to which I am contributing is performing so appallingly that I now see there is no way they can claim to be helping fund my retirement . . . We are not poor, but we work hard and halfway through my working life the time has come to cut our losses on this fund. 13 years of contributions to it totalling $21,530 are now valued at a paltry $22,898. Last year they lost me $495. If the fund managers cannot do any better, then quite frankly they should go back to university.

What should I tell someone like Steve—`Don't worry mate, you're a millionaire'? Where is the incentive for him? Admittedly, it is up to the super funds to manage his investments. But then, if that is the argument members opposite will offer, the claim of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that workers will have a goldmine when they retire will be dependent on, firstly, the workers working a certain number of years—which is highly unlikely—and, secondly, the super fund managing the investment so that it has earnings similar to the predictions of the Prime Minister. So it is still a gamble.

PARA.TAB: Another gentleman contacted me about his son, who had been an apprentice hairdresser. The young man's superannuation payments were going into an AMP fund. He left the employer making contributions to AMP to work for another employer. The new employer did not want to make payments to the AMP fund and instead paid his superannuation contributions into a fund with National Superannuation Plan. The young man later left that employment to study theology. Students of theology receive a benefit of only $2,000 per annum, meaning he had a need to claim the payments which he had made to his super funds. AMP was no problem. It paid him back his $1,500-odd. The National Superannuation Plan, however, has held off paying back his $500 for a number of months now and he still does not have it. It is little wonder that people lack faith in superannuation in general and in superannuation funds in particular. When people need their money and are eligible to claim it, some funds are reluctant to be user friendly.

We are living in an ageing society. In 1961, seniors—that is, persons aged 60 years or more—made up 11 per cent of Western Australia's population. In 1991, they constituted 14 per cent. It is anticipated that, by 2021, nearly one in every four Western Australians will be a senior. It is more than apparent that, during their working lives, Australians need to be encouraged to save for their retirement. If they do not, the burden on the government, and thus the taxpayers, will be enormous. While superannuation is the common form of retirement income provision, some people choose other avenues such as negative gearing on property investments, investing in the stock market and so on. When considering retirement income policies, these factors also need to be considered.

Another point worth noting at this stage—this motion calls on the government to provide policies which encourage savings for retirement—is that self-funded retirees are particularly hard done by. Not only do we need policies which encourage saving in the first place; we also need to ensure that when people retire to live on their savings they are not treated unfairly vis-a-vis pensioners. We may have great retirement income policies, but the incentive will soon go out the door when people notice how poor is the treatment of self-funded retirees. What sort of example are we setting for the younger people in our society when they see what happens to this particular group? The existing tax system threshold disadvantages self-funded retirees. While I am fully supportive of our pensioners, who have every right to the benefits they receive, I do empathise with the plight of self-funded retirees, who are treated quite dissimilarly to pensioners in many ways. I particularly mention the different tax-free threshold.

No doubt the major area of retirement income today is superannuation. The coalition has acknowledged the importance of this by having a superannuation portfolio. We will have a policy on this issue which will provide an incentive to save for retirement. Superannuation needs to be easily understood by the people who use it as well as being worth while, flexible and, probably most importantly, simple. Unfortunately, it seems this is not the case with superannuation today. The anecdotes I have offered back this up. It comes back to the thrust of this motion: there needs to be an incentive to provide for one's retirement, and that incentive simply does not exist today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion, and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the motion moved today by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron). The contribution of the member for Stirling really demonstrates the central problem that we have in Australian politics and in Australian public policy; that is, the Liberal and National parties are part of this country's saving problem. That is why they simply cannot be part of a savings solution.

PARA.TAB: The last budget introduced into this House was all about saving. It was about public and private saving. What did the opposition have to say about that? They came into this House trying to knock off the savings strategy by undermining the budget surplus to the tune of $2.5 billion in the out years through their action in opposing revenue measures. They also came into this House opposing compulsory superannuation. So when it comes to a saving policy, or any other policy for that matter, the opposition has not had a new idea in 12 years of opposition.

The opposition has had one new idea, I guess—the new idea of the GST. Of course, the GST was a great savings policy for the rich, but it was one that would have flogged the battlers. The only new idea they have had in the area of savings in the last 12 years has been a GST, something that would have fundamentally redistributed income from low income earners to higher income earners. The people making the savings under the opposition's policy would have been those on high incomes. The people flogged to death would have been the battlers, whom those opposite sometimes pretend to be concerned with.

The arrogance of the opposition in refusing to stand publicly for a savings policy is breathtaking. The opposition is condemned by most of the significant institutions in this country for its current lack of articulated policy. We can only consider the opposition's previous statements. However, before I go on to talk about that, let us consider what some of the significant institutional players in the policy scene have had to say about the nation's current strategy for savings. I quote from the AMP Society's latest edition of Super Trends—issue 1 of August 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: AMP is a strong supporter of the need to increase national saving and we believe that superannuation is an essential contributor to that goal.
Of course, that runs directly contrary to many of the remarks previously made in this debate by members for the opposition. The AMP goes on to say:
Over the last decade Australia has developed a world class superannuation system.
That remains completely unacknowledged by those opposite. The AMP goes on to say this:

Not only will our superannuation system contribute to better standards of living in retirement, so improving the well-being and lifestyles of retired Australians, but it will also contribute to a stronger economy by reducing Australia's reliance on foreign capital.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AMP produced a detailed study of the effects of the government's approach to superannuation. The AMP developed a new model.
—I suppose those opposite oppose what the AMP says, do they? Is that the attitude of the opposition? Do you stand in opposition to what the AMP is saying?
—I'm telling you a lot of people do.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—I warn the member for O'Connor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us go on the record. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor: what is your savings policy? It is a pity that we do not get more policy debate from the opposition instead of the usual personal attacks and abuse. I would like to get down to the substance of policy—something which is not coming from the opposition. The AMP commissioned a model from Access Economics—and those opposite know a lot about Access Economics and place a lot of faith in that organisation.

PARA.TAB: Basically, the model projects that there will be additional national savings of about one per cent of GDP and total superannuation assets of $462 billion as a result of the recent federal budget moves to lift contribution levels. That is a pretty significant endorsement by Access Economics of the federal government's national savings plan. The AMP model went on to make a few projections about the results of the plan. It projects that by 2003-04, as a result of current policies, there will be:a reduction in the current account deficit of one per cent of GDP to about three to four per cent of GDP; a boost to national saving of around one per cent of GDP; lower inflation due to lower consumption and increased productivity from higher investment; a lowering of foreign debt by 3.4 per cent of GDP; an additional rise in GDP of 0.7 per cent; an extra 28,000 people in employment; and stronger long-term economic growth due to increased productive capacity with investment rising by an additional 0.7 per cent of GDP to 27 per cent. That is a pretty significant endorsement of the government's approach.

The opposition has had a lot to say about foreign debt. Those opposite go around the country claiming that we have unsustainable levels of foreign debt, but at the same time they are saying that the solution to foreign debt is savings. When we ask those opposite what is their savings policy they cannot tell us. They oppose the government's superannuation arrangements but they continually run around the country claiming that foreign debt is a problem.

Let us briefly look at what those opposite have to say about foreign debt. The opposition has been running around the country claiming that the federal government has put every Australian into hock to the tune of $10,000. That is a breathtakingly wild and inaccurate assertion. The opposition has been exaggerating the extent of foreign debt as part of its attempt to talk down the Australian economy.

Australia does have a net foreign debt of $180.5 billion, but the fact is that 60 per cent of that debt is private; that is, it is borrowed by Australian companies to expand their domestic capacities. Only four per cent of that debt is federal government debt. In other words, the Australian public is only liable for $406 per person—$7 billion instead of $180 billion. That shows the length to which the opposition will go to parade inaccurate statistics in its cynical approach to this forthcoming election campaign.

Nor does the opposition tell the public about the significant extent to which our capacity to repay the debt has been increased over time. Significantly, the debt service ratio has fallen from 20.6 per cent in 1990 to a low of 11.2 per cent in the June quarter of this year. In short, the federal government debt is not a burden on Australians. The low level of federal government debt reflects the fact that it has not borrowed offshore since 1987.

This analysis is also backed up by other independent commentators. The opposition is quite fond of quoting many overseas reports on the Australian economy, so I will quote what Moody's had to say in June this year:

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that the Australian government, as well as a large segment of the population at large—
except the Liberal and National parties, I might add—

by now understands the savings/investment problem. In fact, there are a number of very important economic studies regarding the savings question in Australia—studies that have put the level of public discourse regarding this question well ahead of a number of other developed countries. In fact, several important steps have already been undertaken. Clearly, an important element has been the stabilization of the underlying inflation rate.
Moody's went on to say:

In the recently proposed budget, the government supported the phased introduction of employee contributions to superannuation, in addition to the existing provisions for employer provided superannuation contributions. The government also called for a promised tax cut to be instead turned into a government co-contribution to workers' superannuation funds. These are the types of policy that fit well with Australia's savings/investment problem.

That is, almost all of the independent commentators around the country have correctly identified that the government has correctly identified the savings investment imbalance and has taken the proper corrective policy action.

PARA.TAB: What have we got from the opposition in response to this? We have tried to put in place a budget surplus; that has been opposed. We have tried to put in place a national private savings plan through superannuation; that has been opposed. We have tried to put in place an accord with the trade union movement to keep inflation low; that has been opposed. What is the opposition's plan? To continually oppose—to oppose revenue measures in this House, to propose spending increases, to oppose revenue increases and, at the same time, in an act of monumental hypocrisy, to call for tighter fiscal policy.

What we have really had from the opposition has been continual scaremongering and cynical opportunism which is used as a camouflage, if you like, for the fact that the opposition does not have any concrete policies. Nowhere is this more evident than in superannuation. The opposition has consistently, over a long period, failed to match our commitment to ensuring the adequacy of the pension. For example, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) knocked off the CPI indexation of pensions. That showed the opposition's contempt for pensioners. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that whenever a notion or idea becomes an article of faith—that is to say, anyone who disagrees with it is ridiculed or attacked—it is almost always wrong. In economic policy this is just as true as in many other fields of policy. These days with our current account deficit identified as a chronic problem, which grows worse each time the economic cycle revolves, the accepted faith is that the entire answer to this chronic problem lies in boosting national savings.

PARA.TAB: The proposition that I want to put to the House today in rising to speak to the motion of my honourable friend the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) is that that is not entirely the case. You cannot have a savings policy existing alone. To persist with that policy without matching reforms in other parts of the economy may even exacerbate the problems we have with our current account deficit.

The motion that the member has moved today deals with national savings in four ways. It talks about the need to lift the savings rate. It talks about the high fees and charges imposed on Australians who invest their money, hard won gains, in superannuation and in other savings vehicles. It also talks about the obvious flaws in the government's saving policy and finishes with what I take to be a plea to the government to ease the tax burden on those people who are trying to save.

I will divide my remarks today into two parts: one dealing with the need for savings and the other dealing with those high fees and charges that all of us have been suffering. Two main reasons are given for the urgent nature of the need for savings. The first is that we have to save more in order to reduce the burden on government because the baby boomer generation is growing older. I hope that in the autumn of their life those baby boomers represented on the front bench of this government reflect upon the damage that they have inflicted on this country during their time in government—damage that people of my generation and those younger will have to spend the next decade repairing.

The second reason most often given for this urgent need is that we have to increase the pool of domestic capital that is available to satisfy the investment needs of Australia and to reduce our reliance on foreign debt. Those two aims can be achieved to some degree by raising the rate of savings, but I am worried that in following this urge we may fall victim to what I call the grand scheme syndrome. It worries me that in recent decades Australian governments have fallen prey to the tendency to construct grand policy schemes in the ludicrous hope that somehow a grand scheme can deal with an intractable problem at the stroke of a pen, instead of concentrating on making smaller, more nuts and bolts decisions which by their very nature are perhaps less popular with the electorate.

There are many examples of this grand scheme syndrome. For example, it is said that all our trade woes will magically disappear if we integrate with Asia; the answer lies with Asia and, as long as we go along with what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) tell us about our shortcomings in that area, all will be well. Another example of this grand scheme syndrome is our so-called national identity crisis. I cannot say that I, my family, my friends or acquaintances are obviously suffering from some crisis in identity every morning whilst eating our Special K, but we are told from members of the government benches that we do suffer from such a crisis. What will be the solution to this appalling state of affairs? If we became a republic, our national identity crisis would be solved overnight. All we have to do is agree with everything that the government says in its grand scheme and she'll be right, mate; all will be well!

With our current account deficit problem, again we are told that, if we all pile into a huge and compulsory superannuation scheme, somehow or other everything will be all right. The member for Lilley (Mr Swan) quoted from the AMP Society, that marvellously objective body which I understand is now owned by a French company. What a crass irony it is that, in the year when the Republic of France is detonating nuclear bombs in our backyard, one of the authorities from which the member for Lilley quoted is now in French hands. Provided we understand that a savings policy alone is not enough, I think we are somewhere along the right road to a solution to the current account deficit problem and the problem of a generally moribund economy.

The sorts of policies that have to accompany a growing pool of savings include fiscal rectitude—that is, we have to do something about our habitual reliance on government budget deficits. We have to do whatever we can to improve productivity in the workplace, and we have to strive to reduce the tax burden—at least the burdensome taxes that we impose on new enterprises—in order to foster innovation. You need to match innovation in the workplace. If you create an enormous pool of domestic savings without doing something to liberate the supply side of an economy to provide the sorts of goods and services that Australians rightfully crave when they have more money in their pockets, you can end up with something worse than what you started with.

An obvious example of that is the economy in Japan. It is in a frightening state because of a similar grand folly in its economic policy over the last 20 or 30 years. After the war, during its period of reconstruction it set about forcing people to save more money. In doing so, it created a huge pool of savings. It combined that with astonishing growth in productivity in the workplace, but it placed restrictions on where that great pool of savings could be invested.

In effect, Japan forced people into domestic assets, land prices, stock prices, share prices and even golf club memberships. This notion that everything had to be invested domestically and that people should be frightened of foreign products or foreign companies has led to the absurd situation where these assets are now so overpriced that the economy is suffering from deflation. The prices of these assets are falling. They will continue to fall until they reach a level where a proper return on equity is achievable. It is precisely because Japan took a myopic attitude that all they had to do was increase their domestic savings and all would be well that they have reached this appalling state.

It is like the driver of a car with an engine that is not working properly taking the car to a petrol station, instead of to a garage to get a mechanic to diagnose the problems in the engine and fix them, filling up the tank with a higher grade of petrol and saying to everybody, `Look at me. My petrol tank is full. Watch me go.' It may even be that they change the colour of the paint on the car and say, `Look at this.' The performance of the car is no better. In fact, it will only get worse the further down the highway the car travels.

It is amusing for me to look in that way at the savings horizon of Australia. We see some bad things and we see some good things. Let me deal reluctantly with the bad ones first. The worst one of all and the one which makes me laugh the most is the government's campaign to educate the electorate—that is, us—about the benefits of its superannuation policy. What does it do in order to educate us, the people of the electorate? It uses a cartoon of a man with a wheelbarrow full of money and a whole lot of little trees in pots where money grows like leaves. That illustrates that the cabinet—the cabinet that gathers here from time to time and indulges us with an appearance in question time—

TALK.START.PARA: —They believe that money grows on trees.

—They do. It shows they have all the intellectual rigour of a kindergarten. What are we going to have next? My friend the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is sitting on the other side of the House cringing with embarrassment over what his frontbench has done. What are we going to have next? Are we going to have Daffy Duck on industrial relations?

PARA.TAB: Mr Rocher interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have already got something like that down there. Are we going to have Bugs Bunny on health—you know, what's up, doc? Are we going to have the Road Runner on transport policy? It goes on and on. Imagine treating the electorate with such disdain—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved today by the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron), my colleague from Western Australia, has four parts. It asks that the House, firstly, acknowledges the need for Australian workers to save for their retirement; secondly, recognises the imposts under the guise of account and management fees; thirdly, calls on the government to provide policies which encourage savings for retirement; and, fourthly, opposes any taxes or changes which discourage saving.

PARA.TAB: I was entirely bemused to discover that members of the opposition had actually discovered superannuation because, if the truth be told, members opposite have not had an interest in superannuation. When this government came to office in 1983, superannuation had been treated by those opposite as basically a tax deduction for upper middle and high income earners. There was no notion of having a national plan for retirement incomes and no notion of having a national plan for savings, either private or public.

In the course of the decade—it is now longer than a decade—that has occurred since this government came to office in 1983, we have seen effectively the creation of a major national industry: the superannuation industry. We have seen massive boosts to national savings through superannuation and we have seen major improvements in the retirement income capacities of many Australians.

If you simply go to the decade of reform from 1983 to 1993, you can see from the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures of June 1993 the massive expansion in superannuation and the access of ordinary Australian workers to superannuation in the course of that decade—and, of course, the figures have improved since then. In June 1993, the ABS relevant statistics were saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation coverage of employed Australians rose to 80 per cent in November 1993. This continues the upward trend reported in November 1991 when the level of superannuation coverage had increased from 51 per cent in November 1988 to 71 per cent.
Of course, these figures come off the low of 40 per cent which we inherited when we came to office in 1983. The ABS went on to state:
6.1 million employed people aged 15 to 74 were covered by a superannuation scheme . . . 82 per cent of men had superannuation coverage . . . The level of coverage for women was 78 per cent.
Wage and salary earners reported the highest superannuation coverage rate with 89 per cent.

We have seen in the decade since the government came to office a massive expansion in the access of ordinary Australian workers and taxpayers to superannuation. It is quite bemusing to see those opposite now suddenly discovering an interest in this important area.

PARA.TAB: What has been the net effect of policy to date? There has been a massive expansion of access to superannuation which brings with it very important consequences for retirement incomes and a massive boost to the potential for contribution to national savings. The initiatives which we saw in this year's budget build on those previous policies and the previous record of a decade of reform by this government.

What you now see in place is a national superannuation policy which seeks to enhance and further expand both the access to superannuation and the contribution that superannuation makes to national savings. The member for Stirling, in his motion, calls on the government to provide policies which encourage savings for retirement. All you have to do is refer to a speech made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) to the Association of Superannuation Funds to find the philosophical attitude behind the government's retirement incomes and superannuation policies. The Treasurer on that occasion said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's retirement incomes policy will continue to have three elements:
the age pension and associated social security arrangements, which provide an income safety net in retirement—
safety nets are something which those opposite regard as anathema or have no interest in—

a compulsory saving element, achieved through the Superannuation Guarantee and now minimum employment contributions required under industrial agreements and awards; and a voluntary element of superannuation, encouraged by the substantial tax concessions available for superannuation saving and the Government's matching payments.
The Treasurer went on to say:
These measures will result in most employees having the equivalent of 15 per cent of their earnings directed towards their retirement savings from 2002.
He also went on to say:

The matching Government contribution is specifically targeted to low and middle income earners. This group includes a significant proportion of women who, prior to 1983, traditionally missed out on access to superannuation benefits and concessions.
The end result will be significantly higher incomes in retirement for ordinary workers.

That is the philosophical approach of the government. It is one the government stands by and has stood by since it came to office in 1983. That stands in stark contrast to the approach by and attitude of those opposite when they were in power prior to 1983 and stands in stark contrast to the attitude expressed recently by the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). Mr Howard was sprung quite adroitly by an article in the Australian on 28 August—late last month. Mr Megalogenis, one of the Australian's economic reporters, under the heading `Battlers will be the first to fall into Howard's super trap' says:
John Howard and Peter Costello risk the credibility of their economic attacks on the Government if they persist in making misleading outbursts on superannuation.

PARA.TAB: Howard tarnished his self-image as an honest politician this month when he said that Keating's promise of a super bonanza is "very deceitful and a distortion of the facts".
Howard said: "He [Keating] runs around Australia saying under his policy workers will be able to retire on $480,000. The problem is it only applies to somebody who's now younger than 11."

SPEECH.PARA: The writer of this article says:
Howard was wrong on two counts. The number Keating has been quoting out of the Budget papers is $462,000; and the person he refers to is now 18 years of age.
So the Leader of the Opposition has given a massive, deliberate and complete distortion of the implications of some of the measures contained in the budget. Mr Megalogenis goes on to say:
But Howard compounded his error with his attempt to rebut Treasurer Ralph Willis's claims that workers would lose up to $250,000 in benefits under the apparent Coalition policy.

PARA.TAB: "He [Willis] was quite dishonestly observing that I was going to snuffle out workers' superannuation entitlements. . . we're certainly not going to leave people worse off as far as superannuation is concerned," Howard said.

SPEECH.PARA: There is some helpful analysis from Mr Megalogenis on this. He says:

What Willis was saying was clear enough. If the Coalition maintains its present policy to freeze the Superannuation Guarantee Charge at the levels applying at the next election, then ordinary workers would end up with much lower payouts than under Labor.

That is the key point. That is a constant and recurring theme, showing the real attitude of those opposite, whatever they express. Ordinary workers would end up being worse off under them than they are under the current government, be it with superannuation or the award conditions, wages and entitlements they could expect to receive from those opposite. In his article, Mr Megalogenis goes on to say:
The Willis argument is self-evident—a 5 or 6 per cent SGC will deliver a smaller super benefit than the 15 per cent benchmark being phased in by the Government.

PARA.TAB: Howard will be vulnerable on this point for as long as he continues to put off industry and employer calls to embrace bipartisanship on the SGC. Howard would have a hard time supporting the line run by John Hewson at the last election that a freeze on the SGC somehow preserves people's existing entitlements.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Megalogenis finishes by saying:
It is Howard's battlers—
a perverse combination of words—

the low-income workers who cannot afford to top up their super—who are the most vulnerable. Freezing the SGC and then providing tax incentives for voluntary savings above that level will not help them break out of the small-amounts trap.

The complete answer to the motion moved by the member for Stirling is contained in the policies that the government has adopted over the last 10 years. It is contained in the policies indicated by the government in the most recent budget so far as national savings and superannuation are concerned.

PARA.TAB: The final rebuttal to the motion moved by the member for Stirling is the attitude the opposition took when it was previously in government and the attitude and policies which the Leader of the Opposition is now personally handcuffed to, ensuring that ordinary workers will be worse off under the coalition with respect to wages, entitlements or superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, contrary to the claim by the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the most vulnerable people under Labor's superannuation are the itinerant workers, women and those who endure broken service, as witnessed by the present high levels of unemployment—and unemployment amongst those who had been in the work force for a long time. The other disadvantaged people under Labor's proposals are those who earn less than the average wage, and that is by far the greater number of the Australian work force.

PARA.TAB: I was interested in the honourable gentleman's observation that this motion represents some new interest by members on this side of the House. Let me assure the honourable member and the House that there have been umpteen bills on superannuation introduced by this government and on many of them there has not been one single speaker on the Labor side to uphold, defend or in other ways promote Labor's superannuation programs. On so many occasions we have not had anyone to put the case for Labor.

I would like to go to a couple of points touched on by the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) earlier. What he says about what the superannuation scheme means to domestic savings worries me. It may or may not prove to be the case that domestic savings are improved as a result of Labor's compulsory superannuation scheme. There tends to be grave exaggeration when people like the honourable member for Lilley say what he had to say about the effect on domestic savings. There is no evidence yet that compulsory superannuation will increase domestic savings. Indeed, there must be extreme doubt. There is a very real possibility that superannuation as it is now constituted and is being constituted will become a mere substitute for other forms of domestic savings.

One might expect that those people now making provision for their own retirement or of a mind to do so some time in the not too distant future will reach the point of view that because they are making compulsory contributions that will be sufficient to meet their needs in retirement. Nothing could be further from the truth. I have said before in this place—and I do mean it sincerely—that I wish the government would tone down its rhetoric in this regard.

The other matter the honourable member for Lilley touched on is that somehow superannuation as it is now constituted is going to make a great contribution to reducing our indebtedness in this country. He went on to say that the Commonwealth is not responsible for our high level of debt, that it has only borrowed something like four per cent of our net overseas borrowings. The truth is that in the last two or three years the government will increase its borrowing requirements by $50 billion to some $90 billion. It does not matter whether it borrows that $50 billion overseas or in Australia. The truth is that it will probably borrow it in Australia. Those in the private sector will in that case be crowded out. It is the crowding out effect which we have heard mentioned before which is conveniently ignored by people like the honourable member for Lilley.

If the government borrows $50 billion on the Australian financial markets, others who need to take up the slack will have to borrow overseas. It is as simple as that. On top of that, of course, no superannuation scheme is going to offset our disastrous balance of trade and balance of payments figures. They are at the heart of this country's indebtedness. The superannuation scheme that we are talking about now is not going to overcome that fact. So we have the government exaggerating the effects of superannuation in the run-up to the next election because it does not have very much else to peddle, if you think about it. The truth is that there are still people who will at the end of their time need to rely on the public sector to finance their retirement, and this scheme is not going to alter that one jot.

TALK.START.PARA: —This private member's motion is concerned with two essential things—the question of adequate provision for retirement income and the question of national savings. The opposition's approach to these two issues has displayed almost breathtaking cynicism. A lot has been said on the part of members of the opposition about these particular questions. But the fact that there has been no announcement, no presentation, no statement of policy in connection with them indicates the superficial approach that the opposition has made.

PARA.TAB: Just by way of example, the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron), who moved this private member's motion—presumably to indicate his concern and that of his colleagues about these two important areas of retirement income and national savings—has not even remained in the chamber to hear the debate through. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that is an unfortunate practice which is starting to intrude into the operation of this place.

There are occasions when, for the sake of courtesy and procedure, it is important for people to remain in the chamber, and it disappoints me to see practices and courtesies of that kind starting to go by the way. However, there are a number of members on both sides of the chamber who are aware of them, who recognise them and who act according to them. The particular point I make is that the absence of the member for Stirling from this debate—a debate which is taking place as a result of the motion relating to retirement income and national savings which that member has moved—indicates, as I said, the breathtaking cynicism with which the opposition has approached these questions generally.

The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who spoke before me, is one of the better-informed members. As we know, he now sits on the cross benches because, despite the fact that he is well informed on superannuation and questions of this kind, he has been abandoned by the Liberal Party. I do not know who the party has chosen to replace him after the next election. But I know he is standing as an Independent and, because he is well informed, I expect he will be successful in pursuing a return to this parliament. However, one of the points made by the member for Curtin was that, in his assessment, there are two important groups of people who are not being provided with adequate attention under this government's approach to superannuation: itinerant workers, and people who have interrupted periods of employment.

When it becomes possible for a former member of the opposition, now an Independent, to compress into just those two relatively small groups of people perhaps what he attempts to identify as some inadequacy in superannuation, it reflects admirably on the approach that this government has made to the whole question of superannuation. Everyone knows that, before 1983, when this government first came into office, less than 40 per cent of all wage and salary earners in Australia were covered by any form of superannuation—I repeat: less than 40 per cent.

You do not need to guess really hard to determine who the people were who were covered by superannuation provisions at that time. They were the wealthiest, the highest income earners in the community—and they were essentially males. Less than 25 per cent of women in employment in 1983 were covered by any form of superannuation provision for their retirement security. Now, as a result of the policies that this government has put into place, 90 per cent of wage and salary earners can be assured that, on their retirement, they will have appropriate levels of superannuation to supplement that basic safety net of the old age pension and to ensure that they do have an appropriate level of retirement security from those incomes.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the continuing problem in the construction and building industry of subcontractors not being paid by contractors, resulting in bankruptcy, liquidations and loss of jobs;

(2)maintains that the Commonwealth should set the example as a client to enter into contracts conditional upon the main contractor paying subcontractors before further payments or progress payments are made;

(3)notes that State and Territory legislatures have the same opportunities, in drawing up contracts, to require a condition in those contracts that subcontractors be paid in full as a prerequisite to further progress payments; and

(4)recommends to the Minister for Administrative Services that he (a) take the necessary action to protect subcontractors on all federal contracts and (b) entreat his State and Territory counterparts to (i) take similar action to protect subcontractors on all State and Territory projects and (ii) enact legislation to protect subcontractors on private construction and building projects.

The terms of the motion are self-explanatory and I believe should receive the bipartisan support of all members of this House, as indicated by the fact that the member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) has agreed to second the motion and because we all understand the problems created throughout Australian business by payments to subcontractors.

PARA.TAB: The motion speaks of a long-term problem in our building and housing industry: the non-payment to subcontractors by contractors right across Australia. It is not only an Australian problem; it is a worldwide problem. Some of the other developed nations have taken various remedial actions, but Australia and Great Britain are two exceptions to this remedial legislation.

Firstly, I want to say that I am not embarking on an exercise against builders and contractors. For any proposal to succeed it must be recognised that there are many parties to any construction project: the client, the provider of finance, the builder, state legislators providing standards, subcontractors, providers of material, and tradespeople. All these need consideration in any proposal that is put forward.

Over the past decade we have seen, firstly, an upgrading of the licensing provisions of state governments for builders; secondly, standard construction contracts, approved by state governments, as agreements between client and contractor; thirdly, states and the federal government have insisted on quality assurance right across the trade; and, fourthly, various states have implemented legislation for a subcontractors' charges act.

As a consequence, we would feel that Australia has a fully accredited building industry and now requires an effective and secure payments system for all those parties who contribute towards the contract undertaken. The reality is that Australia has no system to ensure that funds made available to a contract are paid out, fully and on time, to all those who are a party to the contract and who provide material and labour.

On a Commonwealth level, the Joint Committee on Public Works for the period of this year has been adding to its recommendations one that calls on the Commonwealth or its departments to ensure payment to subcontractors of progress and final payments.This is on fairly safe grounds. The client—that is, the Commonwealth—has been allocated the funds and will pay the contract price and approved extras. By contracting with the builder to pay subcontractors, the Commonwealth is in a unique position to implement a system and lead, by example, the various states and territory authorities. We are advised by the departments that this has operated very successfully over many years.

One would consider then that the states and territories, again as the client with the funds appropriated, would act in exactly the same way as the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, this is not the case, and I quote my own state of Queensland as an example.

Firstly, the Courier-Mail reported on 7 June 1995 that at the same time as the Premier of Queensland was opening with glitter the $203 million Brisbane Convention Centre, a contract for which the Queensland government was the client, Leighton Contractors faced writs from an electrical subcontractor, a scaffolding subbie, Evans Deakin, and another subcontractor who is in provisional liquidation as a result of the failure, among many others. The administrative services minister, the Hon. Glen Millner, told parliament that about $25 million was still outstanding to five or six major subcontractors.

Another is Q Build, where the same minister is responsible for public housing. On 12 July 1993, the minister wrote to a constituent firm of mine, which had a problem of payment on a state government contract, in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: You may be aware I recently announced the Government has moved to adopt new contractual provisions which give subcontractors a greater measure of protection of payment for all State Government major building projects.

Cabinet has agreed the new contractual provisions will be embodied within the State Purchasing Policy, thus making them uniformly applicable to all major government building and construction projects. My own Department will be applying them to the construction of public housing.
These new provisions will ensure that:
.in appropriate circumstances securities are available to satisfy Subcontractors claims;
.contractors lodge additional security or alternatively set up retention trust funds.
.specified forms of contracts are used for subcontracted works;

.Contractors set up payment recording systems which will provide evidence from subcontractors that they have been paid all moneys due and payable at the time progress payments are claimed by Contractors.
The Government is concerned by the number of Subcontractors who have endured financial hardship because of the collapse, or unscrupulous actions, of building firms.

The same constituent business, addressed by the minister on 12 June 1993, subcontracting on another building with Q Build as the client, on 13 January 1995 was forced to secure an order from the Queensland Building Tribunal for $16,670 against the contractor. Again, the builder had received moneys from the state authority but had not applied them in the appropriate manner. This amount of $16,670 still remains unpaid along with $300,000 of additional creditors—$128,714 in additional subcontractors.

PARA.TAB: On 24 February 1995 the builder petitioned under the Bankruptcy Act to declare total liabilities of $326,000 and a deficiency of funds of $310,000. Q Build had apparently paid the contract price without any reference to the undertaking given by the same minister on 12 July 1993. This result is a failure on behalf of the state government to ensure payment to subbies and has led to a closure of business, a resultant loss of experienced labour and further unemployment, in spite of their best intentions as was indicated by the minister.

It is important to reiterate that, in any failure of a building contractor, there is a massive domino effect that could mean bankruptcy or liquidation of subbies, material suppliers and unemployed tradespeople. The Commonwealth loses from taxation on these profits and there is an increase in social security payments and in the cost of material and labour to overcome the inherent risk factor caused through previous failures in those circumstances.

The third scenario that the motion addresses is the one where the failure of government to act has created the biggest problem, and that is in the non-government sector: the private sector. This failure is almost a common, everyday feature of Australian business life—examples of which have happened in Mackay very recently and ended in a public meeting for the subcontractors. Here the government, state or federal, has little control except by way of setting standards, and often the client can be the problem as much as the contractor through insecure and inadequate financial arrangements. The reality of the Subcontractors' Charges Act, where it exists, is that if a subcontractor wishes to register his name with the client for preferred payment then he may get that job but will not get any further work.

Normally a supplier of materials to a job can insist on personal or directors' guarantees and can ensure against bad debts. This avenue is not available to a subbie whose business normally does not have the same degree of administration as does a client, a contractor or a supplier of materials. I understand other countries have enacted legislation to ensure payment to subcontractors through a trust account. While the business industry is regulated by the licensing and accreditation procedures and quality assurance, surely it is not outside the enterprise of government to legislate to protect all parties, although I am not recommending the trust account system.

However, it must be said that there will always be a risk and no government should intervene to protect a person or persons who should make themselves aware of that risk and provide accordingly. Even on government jobs, a supplier of material, labour and service runs a degree of risk and more so if their administrative procedures and standards are not those required for a business successfully being conducted in Australia today.

Having outlined the problems which I believe are apparent to all the parties, I reiterate that the answer is not in recriminations—one against the other—or in public criticisms of government. The answer can be supplied only in an atmosphere of common purpose and goodwill between all the parties. I am therefore encouraged to find in the course of our Public Works Committee inquiries that there are bodies and committees which are working for that common purpose and goodwill, particularly in New South Wales.

I am similarly encouraged to know that the federal Minister for Administrative Services, the Hon. Frank Walker, has endeavoured through his state ministerial council to suggest further work and cooperation to find solutions both in government contracts and in private contractual arrangements. A news clipping from the Australian Financial Review of 31 May 1995 gives substance to this—that the standardisation by the ministers is being sought and they recognise a lot of the problems that are now being created within the building industry as being something they can collectively address. I thank the minister for his cooperation in that regard.

There is also a royal commission into the productivity of the building industry of 1992 in New South Wales specifically addressing subcontractors and a separate report, Cottage industry investigation: the money trail for the cottage industry, which demonstrates that the subcontractors are responsible for a significant component of the value of building projects in New South Wales. There are other subcontractor groups forming within states with particular interest of the subbies in mind. There are various suggestions of copying from other nations—particularly Canada, Europe and the United States—in the forming of trusts and the providing of safeguards for interest groups, but I must say that the forming of trusts may not be the particular answer because of the cost involved with it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can remember when the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) approached me to second this motion before the House today. I have much pleasure in seconding it. If ever there were a subject that was very near and dear to my heart, it is the protection of subcontractors. When I was a businessman many years ago, I was approached by a subcontractor who was a customer of mine. He said, `I am in a bit of trouble. I may not be able to pay my bill this month because the contractor has defaulted on paying me for the work I have done on the Bundaberg civic centre.' He finally got paid. But then the contractor of the day—a man named Kratzman, who appeared again and again in many business transactions—went bankrupt on the Bundaberg civic centre.He had paid this plumber for his subcontract work but, because the payment had been made six months before the contractor went bankrupt, the plumber had to pay that money back—even though it was payment for work he had done.

PARA.TAB: I certainly hope that the legislation has changed since those days. But I can remember that very well. He could not afford to pay back the total amount of money. He agreed to pay a shilling a week—I think that is what it was in those days—and, hopefully, he has continued to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is probably still paying.

—Hopefully he is, because of the way the legislation was in those days. But, as I say, that was some 30 years ago. Today we are still in this parliament trying to ensure that legislation will be introduced not only in the federal parliament but also in the state parliaments, which is where we can protect those legitimate subcontractors.

PARA.TAB: I know that not all subcontractors are honest and worthy of being protected all the time, but the majority I know have always been worthy of being protected. If ever I feel inadequate about having been here for 18 years and not having ensured that certain legislation was introduced into this parliament, it is about legislation that protects those subcontractors.

All the members of the Public Works Committee are here. We have present the very distinguished chairman of that committee, the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), and all the other members of the Public Works Committee. They are all committed. Every time that we have a Public Works Committee hearing, the member for Dawson always asks the officers who are appearing before the committee whether they are ensuring that the subcontractors are paid. We are always told, `Yes, they will be paid,' but we know that they are always subject to the legislation.

We have found from time to time, as the honourable member for Dawson pointed out today, that the contractors always try to wriggle their way out of paying some of the subcontractors because of legal technicalities. That is what we are here about today. We are trying to ensure that we do introduce uniform legislation throughout this nation that will protect those genuine and honest businessmen that are being dudded all day and every day over many years.

We only have to cast our minds back to the 1980s. I refer to the cover story of the Bulletin entitled `Whatever happened to yesterday's corporate heroes?' which covers all of these corporate crooks. We can name them: Alan Bond, Ian Johns, John Spalvins, Bob Ansett, John Baker, Brian Yuill, John Elliott, George Herscu, Laurie Connell, Russell Goward, Bill Farrow, John Avram, Christopher Skase—there is a good one—Tim Marcus-Clarke, Abraham Goldberg and Reuben Lew. I could go on.

It even lists Bryan Grey. There are all these subcontractors that he did not pay, but he is back again before the courts suing Qantas because it will not allow him to start up another Compass. Can you believe the hide of these people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely outrageous!

—It is absolutely outrageous, as the honourable member points out. All of these people dudded the small businessmen, including young people and subcontractors, that we are mentioning here today—this is being raised not only because of the Public Works Committee—and ruined their families and made them sell their homes, but they squandered some $16 billion themselves.

PARA.TAB: The question has been, and still is today, not where the money has come from but where it has gone to. We all know where it has gone. It is up to this parliament and all of the state parliaments to ensure that we protect the genuine people. I add that many of the customers of my garage were caught by these corporate crooks, and their lives were ruined by these types of people.

I just mention that last year the Public Works Committee authorised the expenditure of some $320 million of Commonwealth moneys, taxpayer dollars. This year also we have been very busy. The chairman keeps us busy all the time and we are very happy to meet all around Australia to ensure that taxpayers' dollars are being spent correctly. This year we have already approved over $1 billion worth of taxpayers' money on works that the Commonwealth is obliged to carry out.

It is our important duty to bring before this parliament the concerns of subcontractors. I can honestly say that I do not believe there is a member or senator in this parliament who has not been approached by a subcontractor or a small business person who has been hurt by contractors not paying for their services.

The central issue of concern is the financial and emotional hardship experienced by subcontractors in the building industry who are faced with financial ruin when a contractor becomes insolvent. When I decided to speak on this notice of motion I contacted the Law and Public Administration Group of the Parliamentary Research Service in the Parliamentary Library and I spoke to Brendan Bailey, who has been very helpful in giving me information about the law. Brendan informed me that only two states have legislation to protect subcontractors and these are New South Wales and Queensland. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales Industrial Relations Act 1991, at section 154, protects the wages of an "employee" of a contractor. The New South Wales law requires the person who engages the contractor to certify that no wages are due and payable by the contractor at the time of the payment.

PARA.TAB: In Queensland, the Subcontractors' Charges Act 1974—

SPEECH.PARA: this goes back that far—
creates a "charge" in favour of a subcontractor over the moneys payable to a contractor (section 5).

I would like to quote also from a paper that Brendan gave to me titled `Real and Personal Securities', written by Mr W.D. Duncan, a solicitor from Queensland, and Lindy Willmott. They say this about the Subcontractors' Charges Act of 1974:

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding the laudable objects of the legislation alleviating the financial risk of subcontractors, the legislation has received much criticism both by the judiciary and the builders' lobby in Queensland. Although the builders' lobby may have a vested interest in limiting the operation of the Act or wishing it repealed altogether, the criticisms made by the judiciary stem from the ambiguity of the legislation. As stated by Dunn J. in Ex p Pavex Constructions Pty Ltd

SPEECH.PARA: There is a wealth of information in this on the inadequacies of the legislation. I do not have time to go through all of the judgments referred to, but I can say that all of the big names in contractors—John Holland Constructions, et cetera—are involved in still refusing to pay subcontractors.

PARA.TAB: So it is up to this parliament and the state parliaments to introduce uniform legislation.
