It is important too to look at the 1995 report of the Victorian Law Reform Committee into the curbing of phoenix companies, which goes a long way towards curbing the activities of these people who deliberately refuse to pay very deserving subcontractors throughout our nation. It is a problem that we must deal with and which, surely, if we all work together, we can resolve. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to rise in support of the motion moved by the member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), to follow the remarks made by the member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) and to acknowledge that under the chairmanship of the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) the Joint Committee on Public Works is quite a purposeful and bipartisan committee. The member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) is something of an outsider participating in this debate, but I welcome his involvement as well.

PARA.TAB: I stand here reflecting some of the member for Griffith's remarks, but with even more passion for subcontractors than he is prepared to show. I think that subcontractors are at the heart of business success in Australia. Fundamentally, subcontractors say, `What can I do better than anyone else?' and set out to prove the point. If we want to run a more efficient economy, we want people who believe in individual competition, in the right to bid for individual jobs and in the right to prove that they can outperform everybody else. Subcontractors fit this die.

The key employment opportunities in Australia and the jobs that are the most demanding and the most labour intensive, particularly in such areas as the rural industry—jobs such as shearing or fruit picking—are invariably what could loosely be called subcontracted jobs. To choose to employ anyone in those vocations by any other basis would be a way of ensuring that the business went broke. Subcontracting is the way to get the best out of people. What the member for Dawson has called for in his motion today is an opportunity for governments at state and federal level to lead by example and remove what are current disincentives to subcontractors getting into business. It is fair to say—I know it is frequently misrepresented—that there is no interest quite like self-interest. It is self-interest that drives subcontractors to be as efficient as they are.

I am afraid that some of the remarks made by members of the government are a little conditioned. I refer to a comment made by the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns) last month in a report from the magazine Inside Canberra. The assistant minister was calling on a research project funded by Worksafe Australia where he wants the impact of subcontractors on the workplace to be evaluated. In his press release he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Because they are paid for output, the pressure is on subcontractors to work long hours and often they work too fast with inadequate breaks. This means injuries are more likely to happen.

I understand and applaud the effort by the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations to eliminate unnecessary risk in the occupational health and safety areas. I think that is entirely commendable. But I have to say that I think that the opportunity to eliminate risk should be restricted only to occupational health and safety because the involvement of subcontractors in making real productivity increases ought to be applauded.

PARA.TAB: I recognise that the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has just left the chamber. I am sorry that I did not have an opportunity earlier in my remarks to focus on one of the things that I recall him saying not only in this House but also in the opposition party room. He has, as a member of parliament, deliberately set about cultivating subcontractors and giving them an opportunity. Unemployed people who have come into his office have been given the opportunity to start their own subcontracting business, either as a result of lawn-mowing rounds or window cleaning rounds or what are seen as menial tasks that allow people to cease to be unemployed and be directly employed in the opportunities that go with being subcontractors.

The member for Dawson, in bringing this motion into the House, has asked us to do as the member for O'Connor has done—that is, to set about encouraging the psyche of subcontracting, encouraging people to be independent, to stand on their own and to ensure that they have an opportunity to contribute to society and to see, frankly, that the sorts of arrangements that have existed in the past, which may have meant that subcontractors were innocently caught up in a bankruptcy claim and consequently not paid, are eliminated, so far as that is possible for the parliament to achieve.

Fundamentally, the thrust of the member for Dawson's motion has been a call for legislation to protect the innocent. It is not possible for a subcontractor to know whether the contract that he has entered into—particularly a building contract in the case of the Public Works Committee—with the principal contractor is financially secure or not. That sort of information is even denied to shareholders in some principal building companies. It is highly unlikely that the subcontractor would know whether he is likely to be paid.

The member for Dawson has set in place a proposal that suggests that both the Commonwealth and state governments should underwrite the payment to subcontractors, which would ensure that they are not placed at unreasonable risk. This is an entirely humane thing to do. Subcontractors are, after all, small businessmen. But, more than that, subcontractors employ people—which effectively ensures that additional people are taken out of the unemployment pool and placed in full-time employment—and those employees of subcontractors are also at risk.

If I were an employee of a major business company that was going broke, I would have an opportunity to be part of the priority payment from that company that is going broke. In the same way that the creditors have an obligation to make provision for the tax arrangements of that company, they also have to make provision for the wages arrangements of that company's employees. But what happens to a subcontractor? He is an employee with no protection and also with no opportunity to protect his own frequently part-time employees. So this proposal gives us an opportunity not only to provide security for the subbie but also to provide security for the subbie's employees, whom all members on both sides of the House would clearly want protected.

The member for Griffith has said that subcontractors are `worthy of protection', and I endorse his remarks. He has indicated that some subcontractors are less honourable than others, as we all know, but that is nothing more than a reflection of society generally: it applies to employees as well as to subcontractors. What the proposal before the House does is to focus the attention of private employers on the arrangements that should be put in place to protect subcontractors.

The member for Dawson referred to the role of the Public Works Committee under its present chairman. In fact, the committee met this morning to look at two major projects. It considered the report on the project for the air traffic control facilities at Darwin. Paragraph 85 of the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence advised the Committee that payments to subcontractors will be protected as the Defence contracts will specify that contractors must specify that contractors have been paid before further payments are made to the contractors.

The committee also considered the proposal for expanded Defence facilities in Townsville. In response to an inquiry from the member for Dawson, the committee took deliberate action in relation to the protection of subcontractors. A portion of paragraph 79 states:
While the managing contractor engages the subcontractors payments to subcontractors are made out of a trust account which is controlled by Defence.

The feasibility of providing such a trust account, which ensures that the employees of subcontractors and subcontractors themselves are not placed at unreasonable risk, is the mainspring behind the member for Dawson's motion. I am happy to be identified with such a motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to congratulate my colleague on the Joint Committee on Public Works the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) on his decision to raise the matter now before the House. It has been an issue that both he and the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) have consistently raised in public hearings.

PARA.TAB: It is well known that one of the worst things that can happen to anyone is to find himself or herself suddenly, and often quite unexpectedly, out of work and facing bankruptcy. The situation becomes even more intolerable when that person is married and has several young children to support. Should that person also have several other workers and their families depending on him or her for their livelihood, the problem becomes that much worse again.

From time to time, most unfortunately, this happens in all walks of life. We are used to hearing about such happenings in the farming community especially during times of severe drought, as we are now experiencing. We also hear similar accounts from people running small businesses.

It is hard to fully comprehend the pain and anguish suffered by those people and their families. Imagine for a moment a person who over the years has gradually developed a reputation for honest, competent and reliable work; a person who has built up a business over years of study and hard toil working long hours for only moderate gain. Imagine then the distress and the anger when that person quite suddenly, and through no fault or his or her own, loses practically everything he or she has worked for and can no longer support the family. We have all, I am sure, met such people.

As chairman of the Public Works Committee, I have become aware of one particular group of people who are particularly prone to becoming victims of such extraordinary hardship—the subcontractors in the building and construction industry. Too often, it seems, through no fault of their own, those people suffer severe economic hardship because the main contractor who engages them for a particular piece of work on a building or construction site goes broke. When this happens, the subcontractor generally has no option but to join the long queue of other creditors, each of them hoping to retrieve some small percentage of what they are owed. For the subcontractor, failure to do so almost invariably leads to bankruptcy. It is my conviction, and it is one shared by other members of the Public Works Committee, that the time has come—and, indeed, is overdue—to address this problem.

The security of payment problem has been commonplace throughout the building and construction industry for some years but has, it seems, become appreciably worse over the last decade. It is a problem that becomes more serious during periods marked by a downturn in building activity. During good times there is a proliferation of builders and major contractors but, when the industry experiences a downturn, in the mad scramble to gain contracts firms are tempted to tender at or below what they perceive to be the minimum cost. Is it any wonder then that a number of them experience cash flow problems and go bankrupt?

The problem is even more acute for subcontractors. While security of payment has become a major issue in the building and construction industry generally, the subcontracting nature of most projects makes those lower in the chain particularly vulnerable to any insolvency at a higher level. Being in small business, subcontractors work on very limited capital at the best of times. They are faced with bills that must be paid promptly and they need the assurance of a reliable cash flow. This does not always happen. It is not at all uncommon that they may find themselves waiting for up to three months to be paid for their work.

In recent years, the security of payment problem has become the subject of considerable investigation. This, I am pleased to say, has resulted in a number of limited legislative measures, as the member for Griffith mentioned, in both New South Wales and Queensland. The time has now come when similar and stronger measures should be introduced by this parliament.

Firstly, as the honourable member for Dawson proposes, the Commonwealth should set the example in all its government contracts. A number of government departments, notably the Department of Defence, already protect subcontractors by including in their contract documents a clause which states that subcontractors must be paid before any further progress payments are made to the head contractor. The departments also insist that the head contractor must provide a statutory declaration that subcontractors have indeed been paid, and only then does the head contractor become eligible for further payment.

The motion now before the House would have the effect of making this practice mandatory for all federal government departments. I am realistic enough to acknowledge that legislation cannot of itself completely eliminate the security of payment problem. I am convinced, however, that such legislation can make a significant contribution to reducing the problem first of all in the area of government contracts and then by encouraging further enactments in the state and territory legislatures. I would also hope that such government initiatives would foster the development within the industry's private sector of a code of best practice which would seek to eliminate this problem altogether.

As I explained, when subcontractors are not paid by the head contractor there are massive social and economic costs which must be borne by the subcontractors and their employees and families. For this reason alone, we should be addressing the problem. It must also logically follow that if payments to subcontractors are to be protected, which we all agree they should, then payments to the employees of subcontractors should be protected also. We should make sure that the main contractors only employ subcontractors on these major building projects that have good track records and can provide the services required.

Unfortunately, there are too many $2 companies. I have had experience in my own area—and I have recently led a delegation to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) on this issue—where those companies go bust and then form again with the same set of directors. If we are going to be strict on the main contractor, we must be equally strict on the subcontractors to make sure that they fulfil their requirements and protect those who work for them.

There is, however, a further reason for seeking to remove this problem. This problem has serious consequences for the entire building and construction industry and, consequently, for the nation. Several years ago the Security of Payments Industry Committee undertook a major study of the problem in New South Wales. It examined the records of several bankrupt companies as well as received evidence from contractors, subcontractors, suppliers and consultants.

The committee's chairperson concluded that the total losses in the industry during the year 1989-90 in New South Wales alone amounted to $1.1 billion from a turnover of $9.66 billion. This represents a loss of 11.3 per cent on the total investment. I should make it clear that this loss was spread throughout the overall industry and was not borne by the subcontractors alone. They, nevertheless, are in a particularly vulnerable position and are compelled to bear a disproportionately large share of the losses.

It is certainly true that there are available within the industry a number of standard building industry contracts. Their use must be encouraged until such time as they become part of a standard code of conduct. Such contracts allow multiple parties to enter into contractual arrangements which seek to safeguard payments at each stage of the building or construction process. They bind the various parties—such as the owner or client, the head contractor and the subcontractor—to a scheme of payments whereby the head contractor's payments can be delivered where necessary to the unpaid subcontractor.

A number of authorities have indicated that the use of standard building industry contracts can have two positive effects. Firstly, they can reduce individual hardship within the industry and, secondly, they can lead to significant cost savings. This is because tender prices could then more accurately reflect the true cost of construction because contractors and subcontractors would no longer have the need to build into their prices an unknown and sometimes excessive allowance for pricing risks beyond their control.

To turn once again to the Security of Payments Industry Committee in New South Wales, the chairperson of that committee has estimated that the provision of a secure payments scheme within the industry should reduce construction costs by some 2.5 per cent. I commend this motion to the House. I again congratulate the honourable member for Dawson for bringing this important topic to the attention of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Small business is the backbone of Australia. Along with the farmers, it is the essential spine of our economy. The building subcontractors are an important part of that. It is very easy for small business to go broke, particularly in these current economic conditions. If you happen to be a building subcontractor and you are faced with the enormous fluctuations in the building construction industry, it makes it easier to go bankrupt. If you get caught up with a major contractor who duds you, takes all the money out of the project and then does not pay the subbies, then you are on the slippery road to ruin.

PARA.TAB: I note that the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) made brief mention of the code of best practices, and I commend him for that. It is a very nice idea, but the reality is that all the codes under the sun are still just idle rhetoric. We need legislation that encapsulates the motion moved by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite). I commend the member for Dawson and the other speakers in the debate for their contributions. For one moment I felt slightly excluded as all speakers are members of the Joint Committee on Public Works, but let me assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the people of Australia that great numbers of members and senators in this place are concerned about subcontractors and the tremendous job that they do.

I know of many examples of problems for subcontractors in my electorate. Opal Cove is a wonderful resort which is functioning perfectly, but during construction the builders went bankrupt, broke, disappeared or whatever—I forget the exact circumstances—and dozens of hard-working, responsible subcontractors were not paid and went broke. Every member in this House can advance similar examples.

The time has come when this must stop. I welcome the motion because the member for Dawson encapsulates everything that needs to be done. I particularly note that he recommends to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) that he take necessary action to protect subcontractors on all federal contracts. The minister is originally from my electorate—he is a Sawtell boy—and I am sure he will take note of the recommendations contained within the motion. I hope he does because this matter is vitally important.

I can give the House two examples. A concreter was not paid $60,000 and went down the drain. A subcontractor involved with airconditioning was not paid $60,000 and he also went broke. Labourers, tradesmen and members of parliament do their work and get paid, but subcontractors have to spend money to be able to perform the work. In many cases they have to outlay tens of thousands of dollars. When they do not get paid they go down the drain.

This morning I conducted a small survey of some of the solicitors in my area to see how many cases of non-payment of subcontractors they have pending. One solicitor currently has three cases and others have had dozens of cases over the years. I have just been handed a note which indicates that one subcontractor lost $70,000. Another lost $30,000 for the roundabout at Port Macquarie—in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile. Some builders lost $12,000 in another instance, another lost $15,000 at Bonville and another contractor lost $13,000.

We must provide additional assistance for subcontractors. Many subcontractors start work on the basis of an oral agreement, but when the contract comes along six months later it bears no relationship to what was actually said. The Commonwealth should take the lead and ensure that when we award a contract we do not merely do it on the basis of price, because all too often in tough economic times people will cut their quotes to the bone to try to survive and as a result they are bound to go broke. As a Commonwealth, we should set the example and only award contracts where they are viable. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank my colleagues for the opportunity to sum up in this debate. I thank them most sincerely for bringing to the parliament what I believe is not only a recognised problem but also an indication that on bipartisan lines we can do something about it if we have the will. We have demonstrated the inherent problems; I think they are common to us all as we go about our electorates. It also demonstrates a genuine desire for a bipartisan solution to this problem.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) mentioned the 20- or 30-year-old problem of a preferred payment within six months of the time of a bankruptcy and that that has not yet been corrected. Thirty years down the track we can still find a subcontractor receiving a progress payment which he is fully entitled to and the main builder goes broke, so there is a preferential payment involved which then goes back. Also, in this debate it has been mentioned that direct wages, paid by a person who is subject to a bankruptcy order or is in liquidation, are protected if they are unpaid. But, if it happens that a subcontractor is paid those wages, and if it is in the form of a payment due to him, there is no suggestion of protection there. I believe that this is the essence of the problem.

The setting up of individual trusts for each individual contract has been suggested. I am led to believe that would be almost unworkable from the point of view of the accounting that would have to be done and also to conform with the trust act. It has come to my notice that a trust which is in the same form as a trust for employees' tax deductions—in the form of group payments—is the solution. So the tax office, in the case of a liquidation, has a preferential claim to that amount.

A suggestion has been made in this debate that, in the event of a liquidation, where a contractor has been paid but has not paid the subcontractors or paid for materials and other items, a trust should be formed in exactly the same way as a preferential trust. I cannot, and I do not think my colleagues can, provide an immediate answer, but we hope that those people who are interested, those people who have practical experience in the finance and building industries, and also the legislators, can get together.

It is heartening that the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Frank Walker, has acknowledged the problem and is prepared to take it before a ministerial council. It is also heartening to realise that throughout Australia there are various groups which are prepared to look at it. For instance, the Construction Industry Development Agency has suggested lots of ways in which there can be security of payment which is linked to making sure the proper financial arrangements are made at the outset and, secondly, that preferred contractors are on a preselection list so that those people who have the ability to do a job—not the $2 companies as mentioned by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), but people who have the ability to do it right down to the subcontractor level—are screened. It is then necessary to ensure that those moneys are in the control of a person—whether it be a banker or a financier—or a building society so that when the payment is made the trust arrangements apply.

So if $10,000 is paid to a subcontractor who is entitled to $2,000, and there is $8,000 for other subbies, that $8,000 must be treated in a trust-like manner. In that way we have security of finance—something that is not always available today. Lots of people recklessly go into a program without adopting a proper contract between the two parties. In fact, I have known cases where, upon getting a contract, the first thing a contractor will do is employ a solicitor so that they can look for the extras and the gaps in the program. If only governments were able to legislate to make sure there is a standard contract which is not subject to the alterations which are so often the case today. That is the security of payment. This body is also security for payment. If there are disputes between one and the other, there can be dispute negotiations and these can be adjusted quite simply on the site. The money is there; it can flow through. In a trust arrangement, in the event of a liquidation, those moneys have to be accounted for, as do so many others.

I hope this is not the last debate here on this matter. I hope we have been able to use this as a catalyst to make sure the state authorities, in conjunction with the Commonwealth, can make these legislative procedures available—a code of conduct not written into legislation, but something that is recognised that builds on the registrations that take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The time allotted for this debate has expired. Before I call the next speaker, I might just clarify this point.The member for Dawson sought leave to speak again to the motion. I presume he did so on the basis that he was not going to close the debate.
—No.
—The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House expresses concern about the exemptions and privileges now enjoyed by telecommunications carriers and calls on the Government to make the erection of mobile phone base stations subject to the consent of local councils.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to everyone living in suburban Australia, `Whether you like it or not, there is now a mobile phone tower near you.' This is the downside of the mobile phone revolution—an ugly thicket of poles and wires, a whole series of electronic pogo sticks which now blight Australia's suburban streetscapes. Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, it will get worse.

PARA.TAB: By conservative estimates, the numbers of mobile phones are supposed to double before the year 2000, and the move from analog to digital mobile phones will halve the radius of the existing mobile phone base stations. That means that, instead of the existing 2,000 mobile phone towers and aerial arrays, we will have 10,000 or more of these things sprouting like toadstools all over suburban Australia before the year 2000. I support the spread of mobile phones, but I think it should be driven more by community imperatives and less by commercial imperatives. Certainly, this system should not be driven by the fantasies of engineers who have discovered yet another new toy to play with. As I said, I have no objection to the spread of mobile phones, but I believe these companies have to be made more accountable to the community which they are supposed to serve.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you or I want to build a flagpole in our backyards, we need to get permission from the local council. However, these telecommunications companies—Telstra, Optus and Vodafone—can put up a 30-metre high aerial virtually wherever they want. You and I have to ask the council for permission; Telstra, Vodafone and Optus simply have to tell the council that that is what they are going to do. This whole process of telling the council—not asking its permission—amounts to a fig leaf of consultation, masking the reality of untrammelled corporate power.

Under the government's existing rules, councils have 30 days to object to any proposal to put up a mobile phone tower. Anyone who has dealt with government realises that it takes 30 days for most government departments simply to open their mail. The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) typically takes up to six months to answer his correspondence. The minister does not answer his questions on notice within 90 days, let alone 30 days. For two months the minister has had a petition signed by 528 residents of my electorate protesting against a mobile phone installation in Harbord. He has not returned it to me, nor to the state member who sent it to him and he has not tabled it in this parliament, even though according to members opposite not to table a petition—at least in the case of John Halden and Carmen Lawrence—is a contempt of parliament. This whole idea that the rules are adequate because councils have 30 days in which to object is just nonsense.

Then, under the existing rules, the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories is to investigate. We have 2,000 mobile phone towers and aerials in this country. Of those 2,000, after objections, just two have been altered. That is a paltry rate of change. What it shows is that the existing system is a watchdog that does not even bark, let alone bite. I will give some practical examples. In one case, local councils sent out letters to residents two days before a 30-metre high tower was to be built on the roof of a private hospital. In another case, work had actually commenced on a mobile phone base station before local residents were even aware. In the case of the Harbord kindergarten Telstra mobile phone base station, which turned the issue from a local problem into a national issue, the council objected—and it did so with the support of Labor Senator Belinda Neal. Public meetings were held, in which a Telstra technical expert allegedly said that he would not like his kids going to school in the shadow of one of these installations. The Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories duly objected. Then Telstra wrote back and said that there was no alternative.

The department meekly rolled over, told Telstra to scratch its tummy and said, `You can go ahead.' It did not give any reasons. It did not seek any alternative sites. It did not look into the possibility of co-location. It did not seek confirmation of Telstra's claims in its letter. What is more, there is no evidence whatsoever that the department has done what it had said Telstra must do, namely, provide evidence of community consultation after the installation had gone ahead. Yet, notwithstanding all these grievous inadequacies, Austel, which is supposed to be the overarching regulator, said that Telstra has gone exactly by the book. That is proof that the book is wrong in the case of the regulation of these mobile phone towers.

The problems of these towers do not just concern my electorate. They are nationwide. The mothers of the Harbord community kindergarten have been contacted by other people who are objecting to installations in Northbridge, Asquith, Forbes in country New South Wales, and in Miranda. The representatives of 13 different groups are fighting 13 separate installations in Adelaide, in Woodford, Chapel Hill in Queensland, Mount Kuring-Gai and Baulkham Hills.

The Sydney Morning Herald reported that at least three councils—Pittwater, Shellharbour and Kiama—are fighting similar plans while Marrickville and Canterbury residents are opposing towers near their homes. People all around Australia are complaining about this threat to their backyards. These people are not latter-day Luddites; they are ordinary Australians who want to control their own backyards and who want to take control of their own neighbourhoods.

They are asking a very simple question: why is the telecommunications industry so different? What is so special about phone companies that means they can ignore the rules that everyone else has to obey? What is wrong with the telecommunications industry? What health risks, for instance, do these installations pose that lead these companies doing this work by stealth in the dead of the night whereas everyone else must ask permission from the council if they want to do anything, even to erect a flagpole?

I accept that we have been living with microwave ovens and electrical devices for a long time, apparently with no ill effect, but I also accept that we were living with asbestos and X-rays for a long time before we realised exactly what the health risks were. It is important to point out to the House that it is understandable that people should be worried about this industry when, for instance, Telstra received a letter from the CSIRO saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is inappropriate to make sound scientific judgments on safety thresholds. There are certain inadequacies in the international standards and CSIRO has commented on that issue.

The very same letter criticised the Australian Radiation Laboratory's report, on which basis Telstra said that this installation in Harbord was perfectly safe. Then we had another letter from the CSIRO to the parents of Harbord, which said:
We concluded that there was insufficient scientific evidence at the time to make any sound scientific judgement about safety thresholds.
So there we have it. The experts are not prepared to back the standards on which these things are proliferating all over suburban Australia.

PARA.TAB: There is only one way to make these things acceptable, and that is to get these phone companies to sit down and to talk to the people, to the neighbours of these installations. The only way for that to happen is to say to these phone companies that you cannot install a mobile phone tower without first going to the council and getting permission from the council in the same way that everyone else does.

These concerns are not simply mine. They are shared by the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) and the member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) on this side of the House, they are shared by the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack) and the member for Moore (Mr Filing) on the cross benches, and they are shared by the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) on the other side. They are even shared by Austel, which says that local councils need to be given more power.

I say to the government: put your policy where your protestations are. You say you want more power for local councils. Well, give it to them, not in 1997 but now, before it is too late. I say to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): has Ben Chifley's light on the hill been replaced by Paul Keating's Telstra tower on the hill? It will be a sad indictment of this government if it has.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Vaile)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Lowe (Mrs Easson) also shares a grave concern about these towers. I know I have only five minutes to speak, so I will quickly go through some of the major points in the speech I wanted to make. I received some letters just last week in regard to this situation, all from people in my electorate, about another tower that is going to be built—at Pearcedale. The tower is to be built just across the road from my electorate and the residents have raised various concerns.The other night during the adjournment debate, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) came into the chamber after a speech by the previous speaker. The minister said:

PARA.TAB: But the point I make is simply this: yes, there are some people who do not like a mobile telephone tower to be constructed near their home. Everyone likes to protect the value of their property. A lot of people think that nothing should ever be built in their own backyard.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree that everyone likes to look after the value of their property. The trouble is that when these towers go up, you will find your property value goes down. And it will go down by 25 per cent, I have been told—if you can sell your house—at the base of one of these. Why would your property value go down? You have your mobile telephone tower handy. You can just go out in the backyard and you have good reception. The value will go down because of the perceived problems with these towers. Maybe there are health problems; the jury is still out on that. As the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) said, asbestos at one stage was the in thing—but look at the problems with asbestos.

PARA.TAB: I say that the value of your home goes down. We have only to look at some of our valuable community buildings that have been defaced by these transmitters that are put on top of them. The value of those buildings has gone down. The value of living in the community has gone down because of these towers that are being erected all over the place. We must fight this trend—and stop it. What I have been advocating—I said it in a 90-second speech—is a moratorium on these towers. I believe that to be correct. There are many instances, which I will relate to the House at a future time, where companies are setting up now to provide satellite communications. We do not need these towers.

Are these towers going to be obsolete in 1997? It appears to me to be so. Satellites are being put up around the world to set up a communications system that we can use. What is going to happen to the Optuses of this world? Vodafone already has a bit of a financial problem. One newspaper is headed `Vodafone gushes red ink in cutthroat market', and states that Australia's third mobile telephone carrier, Vodafone, has made a loss of $45.4 million. It made this loss just this year. What happens if it goes bust when all the satellites go up? Who is going to pull down all the towers? It will be you and me, the taxpayers, who will pay for it.

I think all these companies should be putting some money into a trust fund to pay—if one of the companies goes bust—for the removal of these daleks that are being set up all over the place. As sure as eggs, one of them will go bust. There is not enough room for all these players, especially with the satellites coming on; there will be a lot of competition. There are the Bill Gateses of this world. Gates set up Microsoft and is going to have his own satellite communications system. Motorola is going to set one up. Teledesic, a Gates company, is going to be set up for satellite communication. They will all be competing for that one phone call—and the business will be very cutthroat. So there will be concrete and steel towers spread all over the countryside, with no-one owning them or having the responsibility for taking them down when they are old technology. This is not a long way off; it will happen very soon.

Another item that I have noticed in relation to mobile phones is that people with hearing aids have a problem. Those people hear a clicking; they are affected by the digital transmission tower. Hundreds of thousands of Australians have hearing aids, and they are all affected by this. The health effects of exposure to electromagnetic radiation remain unknown. I have articles from paper after paper on this, discussing mobile phones and health. The articles are looking into the problems that may be caused by mobile phone transmissions. The jury is still out on whether they are dangerous. I urge people who use mobile phones to use them with caution. Be careful, because the radiation from a mobile phone near your ear does not go just one way; it spreads around and 50 per cent of it goes into the soft tissue of your brain. This is a danger we should be aware of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday. The honourable member for Dunkley will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—I would like to draw the attention of the House to the importance of this week, a week which acknowledges both the community awareness and the potential impact of attention deficit disorder, commonly called ADD. ADD is a developmental disorder which affects at least five per cent of children and at least two to three per cent of adults. Sufferers are often described as not relating to the world around them. They are wrongly labelled as disruptive, uncooperative or even emotionally disturbed. ADD is a medical problem often undiagnosed or misdiagnosed. Sufferers are unable to gain access to treatment and management programs. I commend this week to all in the House and trust that it is the focus of this important social issue.

—Recently I attended a meeting of Westernport Speaking Out, a self-advocacy group of people with intellectual disability. They raised the case of a 12-year-old girl living in a nursing home in Victoria. This is the sort of thing that is happening down in Victoria now. The government of that state is putting people with mental disabilities into nursing homes and spreading the cost, and it is coming back to the Commonwealth. It is not right for those people to be put in those sorts of facilities.

PARA.TAB: It is estimated that over 700 people with intellectual disabilities are now in nursing homes in Victoria, and that number is increasing at a dramatic rate. This is Jeff Kennett's way of looking after the health system in our state. I call on the federal government to get a study going to look at this matter very closely. I will at the first opportunity be making the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) aware of exactly what is happening down there. Hundreds of people are being pushed out of the system in Victoria into the Commonwealth system so that we have to pick up the tab. Even less appropriately the state government is not looking after the interests of these people. They should not be in those sorts of places. I will be doing what I can to make certain this report is well-known within the Commonwealth government and that some action is taken on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the hypocrisy of some politicians in Victoria knows no bounds. On the weekend the ALP right wing machine was wheeled out into Brunswick to do a bit of crowing about its opposition to tollways, in particular the Kennett government's proposed toll on the Tullamarine freeway. The fact that the federal government introduced a tax amendment bill into the parliament last year—or was it the year before?—to enable the use of tax concessional infrastructure bonds for the building of tollways did not get a run when these tired old faces went through their Kennett ritual on the weekend.

PARA.TAB: The idea that Labor is, per se, opposed to tollways is the biggest con job and the biggest joke going around at the moment. If the federal government's tollway legislation is not enough, then what about Premier Carr, who deliberately deceived the people of New South Wales when he said that he would remove tolls on freeways? After what we have seen in New South Wales only a dill would trust the Victorian state ALP to remove tolls should it ever be elected again.

What the ALP, state and federal, should be doing is declaring its commitment to public transport. For the people of the north of Melbourne that means the upgrading of the Upfield railway line and the provision of a rapid rail link to the Tullamarine airport. Regrettably, the state ALP and those hypocrites who would have us believe that tolls are the only issue are just as committed to freeways as that other mob down in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Referring back to my last 90-second statement, let me inform the House that over the last three years the Kennett state government has slashed approximately $47 million from the intellectual disability services budget—that is, about 17 per cent. Let us look at some of the other areas of tax that the Victorian government is right into. Down in Victoria we are paying an extra $2 billion a year in Kennett government taxes.

PARA.TAB: Payroll tax has increased to $1.972 billion; the stamp and financial duties tax has increased to $1.244 billion; the bank account debits tax has increased from $115 million to $257 million; the public authority levy has increased from $258 million to $309 million; gambling taxes have gone up from $513 million to $961 million; insurance taxes have gone up from $148 million to $322 million; and vehicle taxes have gone up from $507 million to $834 million. All of these have gone up in the last three years.

This is why we have such a problem in Victoria. Because of these increased taxes on people's spending power, shops are closing down and businesses in some areas are being squeezed. And that is happening through Kennett and his cohorts down there—they are just putting more and more on to people. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss briefly the matter relating to Coles Myer, and in particular, of course, the recent fiasco involving Yannon Pty Ltd, and to make the following observations. The first is that if you went into Coles or K-Mart and pinched a Mars bar and were caught, you would be charged with stealing. You would be charged by the police and prosecuted in court and would suffer the ignominy of having removed a Mars bar without paying for it. Yet here we have a situation where there has been an $18 million loss by Coles Myer, an $18 million benefit by Yannon and we have the executive chairman of Coles Myer saying that he did not know that his family company was a beneficiary to the tune of $18 million.

PARA.TAB: Many thousands of Australians either directly or indirectly through their funds or managed investment funds are investors in Coles Myer. It is my view that, at the very least, Mr Lew ought to resign as the executive chairman of Coles Myer. To satisfy the disquiet, the disharmony, of those institutional investors who are extremely concerned at this, he ought to consider repaying the $18 million benefit that his company accrued as a result of this fiasco.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to announce to the House that, during the last two-week break of parliament, in Cowan we established the Frog Watch campaign. This campaign is an initiative of the WA museum and sponsored by me to search and look for species of frogs within my electorate.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, you might recall that in the last couple of weeks of parliament in August, I spoke about the use of Monsanto's product, Roundup 360. Since that time, the Monsanto company has contacted me, wanting to meet with me. It was very nice of them to do that. But I also want to congratulate the NRA for taking on this particular issue, namely, the killing of the frogs of Australia—frogs of Australia, not the South Pacific. Hopefully, the National Registration Authority will increase their labelling process on those herbicides that are very harmful to the environment. I congratulate the NRA on that initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to rise and say that the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) has been croaking quite a bit lately about various subjects. Talking about frogs, I will get on to the French. I was very pleased with the reaction in my electorate to what the French are doing at Mururoa. I had thousands of people actually sign a petition. It crossed all political parties, which pleased me no end. As someone who has been campaigning against nuclear weapons since the mid-1960s, it is always good to get cross-party support.

PARA.TAB: However, I presented the petition to the French embassy. The ambassador would not see me. I got to the gate and, after a bit of talking with the inspector there, he allowed me to present the petition at the door of the French embassy. I never really got to see the new ambassador to put my point of view across to him, but at least I tried. I was particularly pleased with how the students in the electorate of Dunkley actually started up their own petition and took it around and got many names on it.

These students at the Frankston high school made a petition. They also wrote a letter, which I delivered to the French embassy, that was addressed to the President of France. I hope that he reads it and knows how people feel about this very important issue, which has not ended yet. I think we should keep the pressure on France. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent pronouncements by the opposition about industrial relations form yet another attempt to perpetrate a massive deception on the Australian workplace. I remind the House of the old biblical adage `by their fruits you shall know them'. In this House, we all know who supports the erosion of the wages and award conditions of Australian workers to enhance our competitiveness as a nation: J.W. Howard, the Leader of the Opposition. We all know who opposed, for 10 years, any national wage increases for Australian workers: J.W. Howard, the Leader of the Opposition. We all know in this House who supports the draconian legislation introduced by state Liberal governments in Victoria and Western Australia: J.W. Howard, the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Now guess who holds the record as the worst Liberal treasurer in the postwar era. Guess who continually lauds the economic achievements of New Zealand and continually downgrades the economic achievements of his own country: J.W. Howard, the Leader of the Opposition. Guess who cannot even stomach the thought of an Australian being an Australian head of state: J.W. Howard, the Leader of the Opposition. No wonder the Leader of the Opposition was rejected on several occasions by honourable members opposite when he stood for the leadership. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that the member for Lilley (Mr Swan) is in the chamber. I am pleased to see his name on the cartoon on the front of today's Courier-Mail. The suggestion by the paramount chief with his head gear on in the cartoon, who is the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), is that the honourable member is one of two people who ought to sacrifice themselves.
—You're the sacrifice in Western Australia, so they've got your head.

—The `member for Blanks' often makes interjections in this chamber. All we know him by is his interjections. However, I would like to know from the member for Lilley just exactly how much substance there is to the fact that he is one of the ringleaders to this coup that is being put together to get rid of the Prime Minister because of his gross unpopularity in the electorate.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I can tell you, Mr Speaker, that in Western Australia, as the member for Canning (Mr Gear), who is at the table, would know—he must be trembling in his boots—the Prime Minister is absolutely unpopular. In fact, I conducted a survey in my electorate. Subtracting the negative standing from the positive standing, the Prime Minister came in at about minus 62 per cent. In other words, he is so unpopular that he could single-handedly lose you the next federal election. I must tell you that in my electorate, where I am running as an Independent, I am more than happy to see the Labor Party travel along the bottom of the ocean, because that is of considerable assistance to me personally. I am happy to say that the member for Lilley has the opportunity to explain to the chamber just exactly how much substance there is to this coup. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I had better rise and have another go at Jeffrey `Glib' Kennett. Those opposite are a bit sick of it. It is about time they heard that he is over in Greece swanning around. He is spending millions of dollars over there having a great time. We in Victoria are going broke while he is over there. Have a look at what is happening there. Millions in gambling taxes are going to look after all his mates.

PARA.TAB: As I have said before, an article I have says that gambling taxes have gone up from $82 million to $440 million. That is a huge increase. Where is all that going? It is all going to help Jeffrey have these trips overseas.

He has been overseas more than anyone in the Labor Party. The total amount of time that Cain and Kirner were overseas never added up to the time Jeffrey has accumulated. He has spent millions. He spent $9 million on his own office. He has a better office than the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) here. You ought to go down there. You might try to get into his office.

The Liberals in Victoria have spent millions, but they have done nothing for the people. All they have done is close down hospitals. Look at the Rosebud hospital, which is in the Flinders electorate. We have not heard anything from the member for Flinders (Mr Reith). The emergency ward has been closed down there. Why has it been closed? Because of state government policies. They have closed it down.

The people of Rosebud have to travel another half an hour to a hospital in Frankston, which I must admit is a great hospital. But they do not have an emergency ward at Rosebud. Over the Christmas period, when thousands of people holiday at Rosebud, what will happen if there is an emergency? They will have to go to Frankston. That half hour could mean the difference between life and death. This is the sort of thing that is happening in Victoria, and we have not heard a peep from the opposition. Country schools and hospitals are all being closed down, and what do we hear from those opposite? Nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, Gordon Bilney, will also be absent from question time. He is overseas on government business. Michael Lavarch will be answering questions on his behalf. The Minister for Communications and the Arts and Minister for Tourism, Michael Lee, will be absent from question time tomorrow. He will be overseas on government business. The Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, will be absent from question time this week. He is travelling overseas, also on government business. Michael Lee will answer questions on his behalf relating to the transport portfolio and Gary Johns will be answering questions on his behalf in relation to industrial relations.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the precise nature of his discussions with President Suharto regarding the appointment of a new Indonesian ambassador to Australia? When is it anticipated that a new ambassador will be named? Specifically, can the Prime Minister assure the House that on this occasion the process will be handled competently by the foreign minister?

—It is probably worth taking the opportunity to say that I had a very good meeting with President Suharto. I am pleased, as is he, that there is a belief that there is a lot more depth in the relationship these days than there has perhaps ever been. This is, in my view, the most important relationship Australia has. Indonesia has always been central to Australia's future in terms of its relations with the region. It also has strategic implications.

PARA.TAB: I said in this House before that perhaps the most positive factor in certain strategic circumstances that Australia has had over the last quarter of a century has come from the election of President Suharto's new order government. His governance of the archipelago has brought strategic certainty to the region. One only has to go to Indonesia to see the success in the growth of that economy and the distribution of wealth. Ordinary people are getting a substantial share of the national wealth. It is evident when one goes down virtually any of the areas that one is able to go on these visits.

As a consequence, I have always regarded the Indonesian relationship as being critical for Australia. Therefore, I was pleased to see the President again to discuss the bilateral relationship and also to discuss APEC, which—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can see why they want to change him.
—Order! The member for Sturt!

—President Suharto has a tremendous stake in APEC because of his stewardship of the Bogor meeting and the declaration. There is no free trade process anywhere around the world on offer outside of APEC. His work at Bogor last year is very important for us, for Indonesia and for the region. We discussed that and the prospects of putting into place an action plan at the next APEC meeting at Osaka in November this year.

PARA.TAB: But I spent most of the time in the meeting on the bilateral relationship, which the President believes is in good shape; so do I. He is pleased about it; so am I. We did discuss the ambassadorship. He raised it. He says it is important that whoever is ambassador serve to do the principal task that an ambassador does, that is, not simply to represent their country's interests—in this case Indonesia's interests—but to do it in such a way as to advance the relationship in the broad. That is a completely agreeable sentiment. I said to him that I thought that was right. He said that he would now think about the options that they had and that he would, in due course, make a decision about a person of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before January?
—Grow up, Tim, for God's sake.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition asked the question. The Prime Minister is answering it.

—I have no doubt that that will happen. As far as the representation that Indonesia has here, the charge d'affaires is competently managing the operations of the embassy. The relationship is being, in a sense, directed at head of government level by President Suharto and me and, of course, the foreign ministers meet regularly.

PARA.TAB: The whole point about the opposition trying to make out this case for how an ambassador—and only an ambassador—is central to a relationship and how, if there is not an ambassador, the whole thing falls to pieces is just trite nonsense. Perhaps I could demonstrate the point by saying that, as far as I know, the United States embassy in Jakarta has not had an ambassador for something like five months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. What steps are being taken to provide appropriate venues for the safe transfer of children between separated parents? Where are these services likely to be? How can the government ensure the safety of children when parents are in conflict?

—I suppose of all the difficulties that a couple face as a result of the breakdown of a marriage, separation and divorce the issue of the best arrangements for the care of children is of greatest importance. While, obviously, the partners may no longer be married upon a relationship breaking down or a marriage failing, they are still parents. Our law recognises the ongoing role that both parents have to provide for not only the financial maintenance of children but also the children's ongoing development.

PARA.TAB: The greatest problem arises—which members will be well aware of—in circumstances where there is great conflict between the parties regarding children or where there has been a history of violence within families. Often circumstances where there is violence between one party to the other may lead to the violent party not being able to gain access to the children of the marriage, notwithstanding that there is no violence directed towards the children. In many circumstances, that is an appropriate outcome given that it is in the best interests of the child that there be no contact with the violent party. But there are other circumstances where, if appropriate facilities were available, there could be a handover point for access visits or where supervised access by the non-custodial parent to the children could take place. That is very much to be encouraged.

In the government's Justice Statement, announced earlier this year by the Prime Minister, some $5.3 million was allocated over the next four years for the piloting of access handover centres in each of the Australian states. The purpose of these centres will be to allow access to occur in circumstances where there does need to be supervision or a settled place either for the welfare of the children or where a handover can occur due to the safety considerations for one of the parents.

To date, we have already advertised submissions of interest for the establishment of these centres. There has been very strong support throughout the country, and my department is now in the process of assessing the applications. Very strong consultation has been taking place with the Family Court and with other interested groups, such as the Australian and New Zealand Access Association. The aim of this consultation is to make sure that the people running these centres and their staff are appropriately trained and that staff will make sure that the children's welfare is closely considered.

The end result should see progressively during the first half of next year the services established in each state. If they are successful, as I am sure the House would hope they are, they may well provide us with a model to extend these services throughout the community. I think this will go a long way to enabling another difficult element of separation to be handled in a sensitive way to make sure that we have high regard for the best interests of our children and at the same time recognise the ongoing responsibility of parents to have contact and involvement in the development of their children, notwithstanding that a marriage may have broken down.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister would be aware of the report of the World Bank showing that on the basis of natural resources Australia is the richest country in the world. He would also be aware of last week's report from Standard and Poors which says that, out of the 51 countries it ranks on current account to GDP, Australia was 49th and on external debt to exports out of the 51 countries it ranks, Australia was 47th. These reports highlight the gulf between our nation's potential and the reality of your failed record. Can you please explain how it is that, despite Australia's riches, so many Australians are still doing it so hard under your administration?

—If the honourable gentleman refers to the World Bank's valuation of Australia's natural capital assets and uses them in a question, why then does he continue to support the lie being peddled by the Liberal Party that each Australian owes $10,000? Why would he be such a hypocrite as to ask me this question when he has brochures going out into letterboxes with a complete lie saying that the Australian people owe $10,000 per person? They owe no such thing. The debt is owed by the companies and the people who borrow it.

PARA.TAB: When the Bond Corporation lost $4 billion or $5 billion—I cannot remember the number—there was not a bill in everybody's letterbox. The cost was borne by the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank and the other banking consortiums who lent the money. To be out there talking about our wealth and at the same time putting brochures like dirty postcards into letterboxes—these nasty little stories—like peddlers of dirty postcards, this complete lie about Australians owing $10,000 per person, are the stock-in-trade of the Liberal Party. Nothing has ever changed.

In the 1960s it was the reds coming together from their sampans. I remember running along a long street in Chullora in Sydney in the 1960s with a bag over my shoulders and putting the Labor leaflet into letterboxes and tearing the Liberal one out with the sampans and the red arrows authorised by that great person of truth in Australian politics, J.L. Carrick—Mr Howard's mentor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Great man.
—Yes, I know—great man. Then there were reds under beds. Then there was Malcolm Fraser's—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will wait for just a moment. I remind all members of the provisions of standing order 55. The question has been asked. The Prime Minister is responding to that question. He will be heard.

—In the 1983 election Malcolm Fraser said, `Labor will take your money. You need to keep your money under your bed because they will confiscate it from the banks.' That is just another version of those things. The questioner put the question in terms of the national debt. In your question you are also supporting the Reserve Bank's valuation—
—I am supporting Standard and Poors; why don't you comment on that.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—It puts the World Bank valuation of Australia's natural capital resources at $10,000 billion. The debt is what? It is $180 billion. That is $180 billion versus $10,000 billion. Is that the point you are trying to make to me? It is $180 billion of debt versus $10,000 billion of assets.
—Call a garage sale.
—Order!

—I wanted to make sure I got the magnitudes right. On the basis of the question, he is saying that we are worth $10,000 billion but we have a debt of $180 billion. Then you fall back to some Standard and Poors issue of debt servicing ratios, et cetera. The key point about the debt is that 22 per cent of our exports serviced it 10 years ago. As of last month, it is 11 per cent. Why is that there? Because of the growth of Australian exports over the period. Why are they there? Because of Australia's new found competitiveness. And why is it there? Because of this government.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Has the minister seen a report in the Weekend Australian concerning the direction of the government's social policies? What is the government's response to that report?

—I did see a number of articles in the Weekend Australian arguing that government social policies were contributing to the breakdown of families. The main article in that set of articles, which was reprinted from the British magazine the Economist, was talking about concerns predominantly in the US and UK with declines in families.

PARA.TAB: I have just returned from the United States and there is quite a debate going on over there about what they term welfare reform. When they use the term welfare they are primarily talking about the AFDC—aid for families with dependent children—which is broadly equivalent to our sole parent pension. The argument was that the existence of this payment was contributing to the perpetuation of a state of welfare dependency and intergenerational transmission of that welfare dependency.

Whatever one may say about developments in the US, to suggest that those trends are in any sense indicative of what is happening here or what the impact of social policy is here is completely wrong and demonstrably inaccurate. To take a few basic statistics, part of the conventional wisdom about this issue is that sole parent pensions are inducing young women and teenagers to go out and have babies.

What are the facts of the matter? In Australia around one per cent of sole parent pensioners are under the age of 18 and teenagers make up around three per cent of the sole parent pensioner population. In the United States, the equivalent figure relating to AFDC is around eight per cent. In the United States, between 1979 and 1991 that proportion rose from four per cent to eight per cent—that is, the proportion of AFDC recipients who are teenagers.

In this country the trend is the direct opposite. In 1976, teenagers made up 11 per cent of the equivalent of sole parent pensioners. They now constitute three per cent. In other words, not only is the situation quite different but the trends are fundamentally different.

Those social commentators who try to argue that we are heading down some route to disaster with the breakup of families and the perpetuation of welfare dependency are dead wrong. The median duration on the sole parent pension in this country is two years, which is very different from the situation in the United States. We have had demonstrably successful programs, through the jobs, education and training program, to get sole parent pensioners earning an income. The proportion earning an income has increased significantly and continuously over the last few years—again, a contrast with the situation in some of these other countries.

This whole horror scenario that has been concocted about the way in which the existence of social security payments is leading to family breakdown and the proliferation of teenage pregnancy and so on is wrong. I could give a few other statistics that relate to the rates of family breakdown and divorce. In the United States, where benefits equivalent to ours are significantly less generous, the divorce rate is 90 per cent higher. In this country, after the passage of the Family Law Act, there was an increase in divorce rates from 1975 to 1983, but from 1983 to 1993 the rate has declined significantly: not only has it declined significantly, but the proportion of divorces involving children has declined from 63 per cent to 53 per cent. In the United Kingdom over the comparable period the divorce rate increased by 16 per cent.

I could go on. It is both fake and wrong and absolutely absurd to suggest that having an adequate social safety net to protect people who need assistance from government in order to be able to look after their children in some appropriate state is the cause of family breakdown.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is it a fact, Minister, that you told this parliament in respect of the Easton affair that you stood by your claims made at the National Press Club? Is it a fact that you told the National Press Club that you did not know about the Family Court connection with the petition until the petition was tabled? Is it not a fact that you have since conceded that a connection was canvassed prior to the tabling of the petition? Why have you changed your story?

—Devastating stuff! I conceded, by way of an acknowledgment that Mr Halden said it had been raised, that it may have been raised. As I said last time when this matter was raised in the House, I know that members opposite will want to run a parallel inquiry. I do not believe that they will succeed in doing that; not least because they do not have the skills.
—Not under the sub judice rule that we have in here.
—The commissioner himself has already indicated—

—Order! The minister will just wait for a moment. The honourable member for Flinders had the opportunity earlier this afternoon, when a statement was made in respect of that particular matter, to comment at length. He was given that opportunity. I would hope that any other interjections about that are kept to himself.

—I am simply indicating that I do not believe that the members opposite have the skills. The commissioner himself has already indicated that this is a politicallytainted inquiry. All that happens when members opposite open their mouths is that they confirm that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, much has been made in recent days about my lack of memory, but I took the trouble to take out some statistics. A political commentator of some considerable standing, at least in terms of the amount of time he has had in the public arena, Mr Paul McGeough, complains in one article—and I think this is what members opposite are running off—that I said 19 times, `I don't recall.' In fact, he got that wrong. When you search for synonyms, I used that expression 14 times.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —You wait for it. I said—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister has the call.

—You will laugh in a minute. In addition to that, I said `don't remember' six times and `can't remember' four times in the course of giving evidence all that day. That hearing on that day ran for some 35,385 words. The ratio of my saying `can't recall' and `don't recall'—
—We have to laugh.
—Order!
—Members opposite may not like this.
—Order! No. The minister will wait a moment. The member for Flinders has asked the question. The minister will be heard in silence.
—Given my time there and the number of questions asked, that is a ratio of once every 1,273 words. Mr McGeough, as it happens—

PARA.TAB: Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Flinders is not helping me or anyone.

—It may be a matter of some amusement, but I think you should listen to this. Mr McGeough—it amuses me too—who himself gave evidence to the commission, and then proceeded to cover it, I might say, was there for only 5,700 words—his was a very brief encounter—during which he said `don't recall' or `can't recall' or an equivalent an average of once every 814 words.
—You can remember all of this?
—Order! The member for O'Connor!

—Mr Speaker, Mr McGeough's memory failure rate was more than 50 per cent higher than mine. Indeed, his memory failure rate was 17 per cent higher than that of the commission as a whole. At the end of last Thursday, if members are interested, the number of words that had been spoken by witnesses at the commission amounted to 813,817 words, and a memory failure on the part of somebody, including members of the media, occurred once every 951 words. If members are listening, that is 34 per cent more often than during my evidence, Mr Speaker. So in comparison with the commission average—with Mr McGeough, as it turns out, who is one of the worst performers and, indeed, with Mr Wilson—my average of not remembering after three years is considerably less than that of other players. Might I say—
—Howard has a bad memory.

—Yes; when it comes to the crunch, the Leader of the Opposition has a very poor record here. He cannot remember precisely when he heard about the Hindmarsh Island affair and the stunt that was pulled in here. Was it 2 1/2 weeks, was it three weeks, was it 10 days—can't remember. He can't remember that he signed a petition in this place, interestingly, after three years. The memory of the Leader of the Opposition is a bit faulty too.
—Too, too, too.

—I will tell you what, Mr Speaker, everybody's is. As I say, the same ratio was one `can't recall' to every 900 words, roughly, in the commission; every time the Leader of the Opposition opens his mouth he falls in it.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I think the important point, though, for the Australian people is not these statistics but the fact that from 1972 onwards at various moments the Leader of the Opposition has voted, in my area, against Medicare. He has said time and time and time again that he is against Medicare. He was against its establishment; he watered it down when in government; he was against its re-establishment. In the Fightback program they were against Medicare. What the Leader of the Opposition hopes, and he is wrong, is that the Australian public has collective amnesia about your attitude to Medicare. They do not, Mr Speaker. Even the medical profession, the head of the AMA in South Australia, when asked about opposition policy—`What is the position with the Liberal Party on this; where do they stand'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this relevant?
—I warn the member for Cowan!

—`Where does the Liberal Party stand on Medicare?' What does the President of the AMA in South Australia say? He says, `Silent, I think, is probably the proper word. They are not going to say anything because they are going to change Medicare. He goes on to say, `Even if they are not going to change it, no-one would believe them.' The Australian people don't have collective amnesia on this point. They know you are opposed to Medicare, they know you will unravel it, and they will hold you responsible when it comes to the election. So don't worry about who can't recall; the Australian people know you and they have got you pinned.
—To assist the minister's recollection, could she table the documents from which she was quoting, lest she forgets?
—Was the minister quoting from confidential documents?
—Yes, they are.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. It refers to the article in today's Medical Journal of Australia concerning midwifery care. What is the government's response to that article?

—Mr Speaker, I know there has been some publicity given lately to the fact that there are shortages of obstetricians around the country, particularly in the country areas. I was very interested in this study which confirms a lot of international research. It shows very clearly that a team of midwives conducting deliveries actually has a somewhat superior outcome to the case where you have doctors and midwives together, and it compared both high-risk and low-risk women. Mothers and babies indeed had fewer adverse outcomes under the care of midwives, babies were less likely to be induced, and mothers were less likely to be administered the pain-killing drug pethidine.

PARA.TAB: In addition, from the government's point of view it is a lower cost option but, more importantly, it is more satisfying for the parents. So you do not get a poorer outcome. Indeed, you get a better one with fewer applications. Because of that, some time ago we established the alternative birthing services program to provide incentives to the states to enable women to have precisely that choice. A lot of women do want midwives. They want home deliveries, they want alternative birthing services, and they have spoken very clearly to us to that effect.

A number of birthing centres have been established around the country with Commonwealth funding, recognising that birthing is a normal event which does not necessarily require a lot of medical intervention. Indeed, the best in the profession will tell you precisely that. Unfortunately, some states have not cooperated. My own state, in particular, has failed to recommend projects which we could fund under the program. The result is that women in Western Australia do not have as much choice in having a midwife sponsored birth. Indeed, women in Western Australia do not have the same choices across a range of areas.

I have to say that in both Western Australia and the ACT it is quite probable that the reasons the state and territory governments have not come forward with programs is that of opposition within the medical profession. That is very disappointing when, at the same time, they are asking for greater funds from taxpayers and for more of their number to be trained. Of course, not all women want midwifery care; they want doctors. But others have the opportunity to have midwifery care in every state but Western Australia and the ACT. I would certainly urge those governments to undertake those programs right now to give Australian women the choice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health
