—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: is the questioner directing a question to the person he accused of being the cause of the death of Penny Easton? This malicious wrecker of reputations—
—No, no. Prime Minister, that is not a point of order.
—This is not a point of order.
—Name him; name him.
—You should name him.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: that is a clear and spurious point of order raised by the Prime Minister. You have given people on this side warnings that spurious points of order would be dealt with severely. Quite frankly, if you expect us to abide by the standing orders, you ought to mete out the same treatment to the government as you have warned the opposition about.
—As I have said to members on all sides of this place on occasions, there is no point of order, and that is what I said to the Prime Minister.
—Is it a fact that in the 1984 Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry you wrote a four-page editorial entitled `Testing for Memory Disorders'? Does the minister recall writing:

QUESTION.PARA: It is one thing to note that a patient cannot answer a question, but quite another to determine whether the answers given are true or false.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was not a difficult question to anticipate. I thought the opposition had given up since they have not really gone as feral as they have on previous occasions. I gave you the answer a little while ago. At least I have an academic record that includes some publications in prestigious journals. I am pleased to have been able to provide an editorial of that kind. As I pointed out, members opposite need to be pretty careful about the question of memory. The Leader of the Opposition has a very faulty memory indeed about petitions—about whether he was briefed, when he was briefed and such matters.
—Ha, ha, ha!

—The Premier of Western Australia in discussing the question of whether there had been some connivance between him and the Leader of the Opposition in establishing the royal commission could not remember—
—He denied it.
—No, he said he could not remember.
—He denied it.

—He precisely said he could not remember. I can read the transcript if you wish. He basically said he could not remember whether he had or he had not. He presumed that he may have. That is the sort of problem that members opposite have. They have been trying to duck the issue, but we know that the Leader of the Opposition and the Premier of Western Australia got together, discussed the royal commission and the terms of reference and decided that it was a politically smart thing to do.

PARA.TAB: When the commissioner himself came out and said that this inquiry was tainted by politics and that it should be drawn to a swift conclusion, there was silence. Members opposite suddenly went very quiet. They did not want to talk about it for one day, two days, three days, four days. I think they started to get withdrawal symptoms, so one or two of them popped up again. I think members opposite need to be very careful about the question of memory and who is faulty.

As I have indicated, my ratio is far better than most of the other participants in the commission. After 3 1/2 years, I am not doing too badly. The member opposite could not remember whether he had discussed the question of the Hindmarsh Island affair with the member responsible—whether it was 10 days or 2 1/2 weeks ago—just a matter of months ago.

As I said before, the people of Australia have long memories. They know that John Howard is a recycled failure who has been kidding them about Medicare, trying to roll up into the smallest possible ball hoping that he will disappear. It is not, `Bye bye, Carmen.' You will never make it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I seek leave to table an editorial from the Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry, volume 18, page 207, 1984.
—Is leave granted?
—It is an excellent publication.
—I seek leave to table it if it is excellent.
—Leave is granted. To table it, you will hand it to the clerk.
—Mr Speaker!
—The Prime Minister, to add to the answer.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr KEATING

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of memory loss, I would like to refer to a judgment issued by a judge of the Supreme Court of South Australia about the Liberal Premier of South Australia. He said:

INTERJECT.PARA: There were significant divergences in factual detail which arose as between the applicant—
that was the former chief of the Health Commission, Mr David Blakey—
and the Premier. In the event, I unhesitatingly prefer the evidence given by the former than that given by the latter. I simply conclude that he—
the Premier—
is mistaken as to some aspects which occurred at the time. Indeed, Mr Moss, counsel for the respondent, the Premier, very properly conceded that that must be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the Minister for Human Services and Health was asked a question about whether she regarded the words `true or false' as the same as `I cannot recall'. I fail to see how this judgment has any bearing on the answer to the question.
—There is no point of order. The question that was asked was very broad indeed, and the minister responded. The Prime Minister, as the Prime Minister, is able to supplement the answer.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr KEATING

TALK.START.PARA: —The judge also said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I am also of the impression that some aspects of his evidence—
that is the Premier's—

may have been influenced by a degree of ex post facto reasoning. This is particularly so as there were important matters of detail testified to by him in the course of his oral evidence which found no expression at all in his affidavit sworn on 18 May 1995. The Premier's memory of what transpired and what was said to have taken place simply cannot be reconciled with the evidence of either Mr Shilling or Mr Foreman, the Commissioner of Public Employment.
What do you think about that loss of memory or that damning judgment? This is the punch line. The judge said:
I expressly find that the evidence given by the applicant—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: under standing order 145, is the Prime Minister going to take the Western Australian royal commissioner as seriously as he is taking this?
—There is no point of order. I have already ruled that the Prime Minister is in order.
—It is completely irrelevant to the question asked.
—Resume your seat. The Prime Minister is responding.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr KEATING

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a judge of a court talking about a premier, after taking evidence in court. He said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I expressly find that the evidence given by the applicant—
that is the person whom he dismissed and forced out of his job—
as to what transpired at the meeting is that which must be accepted.

In other words, the Premier cannot be believed. It is well and good for the Liberal Party to get up asking these sorts of snide questions, but what has happened here is that the Leader of the Opposition has connived in a royal commission which has blown up in his face. Commissioner Marks said:

The sooner this commission comes to an end the better. I think that the experience here has demonstrated the usefulness of royal commissions is fast receding. The terms of reference have turned out to be fairly restrictive.

When he said all these things, the Leader of the Opposition, when asked by journalists on the day of his publishing the remarks, said that he would not give a comment, after asking the majority of the questions in the parliament for the previous two weeks on the same subject. Little Mr Clever Dick over here, in league with the Premier of Western Australia, thought he had a nice little political scam running, and it blew right up on him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, a point of order—

—Now, as a rearguard action, he is back to giggling while the reputation killer opposite comes in here trying to ask questions about psychiatrists. The same person that bursts in here and accuses the minister—
—The Prime Minister will resume his seat.

—I think it would help the House if the Prime Minister was asked to withdraw that language. If children in my electorate were using that language they would have their mouths washed out with soap. The Prime Minister should not be allowed to use that language in this House.
—Order! There is no point of order. Resume your seat. The Prime Minister, I think, is concluding his answer.

—Mr Speaker, what you have seen in this House over the last couple of sitting weeks has been the most tawdry exercise in character assassination, using the executive arm of a state government for the purposes of the Liberal Party, costing somewhere between $3 million and $6 million, and arraigned against a single person in a most spiteful and vindictive way. It has blown up on the Leader of the Opposition. Having had this ploy, this great investment he has made of two weeks of parliament—resting all on this case—fall to pieces before his eyes, he has this shabby figure opposite ask questions about psychiatrists.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice. Can the minister inform the House of the measures the government is taking to improve the national legal aid system?

—I thank the honourable member. The first thing I would say that is important in this regard is that we have recognised that legal aid has not been adequately funded. The Justice Statement announced by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and me in Brisbane some months ago did significantly increase the amount of money provided to legal aid, particularly in key areas which have not been adequately addressed, that is, in civil and family law matters.

PARA.TAB: To say that we can address these issues simply on the basis of putting additional funding into legal aid, recognising the ancillary provision of legal aid through community legal centres—this has been addressed in funding terms; in fact, we have doubled the amount of money going into community legal centres around Australia as a result of the Justice Statement strategy—is not going to be an adequate answer. That is because we have to look at prevention programs. The Attorney has talked about a number of programs that are designed to build a focus around prevention and trying to avoid litigation—to keep that as a matter of last resort—and also at ways in which we can get the system to operate more efficiently.

In that regard, legal aid needs attention. The Sackville report, which was the initiative or springboard for the Justice Statement, did provide us with a clear indication that the Commonwealth needs to take greater national leadership, not so much to operate without regard for the interests of the states or legal aid commissions, but to work with them in partnership, with close attention to getting best practice and more effective outcomes from the delivery of legal aid.

A big step was taken towards that outcome last week when I announced the appointment of John King, who is a former secretary of the Attorney-General's Department in Victoria and currently is the head of the Victorian Port of Melbourne Authority. He has strong business credentials, very good and effective business management skills and will become the head of the Australian Legal Assistance Board, which will be my principal adviser in this area. I am hopeful that John King will be working closely with the commissions, principally with the four largest commissions, so we can go about targeting the scarce resources available to legal aid, to get the biggest bang possible for the buck.

I am sure it is a matter of great interest to both sides of this House that there are real needs for us to take a national approach to legal aid. There are a number of decisions, not least the Dietrich decision by the High Court and, more recently, the Milat judgment in New South Wales, which have implications with funding consequences for legal aid commissions.

At the next meeting of the Standing Committees of Attorneys-General in Adelaide, the Attorney-General and I will be taking a paper forward for further discussion on how the states and the Commonwealth might respond to the implications of the Dietrich decision. It will also build in some reflection on the Milat judgment which, whilst under appeal, if confirmed would have a further implication in terms of the consequence. The implications of the Milat decision would be that courts might look behind the rates of scale payments that legal aid commissions have provided and order higher provision of legal assistance to counsel than commissions have budgeted for.

That, of course, would have cost flow-ons to states and the Commonwealth in an area where there is, I think, little likelihood that there is a capacity to provide additional funding. That would put greater pressure on those legal aid dollars.

So we are looking at those issues. I have indicated publicly that the Commonwealth is concerned about the Milat judgment. We have indicated to New South Wales that if it wants our assistance in the appeal we would be happy to intervene but to date New South Wales has said that no, it does not regard that as necessary; the arguments are proceeding well and it thinks it can carry them without our intervention. But if the matter does ultimately come before the High Court we will be ready to intervene in that matter, for obvious reasons.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. However, now you are saying that Mr Berinson and Ms Hallahan were the only two ministers you checked with. Which recollection is correct—your recollection of 17 April where you said that other ministers in addition to Mr Berinson and Ms Hallahan had privately confirmed your recollection of events, or your recollection of last week, where you said that you had only checked with Mr Berinson and Ms Hallahan? Why have you changed your story?
—I suggest that members opposite read the transcript before they come in here and ask stupid questions such as that.
—It is in the transcript.

—If you read the question that was put to me you will see that your inference is clearly wrong. The fact is that you have got this all twisted about for political purposes. Go and have a look and you will find that you have. I noted some time ago that the Leader of the Opposition in particular, who is not asking questions on this today, which is interesting, said that it was important that I had my day in court, as he put it, misunderstanding that a royal commission is not a court and that he was not going to make any judgments until there were commission findings. The commissioner himself has already suggested his findings are going to be suspect. Don't make it harder for him.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. It concerns government funding for financial counselling services. Can the minister advise the House how the funding is being allocated?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. The government has allocated $6.4 million over four years to financial counselling services, also as part of the Justice Statement. This money will be for new services and to increase resources amongst the 30 services that the Commonwealth already funds. A great demand for increased staff for financial services exists across the country because of the great complexity and variety of choice of financial products. A lot of people are finding difficulties. So the bureau and I have liaised with the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association to determine where the greatest need exists for the new services.

PARA.TAB: We have now proposed 17 locations for new services, four in Queensland, four in New South Wales, three in Victoria, two each in South Australia and Western Australia, and one each for Tasmania and the Northern Territory. We will be placing advertisements—most have already gone in—calling for expressions of interest for agencies to operate services in the variation locations. In Queensland these will be Gympie, Roma, Logan City and Cairns. In New South Wales they will be in Bourke, Dubbo, Liverpool and Sutherland. In Victoria they will be in the Dandenong-Pakenham area, in the Eltham area and in Footscray. Meekatharra and the Perth northern suburbs will get the new services in Western Australia and there will be new services in Katherine in the Northern Territory and Launceston in Tasmania. In South Australia the new services will be in the Elizabeth area and in Coober Pedy—exactly where the need is. Five of these will be designed specifically to meet the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who have very special problems.

I was recently in Alice Springs where our financial counsellor there recently got the Advance Australia award for his efforts. I met many of his clients. The need is great. It is a perfect example of an area where the service needs extra support, as indeed do all the services around Australia. So I commend to honourable members the allocation of those new services.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Is it not a fact that this is the third time you have effectively pleaded the `amnesia defence'? —He did know and he didn't know—`Maybe it was 2 1/2 weeks ago. Maybe it was 10 days ago.' The Leader of the Opposition never acknowledges when he makes a mistake—he never acknowledges it. PARA.TAB: So, Mr Speaker, I think if you are going to be consistent you should look at the times when the Leader of the Opposition has failed to answer questions. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports of evidence presented to the Western Australian royal commission by the clerk of the legislative council? Does this conform with the views expressed by the Prime Minister in this place concerning the requirement on members to lodge petitions on behalf of their constituents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I did see the evidence of the clerk, Mr Marquet, the clerk of the Western Australian upper house, about the responsibilities on a member to present a petition from a constituent petitioner, and it is a view which accords with practice in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, you know that the Western Australian upper house, of course, has been controlled by conservative parties in most of its history—I think, all of its history. There is no way, of course, that Mr Marquet can be described as a Labor supporter, as a person who has partisan or particular views.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Carmen did not know about it.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor!

—And, Mr Speaker, given the fact there was a royal commission about this petition which he was involved in preparing and that has been the subject of debate in this parliament for two weeks, I would have thought that his evidence was central to the whole matter and the consideration of it. And I want to just record a couple of points, Mr Speaker, which I think are terribly significant in this. Mr Easton outlined his concerns and the clerk is asked by counsel, `What happened after that?' He said, `It looks as though a parliamentary petition would be the right way to go,' said the clerk. That's advising Easton. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: As far as I am concerned, it looks as though you have provided sufficient documentation, which suggests to me that you have at least got an arguable case.
I volunteered to assist him in drafting the petition on that day. I probably started on that day.
He goes on to say in answer to another question:
I had asked the petitioner to provide me with documentary evidence and I made my own inquiry.
So there is a real process here. It is a proper process. The question was then asked:
Do you have a view of the propriety of a member of the executive government attempting to prevent a member from tabling a petition?
That would be a contempt of the parliament.
Well, any interference with a right of a person to petition the House, I think, is improper.
On the previous page, he describes it as a contempt. This is, of course, central to the whole matter under the view of the royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it isn't.
—The member for O'Connor, consider your position.

—There are a couple of points worth making. This testimony was given on Tuesday, the 12th. It was not published in the newspapers in the eastern states until today, 18 September, which is six days later. I do not know whether Mr McGeough had filed any copy. Papers like the Sydney Morning Herald have covered this commission up hill and down dale. How could they not report such a central argument? How could Mr McGeough not report a central fact and such a central argument? It is something as central as the clerk of the parliament saying that it would be a contempt of the parliament for the former Premier, the now Minister for Human Services and Health, Carmen Lawrence, to have stopped a member presenting the petition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. What is the government's response to the proposal to exempt mineral exploration leases from the native title process?

—I have received a submission on behalf of the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, AMEC, proposing that exploration leases or licences be excluded from the native title legislation. I believe that the association has also released publicly a discussion paper to that end. The background of this particular matter is on the supposition that native title issues and the native title legislation are hindering in some way mineral exploration in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I note as a starting point that the Australian Bureau of Statistics last week released figures for the 1993-94 financial year regarding mineral exploration in Australia. It indicated that exploration in that financial year had in fact increased over the previous financial year by some 12.7 per cent and reached a total of $893 million. Interestingly, the largest increases were in the states of Western Australia and Queensland.

Nonetheless, I take the point which the Minerals Council raised. The government has always contended, in relation to its response to the Mabo High Court decision, that we were required to balance the interest of a decent outcome for Aboriginal and Islander people with the need to ensure certainty of title and a backdrop where worthwhile economic activity was able to continue. To that end, the legislation itself already includes within its provision the capacity for low impact exploration to be excluded. It also allows the capacity for state governments to incorporate native title principles into their land management system and to establish state bodies to enable the processing of mineral and other interest in lands together with questions of native title.

The Commonwealth has been speaking to all of the Australian states on this issue. We have made good progress with a number of the states in terms of getting both the recognition of state bodies and proposals for the exclusion from native title issues of particular low impact mining activities, particularly exploration. These are matters which will be processed in accordance with the scheme laid out in the native title legislation.

The Commonwealth has had the least amount of progress in the state of Western Australia. That is not surprising, given the very strong line which the Western Australian government up until recent times has taken in response to the Mabo High Court decision. Of course, in the first instance we had the Western Australian government proposing its own legislation which effectively led to the extinguishment of native title in that state. That legislation was thrown out earlier this year by the High Court because it was held to be constitutionally invalid. Since then, the Commonwealth has gone to the Western Australian government and made it clear that the time has long now passed for political rhetoric, posturing and point scoring in relation to native title issues and that it was time for constructive discussions between the Commonwealth, the Western Australian government and economic and Aboriginal and Islander interests in that state so we could come up with a decent outcome.

Recently, I have spent a fair amount of time in various regions of Western Australia. I have spoken to a number of mining interests, a number of different native title claimants and representative groups of Aboriginal people as well as local government and other business interests in the state. I find there is a very strong willingness on behalf of all those parties to come together for a constructive approach towards advancing the position in Western Australia. If there is still reluctance in Western Australia, if there is still resistance in Western Australia, it rests largely on behalf of the Western Australian government.

It is now time for Premier Court to put his mind to constructive things such as dealing in a proper way with native title issues rather than pursuing political vendettas—as he is in the Marks royal commission. It is now time for the Premier and the government of Western Australia to engage the Commonwealth constructively in this issue and, just as importantly—in fact, more importantly—also engage the other stakeholders, particularly Aboriginal people, in debate so we can have a situation where we have proper processes recognised in Western Australia and a backdrop of which the mining industry as well as Aboriginal people can be confident that their interests will be safeguarded.
