SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death, on Wednesday 30 August 1995, of Dame Pattie Maie Menzies, places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Pattie Menzies played a very significant role in Australia's national life over a very long period of time. She will be long remembered for her dignity and her warmth and it is only fitting that we honour her today through this condolence motion.

PARA.TAB: Dame Pattie Menzies was born in Alexandra, north-east of Melbourne, on 2 March 1899. She attended school in Melbourne, first at the Presbyterian Ladies College, East Melbourne, and then later at Fintona. She married Robert Menzies on 27 September 1920, in the year that he appeared before the High Court in the engineers case and at a time when he was making his reputation as a leading barrister.

Dame Pattie was not a person who set her mind on a career in public life—rather, she supported her husband's career. Throughout Sir Robert's life, she was his loyal and supportive partner—and during his tenures as Prime Minister in 1939-1941 and 1949-1966, she was very successful and popular in her own right.

Dame Pattie was awarded the GBE in 1954 in recognition of years of incessant and unselfish performance of public duty, in hospital work, in visiting and addressing and encouraging many thousands of women in every state of Australia, including very remote areas, and in her distinguished representation of Australia on a number of occasions overseas. That was on many occasions overseas, as I said earlier, over a very extended period of time. After Sir Robert's death in 1978 Dame Pattie remained active in Australian public and political life, particularly through her association with the Liberal Party.

Dame Pattie lived a full life of 96 years—an extraordinarily long life—outliving her sons Kenneth and Ian who died in 1993 and 1974, which must have brought considerable sadness to her. For a parent to lose a child in that way and to basically outlive her children would have been a sad reflection, I am sure, for her. She is survived by her daughter Heather and her 10 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren.

She was a fine Australian and a very private person who led a very public life. This, of course, must have put enormous stresses and strains on her life and her personality over the years. Through all this she earned the deep affection of the Australian people. On behalf of the government and the Australian Labor Party, I extend to Dame Pattie's family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I would like to thank the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the government for facilitating this condolence motion. I would like to briefly associate the coalition with what the Prime Minister has said. He has canvassed the broad details of a remarkable life.

PARA.TAB: Naturally, to those on this side of the House, Dame Pattie Menzies was a very special symbolic figure. Dying at the age of 96, having been married to the longest serving Prime Minister in Australia's history, and having been the daughter of somebody who also served in politics, it can be said that her life encompassed, in a very direct way, most of the major events and the major periods that shaped and influenced the Australian nation. She was a remarkable, confident partner, wife and supporter of Sir Robert Menzies. On his retirement the former Prime Minister said that nobody could have had a more loyal, supportive and helpful companion through public life and the private side of it than he had in Dame Pattie. The contribution that she made as his wife to Australia is very well known and very well recognised.

This is an occasion to reflect more upon her life and her role and the impression she made upon the many people she met and the many people whose lives she touched rather than upon the deeds and the contribution of her great husband to the welfare of the people of Australia. As a young person growing up in the Menzies era in Australia in the 1950s, I looked upon Dame Pattie Menzies as a figure of stability, of decency, of reassurance, of companionship, and of continuity.

Robert Menzies and his wife represented to millions of Australians of that period the essence of what was stable, predictable, valuable, worth while and dignified in our national life. Not everybody would have agreed with everything that Dame Pattie Menzies believed in and stood for, and she would have understood and respected that more than, I think, some of her political opponents in the broadest sense might have given her credit for. But she maintained an impeccable courtesy and decency through all her years as the wife of the Prime Minister. She stood by her husband's side during the peaks and the troughs of his very turbulent, long and successful political career.

Dame Pattie was with him when he was cast out by his party in the 1940s, she stayed by his side during the process of building the Liberal Party, and she stood by his side when he returned to office in 1949 and was there through his long years in office. She made for herself a very happy, a very useful and an infectiously humorous life, despite a great deal of personal sadness in the years that followed Sir Robert's death.

I personally only got to know her when she was approaching the age of 90. I have a number of very happy recollections. I can well remember her attending a Liberal Party dinner in Sydney, I think in May 1987. If my memory serves me correctly, relations were not the most tranquil inside the coalition at that particular time, and she was kind enough to hand me a small spanner at that dinner, exhorting me to retain it in my briefcase and to continue to work on the coalition problems. I reflect that perhaps I may have lost it in some papers for a year or two, but I think it is fair to say that I have relocated it, and it now occupies a very prominent place in the briefcase at the present time.

Another very vivid recollection I and many others would have of Dame Pattie Menzies is of a quite remarkable dinner that was attended in her honour in Melbourne in February 1989 to mark her 90th birthday. It brought together an enormous assembly of people on the broad liberal side of politics. The only two speeches, apart from that of the chairman, were of the late Sir Paul Hasluck, who proposed her health on behalf of all the guests, and Dame Pattie herself. It was a quite remarkable response of hers at the age of 90—a 20-minute speech delivered without any notes, delivered with great verve, great wit, great recall and very great charm. To many people who looked upon her as a very distant and unknown figure, it was quite a remarkable evening.

As the Prime Minister remarked, she was touched by a great deal of personal sadness. To lose two of your three children is a sadness that I do not think many parents could accommodate, and she handled that with her very stoic courage and great dignity.

Dame Pattie made an enormous contribution to the symbolic importance, as well as the real significance to the Liberal Party, of our 50th anniversary celebrations in 1994. To have had present at those celebrations the widow of the founder of the party, somebody who had been continuously associated with the party through its history, was a remarkable component of those celebrations, and I know that many of us marvelled at the tremendous energy that she displayed and her tremendous commitment in coming to so many of the party's important celebrations.

Many of us had the opportunity of attending the memorial service held at Scots Church in Melbourne. Many of us also had had the opportunity of attending that great funeral service in Marrickville for the late Fred Daly, and I reflected to myself, after Dame Pattie Menzies' memorial service, that in a sense both of them represented in their own distinctive ways the different tribal gatherings. The gathering at Fred Daly's funeral was a great Irish-Catholic-Labor tribal gathering, which has been such an integral and important part of the fabric of this nation, and the gathering at Scots Church represented in a very real sense a Melbourne-Scots-Presbyterian, with a heavy liberal streak, gathering of that particular tribe. Although the tribal demarcations between our political parties and our different cultural traditions have now become very blurred and are very different, I think both of those traditions have made an enormous, valuable and positive contribution to the broad fabric of the Australian way of life.

Dame Pattie Menzies represented the values of millions of Australians, particularly the older generation. To say that not everybody would share all of those values or respect all of the traditions that she respected is not to deny the importance of those traditions and those values to a large segment of the Australian population. She represented the values of stability and continuity. She represented the values of service and commitment to country and commitment to family. They are values that I know are respected across the party lines in this country. She was a person of immense strength and personal charm. Her death, after such a very long, fruitful and enormously valuable life, although sad in itself is also a celebration of the capacity of individuals to touch many lives and to leave a power of good.

To her daughter, Heather, to her son-in-law, Peter, and to their children, all of whom bulk very large in the regard and affections of many in the Liberal Party, I convey my sympathy. Those who heard Heather's marvellous and moving tribute to her mother, both at the service in Melbourne and at the service in Canberra, saw it and heard it for what it was—an eloquent commentary from a fine lady about a very remarkable parent and an extremely fine Australian.

The Liberal Party honours unreservedly the memory of Dame Pattie Menzies. Her death severs a final link with a generation of Australian political behaviour and certain aspects of the Australian way of life that perhaps will never be the same again. We thank her for her enormous contribution not only to her family but also to the nation. She has certainly contributed much, and she will be long remembered not only by members of the Liberal Party but also by millions of Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the condolence motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) regarding the death of Dame Pattie Menzies. My wife, Judy, and I had the privilege of attending a special dinner function at the monarchists league in Australia a little over a year ago, on Wednesday, 15 June 1994, in the magnificent setting of the state parliament house dining room in Sydney. We had the privilege of sitting alongside Dame Pattie Menzies. On that occasion, a long day and a long and late function at night, she was fitter and fresher than many of us at the table. Indeed, she regaled us with many anecdotes over her long and rich contribution to the political fabric of this nation. Furthermore, she stood up and made a speech and showed that she was capable, cogent and cohesive at that very late stage in her life. It was an absolute delight that Dame Pattie, on a number of occasions, went out of her way to extend friendship to my wife, Judy, at a stage when Judy was first attending functions around Canberra and the capital cities. I was greatly helped and honoured by that, as I know Judy was.

PARA.TAB: Dame Pattie's upbringing was a very tough one. She lost her mother very early in life and had a pretty tough time of it family-wise around Alexandra, in central Victoria, and later in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. I am led to believe that the upbringing of a student at PLC is no bed of roses. It was very strict, but it allowed her to go to church each Sunday, look across the aisle and see the Menzies boys. She singled out one in particular—Robert Gordon Menzies—and spent some time being slightly distracted from the sermon. She subsequently got to know him, married him and made that huge contribution to Australian politics.

Of the leaders of my party, she knew most of them and knew them quite well. Over the 75 years the federal National Party has had nine leaders. She said to me on one of the last occasions that I spoke to her that she had argument with only one of them; the others she very much appreciated. There is no prize for guessing which one she disliked. It was, of course, Dr Earl Page and the reason related to the events of 1939 and 1940. She was very much a friend and a supporter, and she enjoyed a very extensive friendship with so many members of the parliamentary National Party present and past in a way which gave great cohesion to the coalition. I am very happy to join with the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister and others who are about to speak in extending sympathy to the Henderson family, the Menzies family, the Leckie family and their extended families regarding the loss of Dame Pattie Menzies.

It was a privilege to attend Scots Church—on the corner of Russell and Collins streets—for that very special and very moving service and to hear not only the Hendersons' great contribution, which the Leader of the Opposition referred to, but also that of Reverend Fred McKay, also aged about 90. Fred, who knew the family so well—who in his own right has made such a huge contribution to the flying doctors service and many other aspects of Australian life—was so wonderful in his praise of Dame Pattie Menzies. I say to the Henderson, the Menzies and the Leckie families, `You have an absolute right to be proud of a very special person who was a privilege to know.' I extend my deepest sympathy to the families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) in supporting the condolence motion for Dame Pattie Menzies. I too was privileged to be present in Scots Church when Heather Henderson and the Reverend Fred McKay delivered eulogies. Heather Henderson finished with that memorable line that her father used at the funeral of Sir Winston Churchill—`She will be gloriously remembered by me.'

PARA.TAB: Although we cannot claim to remember Dame Pattie in the same way that Heather can, we can all claim to gloriously remember her. She was a living link to the foundation of the Liberal Party, formed by her husband, whose term as Prime Minister of Australia will never be rivalled and whose pre-eminence will never be equalled. No-one was held in greater affection by the members of the Liberal Party than Dame Pattie. She was interested and involved in its activities to the end. Even though she never sought public office, she lived a very public life and was held in great esteem.

I think one of the things that most people who knew Dame Pattie would comment on was her sense of humour, her grace and her excellent judgment of people. On the occasions that I spoke to her, she was always full of advice, with penetrating advice on the people of the Liberal Party and the people of politics generally. There was no sense at all that she had lost her interest in politics. She was deeply engaged. I found her to be absolutely astute. She also had a sense of relaxation that put others at ease. Those of us who were present at the 50th anniversary dinner for the Liberal Party in Melbourne will recall that she was to be presented with an award by the president, Tony Staley. She took one look at Tony Staley and decided that she was fitter and more active than he was, so she walked to him to collect the award rather than let him walk to her to present it.

She was devoted to her family. She undertook considerable activities in the field of aged care, particularly the Melbourne women's hospital, and at the children's hospital. She never made a show of her social work, but she used her understanding and practical knowledge for the good, including on many occasions influencing her husband with policy changes. She was made a Dame Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire in recognition of her tireless work for hospitals and her incessant and unselfish performance of public duty, particularly her encouragement of Australian women.

She talked with women all over the country, in remote areas and in city locations, and encouraged them in her endeavours. She and Sir Robert were long-term residents in the Higgins electorate and, after Sir Robert's retirement, I came to represent her from 1990 onwards until she moved to Canberra. She believed passionately in the capacity of the individual. She championed freedom of speech, and she believed in the mutual support of family in the efforts that are bestowed upon all the family members.

Dame Pattie had a great sense of duty and service. No-one who met her would be in any doubt about her sense of fun and sense of humour. She lived her life to the full. No matter what the pressure was, she handled it with grace and distinction. We are saddened at her passing but enriched by her living. To her remaining child, Heather Henderson, and Heather's husband, Peter, to their grandchildren, to the other grandchildren and great-nephews and grand-nieces, I extend my condolences.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has indicated, the late Dame Pattie Menzies was born in Alexandra in the state of Victoria, and the town of Alexandra is within the federal division of McEwen. I am pleased to say to the House that Dame Pattie will not be forgotten in the town of Alexandra. She is recognised there by the establishment of the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre for the intellectually disabled, which has been in existence for a number of years. Dame Pattie Menzies was a frequent visitor to that centre, and that is where I had the privilege of meeting her.

PARA.TAB: Dame Pattie is a famous Australian woman. She will go into the history books as the wife of the late Robert Menzies and will be remembered. On behalf of the electorate of the division of McEwen, particularly those within the town of Alexandra, I place on record our sympathy and condolences to Heather Henderson and the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in the condolence motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). Dame Pattie's memorial services in Melbourne and Canberra regrettably took place when I was not in Australia; therefore, I could not attend either.

PARA.TAB: My knowledge of and acquaintance with Dame Pattie goes back many years. Indeed, I am the only remaining member of this parliament who sat with the late Sir Robert Menzies in his cabinet. I well remember at the time I was appointed Minister for Social Services receiving quite considerable advice and guidance from Dame Pattie. She had very strong views, not only in her later years but in her earlier years, about the administration of social welfare in this nation.

I also remember quite personally the extraordinary sympathy she showed my family and me when my first wife, Margaret, died way back in December 1967. Dame Pattie was a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and, more recently, great-grandmother. Above all, the life of Dame Pattie reflects something of the extraordinary contribution that wives and spouses can make to members and senators in this rather extraordinary life we live.

One of the extraordinary parts of Dame Pattie's contribution was not only in her public performance but in her private influence. Indeed, when one looks at Canberra and sees something of the development of this place, I think it is wise to remember that the Lodge in those days—in a different day and age—was far more part of what was then essentially a relatively large country town. If issues came to pass which involved the development or the services of this city, in the days of the National Capital Development Commission, Dame Pattie's influence inevitably was reflected in Sir Robert's voice. His attitudes and patterns in this place certainly reflected very much her own view of how this place should grow and develop, and Canberra and Canberrans should recall with pleasure and pride the way in which she indirectly and sometimes directly contributed to its growth and development.

She also had very strong views on a range of issues. During those years when Sir Robert was Prime Minister, in good times and bad it was her guidance, advice and friendship as much as her love for him which I believe contributed significantly towards the efficacy of his term as Prime Minister of Australia.

I saw Dame Pattie again as a grandmother. My children attended school with Heather's children, and we saw each other at speech days and other functions. She certainly was a remarkable person in the way in which she showed the entire devotion that one hopes will always exist between members of a family. She was a very kind and wonderful person in that sense, and I know how much Heather and her children will miss her. To Heather and Peter, to the extended Henderson family and to other members of the Menzies and Leckie families, I, like my colleagues, extend on behalf of Rosemary and me our deepest sympathy in her passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the pleasure of meeting Dame Pattie Menzies on a number of occasions and of hearing her speak. She communicated a remarkable life experience in the form of wise comment and advice which always struck a chord with the Liberal Party gatherings that she attended. The clarity of her mind seemed undimmed by the passage of the years. If anything, it seemed to become more finely honed, more incisive and wise.

PARA.TAB: In 1986, I had the honour to deliver the Sir Robert Menzies Lecture at Monash University, which Dame Pattie and her daughter, Heather, attended. The theme of the lecture was Robert Menzies' statement that liberty was a fundamental organising principle of a civilised society and that, in Australia, many liberties were being lost through the power of large organisations and government attempts to control the private lives of people.

At the end of that lecture, I quoted a statement of Sir Robert's about the nature of political life, which seemed to strike a special chord with Dame Pattie. I might just repeat it here. Sir Robert made the statement in 1954 at the end of a dinner address. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: "Did anybody suppose . . . that a man like myself who loves the law, and the practice of the law, and the whole philosophy of the law, would go into this turbulent stream for a job? A job! Of course not! And what I ask you to realise is that people like myself—and I'm not the only one—go into this life because they have beliefs, because they have a faith, because they believe there is something that matters for their own country".

In the role that she performed so well, Dame Pattie embodied I believe that same philosophy. She exemplified the model of public service, about which Sir Robert spoke. She cared for the Liberal Party, but above all she cared for Australia and its future and she never tired of promoting this country and the values which she believed underpinned its success. These were pre-eminently values of personal responsibility, integrity, selflessness and public service.

PARA.TAB: We will all miss her enormously, but none more so than her daughter, Heather, her son-in-law, Peter Henderson, and her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. I join the other members of the House in extending my condolences to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many have spoken before me, and I join with them in supporting the motion of condolence. Many have spoken of Dame Pattie Menzies as a wife, a mother, a grandmother and somebody who gave support and succour. I would like to say a few words about her as a woman, whom I came to know as a very modern woman, a woman of strength and resilience in her own right.

PARA.TAB: When I became President of the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party in 1985, it seemed to me that we needed to establish a foundation which would pursue the ideals, the philosophy, education and research—what you might call the higher things—of politics. I sought to name that foundation after somebody whom I believed had given enormously, yet had not been recognised in her own right. So I went to Melbourne to seek the permission of Dame Pattie Menzies to name that foundation after her.

After many discussions, we established the framework of the foundation. She agreed to give her name to it, and we drank a small toast to it at midday in sherry. Dame Pattie came to Sydney to launch that foundation. It was at the very dinner that John Howard referred to just a little while ago when he was presented with a screwdriver that she gave a speech of such force and such resilience as to spur the party on to ensure that the ideals in which she believed, as well as Sir Robert, were part and parcel of the ongoing Liberal Party.

When we gathered together on her death, it was at a service of thanksgiving for her life. It was a period of joy. Others have mentioned the stories told by Heather Henderson of her mother—about how she cared about running a good house, telling her husband to walk on the side of the stairs so as not to wear out the carpet, making pillowslips out of old sheets; understanding that she was an ordinary woman but living an extraordinary life.

Dame Pattie was small in stature, yet she strode the international stage with confidence, with affection and, yes, at the side of our longest serving Prime Minister—but also in her own right on so many occasions. It was a time when perhaps women's praises were not sung so loud, but she was one who gave a contribution because she believed in things. She was a strong and a resilient force within the Liberal Party right up to the last moments of her life. Her very presence could tell you that you had to lift your game because in public life we have standards to attain.

So in saying to Heather, Peter and the family that you have our condolences, I say you also have our thanks—our thanks for the fact that you shared your mother with us, and that she had the courage and the strength to be a woman who could stand very much in her own right, Dame Pattie Menzies.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Liberal Party held in Wodonga, my home town, in 1994 I was pleased to see Dame Pattie Menzies there to help us celebrate the history of the party founded by her late husband. During my conversations with her, she took great delight in reminding me that I was, in fact, the third member for Indi who had been the previous state member for Benambra. Sir Isaac Isaacs, of course, was the first and her father, John Leckie, was the second. It was very interesting to hear her talk about her father's work as the state member for Benambra and as the federal member. He was the state member from 1913 to 1916 and then the federal member for Indi from 1917 to 1919. Afterwards, he became a senator. I think it was good for me to hear that because it demonstrated her great knowledge of politics.

PARA.TAB: There are very few people who can claim to have a father who was both a state and a federal member. She told me that she used to spend some time with her father in the beautiful electorate of Indi and that it was always a means of escape for her from boarding school. She said that she was in boarding school for most of her early life and during school holidays she would travel with her father in the electorate of Benambra and Indi.

With those historical links to Dame Pattie, I am naturally very keen to add my words of sympathy to Heather and Peter and the grandchildren and great-grandchildren because they had a very great mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, and also because Dame Pattie had a great feeling for country people. She actually told me that her father used to say that for every pound that you spend on country people, you get two pounds back. For every pound you spend on city people, it costs you double. That was pretty earthy advice and I am sure that people would understand, therefore, the need to recognise the role of country people.

Dame Pattie was an Australian and I know that she meant a lot to people. Last week I lost my mother, who was 91, and she had such great pride and affection for Dame Pattie. So many people of that era really appreciated, understood and respected the Menzies family for what they were and for their commitment to this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a few words of tribute to the late Dame Pattie Menzies. I usually saw her at the Commonwealth offices at 4 Treasury Place, East Melbourne. She had an office there and generally turned up driving herself in a small, rather battered car. I talked to her quite often and found her a very lively conversationalist. She had a very keen sense of humour and laughed about odd incidents reported in the media. She was a very shrewd observer of character, not entirely partisan in judgment, I may say.

PARA.TAB: During her long life she gave distinguished service to the Australian community, her husband, her family and the Liberal Party. Her having attended PLC, it is entirely appropriate to refer to her `brilliant career'. She leaves a fragrant memory behind her. In such times where we leave our partisanship behind and salute her memory, I extend my condolences to her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege to support this motion of condolence on the death of Dame Pattie Menzies. The nation has lost a distinguished Australian. Dame Pattie served Australia with diligence and distinction. She stood alongside Sir Robert throughout his trials and his triumphs. Her contribution to Sir Robert's achievements as Australia's outstanding and longest serving Prime Minister cannot be overestimated.

PARA.TAB: She gave service to all Australians in her own right.Her community activities, her vital interest in contemporary political affairs and her constant travelling around the country kept her in touch with the aspirations of all Australians. Her huge circle of friends and admirers is a testimony to the affection with which she has so long been regarded.

Anyone who met Dame Pattie in her later years was struck by her vivacity, gentleness and ability to cut to the heart of an issue. So impressive was she that for a long time one believed that she could go on forever. Inspiring is a much overused word but it did apply to Dame Pattie.
Dame Pattie, alongside Sir Robert, gave the electors of Kooyong an unprecedented period of service. They will miss her and remember her with respect and affection.
I join with others in expressing my deep sympathy to the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being nearly 30 years since Sir Robert Menzies retired from parliament, not surprisingly there are not many members in this House who knew Dame Pattie when she was the wife of the Prime Minister. But I was privileged to meet her twice in 1963. The reason I speak today is that she made such an indelible impression on me that I felt I should contribute to this condolence motion and put on the record, for those who did not have the privilege of ever meeting her, just what an extraordinary impression she made on people.

PARA.TAB: In 1963, Robert Menzies, as he was then, and Dame Pattie as she was, visited Brisbane twice, in April and November, during an election campaign. When they arrived in the prime ministerial plane, the call went out to Young Liberals to go to the airport to meet them because most members of the party were at work. I was then the State Secretary of the Young Liberals and duly went out. The state director of the party, Charles Porter, thrust a bunch of flowers into my arms and said, `Please give these to Dame Pattie.' He introduced me to her and I did that. She chatted in a very animated way with the young people who were out there. Robert Menzies was not so interested in the young people—I am sure he had very important things on his mind—but I must admit I was impressed at the time with the time and trouble she took over us youngsters.

In November of that year, when the election had been announced, Robert Menzies came to Brisbane. There was a youth rally in the Brisbane City Hall. It was the first youth rally of any political campaign in Australia and the first release by any political party of any youth policy. Again, the powers that be in the Liberal Party decided that instead of having a lot of grey hair on the stage with Robert Menzies they wanted youth. The state executive of the Young Liberals were told they were to sit on the stage at the city hall—which we thought, of course, was a great honour. By then I was no longer state secretary; I was Vice-President of the Young Liberals. The point at which Dame Pattie really slew me was when we were being introduced to the Menzies in the foyer of the city hall. Charles Porter said to Dame Pattie, `I would like you to meet the Vice-President of the Young Liberals.' Before he had mentioned my name, she said, `Oh, I have met Miss Martin before.'

I was so impressed by the fact that she not only remembered meeting me but also put the name to the face that I was her devoted worshipper ever since. Sir Robert Menzies had other things on his mind and was very preoccupied. I considered it a great honour to have met the Prime Minister of Australia twice, but Dame Pattie made such a powerful impact on me in those two meetings that I always treasured their memory. I realised, as I do even now, that I had met a very special Australian.

When she died I read all the obituaries and all the eulogies and all the newspapers that I could lay my hands on. I went in search of this woman's personality, the woman whom I remembered with such strength of affection. I read about a woman who did many things that I was previously unaware she had done.

She clearly was a very intelligent woman, with great personality. Everybody I know who ever met her would use the same term as I would. My memory of the impact she made on me then and the memory I have of her is that she was `bird-like'. She was tiny, her eyes were bright and shiny and she was full of bounce and life and vivacity. She had a great interest in things, which she focused fully on whatever was occupying her at that moment.

She was one of those extraordinary human beings whom, as I said, I was privileged to meet not once but twice. I say to her family that I have just the smallest inkling of what an enormous void must have been left in their lives by her passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to this condolence motion for Dame Pattie Menzies as a woman and as a shadow minister for women's affairs. I, unfortunately, did not know Dame Pattie Menzies but it is very clear that Dame Pattie contributed immensely to Australia at the side of her husband, the leader Sir Robert Menzies, by her own deeds and through her own special capacities. She was a wonderful role model for those women in the days when she was with us and she will continue to be a wonderful role model for young women and women generally in Australia even after her passing. I acknowledge the tremendous contribution Dame Pattie made to Australia, to the Australian people and to women specifically and offer my condolences to her family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for the electorate bearing the name of the former Prime Minister Sir Robert Menzies, I wish to associate myself with this tribute to his wife, Dame Pattie Menzies. I do not believe that anyone who has not been in public life can fully understand the enormous pressures that this life sometimes places on spouses and families. That Dame Pattie carried herself through the 40 years of public life of her husband and for another 20 or more years afterwards in public life with quiet dignity, with warmth and with a genuine concern for others is a tribute to her of which all Australians, I believe, regardless of their party political affiliations, can be entirely proud.

PARA.TAB: The worth of her contribution was noted in the official citation conferring the Grand Cross of the Order of the British Empire in 1954, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) cited. Dame Pattie's contribution involved the good advice that one would expect to be offered by her. In his book The Measure of the Years Sir Robert recounted the conversation over dinner at the Lodge in 1954:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1954 over the dinner table at the Prime Minister's Lodge, my wife made a remark which took root in my mind. She said, `I hear a lot of talk about rates of pension and so on, but do you know, I believe that the greatest social need for old people is that they should have a place of their own to live in. Couldn't you think up some scheme under which the government could subsidise the building of proper accommodation?' The immediate result of this suggestion was that I began to think more closely about that aspect of the problems of old age. The next step was to devise a scheme in consultation with some of my colleagues. The result was the Aged Persons Homes Act—

the forerunner of legislation which relates to elderly people in hostels and nursing homes, to so many Australians today. Of course, not all Dame Pattie's advice was accepted by her husband. In his other book Afternoon Light Sir Robert recounted his decision in November 1940 to visit the Middle East and England:

Late in November 1940 I decided to pay a visit to the Middle East and to England. Seeing that I had been reduced to a majority consisting of two Independents, this was no doubt a risky venture. Indeed, my wife, with feminine realism, said to me, `If you feel you must go, you will go but you will be out of office within six weeks of your return.' In the event, she was not a mile out.

We on this side of politics, in the Liberal Party, have been honoured by her contribution to this nation. We have been delighted by her presence, especially in recent years, such as at the opening of R. G. Menzies House here in Canberra. We are saddened by her passing. The values of loyalty, of service and of compassion remain an inspiration to us all. With my other colleagues I offer my condolences to Heather and to other members of her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesitate to join this condolence motion but I want to say just a few words on behalf of a friend of mine, Mrs Margaret Kelly, nee O'Malley, who knew Dame Pattie Menzies very well. She originally worked for Hansard, she worked for Sir Arthur Fadden, she worked for Sir Robert Menzies when he was Prime Minister and she thus knew of Dame Pattie's very many qualities. I would like to relate to the House an incident that occurred in 1945 following the passing of Prime Minister Curtin.

PARA.TAB: In those days in the Old Parliament House things were very much more intimate than they are in this place. Mrs Kelly, who then worked for Hansard, was told with other Hansard stenographers that if they wanted to see the Prime Minister's cortege pass then one went to the office of the Leader of the Opposition. She went up there with others and saw Dame Pattie looking rather sadly from the window at the passing funeral procession. She went up to Dame Pattie and sought to comfort Dame Pattie, who was visibly moved by the very sad events which were occurring. Dame Pattie said words to the effect that, `It is very sad. Bob will be next. It's a very hard life.'

Fortunately on this occasion Dame Pattie Menzies was not right because Sir Robert lived to serve his nation for another 33 years. Sir Robert Menzies and Dame Pattie were a very close family unit. I am also told that in his office when Dame Pattie's plane was late Sir Robert would pace back and forth and would use words to the effect, `Is Pattie down yet?' over and over. He was obviously very concerned that she should arrive safely.

I also refer to the recollections of Mrs Margaret Gaffey, nee Underwood, who worked and took shorthand for Dame Pattie Menzies. She always said what a pleasure she was to work for. When one listens to the contributions made by members on both sides and when one listened, as I was fortunate to do, at the State Memorial Service in Melbourne to the contribution made by Dame Pattie's daughter it is very clear that all Australians have lost a wonderful fellow citizen, a person who made a very great contribution to this nation's welfare over a very long time. I am very pleased and also humbled to associate myself with the condolence motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and other speakers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this condolence motion because one of the effects of the Canberra by-election was that Dame Pattie actually became one of my constituents. I had met Dame Pattie several times before becoming a politician and she was always an inspiration to me. She was certainly loved by the local party and we were pleased to have her here as a resident in Canberra. The thing that impressed me most was the ordinary way in which she went about her life. She was certainly a great wife and a great supporter of her husband. To all Australian women she was a great representative of Australia and, therefore, a great example to whom all Australian women could look to.

PARA.TAB: She used her position to do good through her charitable work and through the influence that she was able to bring to bear on her husband. As we have heard, long before it was fashionable she was working for the good of people with disabilities. She lent her support to hospitals and particularly to aged care.

From the perspective of Canberra, as the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said, it was at her urging that Prime Minister Menzies did something about Canberra and, in 1956, formed the then NCDC. It was also at her urging at a personal level—it was hard for women with strollers and children to get up and down some of the decaying sidewalks—that footpaths were established. Again, it was her personal care for the people of Australia that culminated in the wonderful city of Canberra, part of which I now have the opportunity to represent.

Her daughter Heather, in the ceremony here at the Presbyterian Church of St Andrew on Monday last, said that Dame Pattie had one unfulfilled ambition for Canberra, and I will now put that on Hansard. It was her wish to see a Prime Minister's avenue established, with each tree representing a Prime Minister that has gone before us and existing Prime Ministers as they come along. Each Prime Minister's family would have an opportunity to plant a tree so that this city would have a continuous link with the Prime Minister of the nation. Perhaps that is something the new NCPA could look at.

My wife Glenda and I met Dame Pattie on several occasions and were always impressed by the fire in her soul, even though her body got older. Last year at the opening of the R.G. Menzies House she spoke very strongly about what the Liberal Party owed this country and the leadership that it must offer. Again last year there were festivities at the National Library of Australia to celebrate 50 years of the Liberal Party and I had the opportunity to assist Dame Pattie at those functions. In fact, I got to wheel her around in her wheelchair at that stage. Again, I was touched by this lady's remarkable nature in her ability to converse with all people and to treat all people with great dignity.

On behalf of the ACT division of the Liberal Party, my wife and me, I offer condolences to Peter and Heather, who are also long-time residents now of Canberra, and I extend these condolences to the Henderson and Leckie families.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—I thank the House.
Motion (by Mr Elliott)—by leave—agreed to:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent Grievance Debate being continued until 6.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that we, the undersigned would like to express our firm belief that East Timorese in Australia who are applying for refugee status:
should be given refugee status if it is found that they have suffered any form of persecution under the Indonesian government,
should not be forced to resettle in a third country as the humanitarian aspects of their applications override any political considerations,
that this decision on refugee status be made quickly so that drawn out legal proceedings do not add to their already unbearable situations.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House take all steps necessary to grant the above requests.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free (from 63 citizens), Mr Allan Morris (from 30 citizens) and Mr Ronaldson (from 39 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Day Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, being—Family Day Care Caregivers and/or Parent users of Family Day Care services,—draws to the attention of the House to
the threat to the continuation of Family Day Care services,
the loss of thousands of childcare places,
the loss of employment for thousands of caregivers, resulting from the introduction of an award for Self Employed Caregivers.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House recommends, with regard to the ALP Working Party, set up under resolution No 164R "to consider the implementation of the provision of better wages and conditions for home based child care workers", that the Government seek input from the stake holders:
the 15,087 Family Day Care Caregivers
the Parents of the 76,356 children using Family Day Care
the Sponsors of the FDC schemes

PETITION.PARA: before making any decisions.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb (from 63 citizens) and Mr Hollis (from 116 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker (from 40 citizens) and Mr Jull (from 10 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Mobile Base Station, Harbord
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of Harbord draws the attention to the House of the situation where Telecom has installed a mobile base station beside the Harbord kindergarten and Baby Health Centre.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House asks the Minister for Communications to reverse the approval of this facility in the heart of Harbord Village on the grounds of the community's concern for the health and welfare of its children.

PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

We believe that the traditional Christian view of the family unit excludes anything other than a male and female, living in a lawful marriage relationship, along with their children, and that it is necessary for this to be restated by our political leaders.
We reaffirm our belief in the traditional Christian view of marriage as God's holy institution in which male and female become one flesh. (Genesis 2.24; Matthew 19.5,6)

We reaffirm that God is the author of marriage, and has restricted it to the union of male with female and that such marriage between male and female is commended in Scripture as honourable among all. (Ephesians 5.15-23)
We reaffirm that such marriage between male and female is ordained for life-long companionship, help and comfort which husband and wife ought to have of each other. (Romans 7.2,3)

We reaffirm that children are a heritage of the Lord and should be nurtured in a godly home, and that human society can be strong and happy only where the marriage bond is held in honour. (Psalm 127.3)

We reaffirm that incestuous marriages can never be made lawful by the law of any man or government, or the consent of parties, so as to allow those people to live together as married couples. (Mark 6.18; Leviticus 18.6-28)

We reaffirm that, according to Biblical law, it is forbidden for a male to practise sexual intercourse with another male, or for a female with a female, and that since this is an abomination before the Lord, such as a prohibited relationship for marriage. (Leviticus 18.22; 20.13)
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the Government to:
(a) Preserve completely intact the exclusiveness of marriage as being one male and one female.
(b) That the definition of a prohibited relationship in the Marriage Act 1961, Part III 23(2) be amended with the addition of a new clause (c) so that it reads as follows:
(2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited relationship are marriages—
(a) between a person and an ancestor or descendant of the person; or
(b) between a brother and a sister (whether of the whole blood or the half blood); or
(c) between a male and a male or between a female and a female.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest possible terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Craigieburn Railway Line
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned requests urgent and immediate funding for the electrification of the railway line to Craigieburn.
Your petitioners request that such funding be provided under the Better Cities Program to alleviate the lack of public transport in the fastest growing area of metropolitan Melbourne.

PETITION.TITLE: No Fees for Degrees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of citizen and resident of Australia points out to the House the adverse impact of fees for all courses. Fees:

are a major barrier to the participation of women, mature aged students, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students, and students from other economically, socially and geographically disadvantaged backgrounds in

restrict the educational options of students. Students with large HECS debts from their previous education may be inclined to avoid undertaking valuable postgraduate and undergraduate courses, therefore leading to premature closure of career choices
contradict the ALP Federal Government's stated goals of lifelong learning and retraining
Your petitioners therefore request the House ensure the equitable provision of undergraduate and postgraduate education in Australia's Universities by:
fully funding postgraduate course offerings and amending the Higher Education Funding Act to preclude the imposition of fees for postgraduate courses
input more public funding into higher education, abolish HECS and stop increasing HECS

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned residents in the region of North Queensland respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: That the action of French nuclear testing on Murouroa Atoll has the potential to cause environmental hazard in the Pacific.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the parliament of Australia will ensure that:

PETITION.PARA: The government will lobby other countries and the UN to enforce a trade embargo on France.
The government will stop selling Uranium to the French.
and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: 1.They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2.They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack—itself the creation of three Christian crosses—represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.

PARA.TAB: (b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the States and the Territories of the Commonwealth.

PETITION.PARA: 3.They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to the generations of Australians in peace and war.
4.They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5.They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian Community.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole National Flag.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:
(a) deplores the fact that six Australian women per day die from breast cancer and notes the possibility of contracting breast cancer is as high as one chance in 12 for Australian women;
(b) recognises the fact that breast cancer has the potential to affect every Australian family; and
(c) recognises that there are inadequate research funds available to help combat breast cancer.
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives call on the Government to:
(a) increase funding for breast cancer research ten-fold (a minimum of $14 million) in the 1994/95 Budget; and
(b) consider further initiatives through the tax system to encourage donations for breast cancer research.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the grave environmental and health consequences arising from the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to note that those petitioners whose signatures appear below:
(a) are appalled at the political arrogance of the recent decision by the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific;

(b) commit themselves to a voluntary boycott of the consumption of all goods made in France and all services delivered by majority-owned French companies—until such time as the French Government reverses its decision;
(c) call on the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to initiate the strongest multi-lateral and bi-lateral diplomatic action necessary to bring about a reversal of the French decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the adverse consequences of a decision by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to close Adult Migrant English classes in Auburn New South Wales and to require the Adult Migrant English Service (AMES) to transfer these classes to Parramatta.

This action presents obstacles to attendance at English classes. It would impose a need to travel on many migrants and refugees in their early stages of settlement. Many lack the confidence, language skills and money to do so. It would create difficulties for parents caring for young children. Some would not be able to overcome these obstacles and would forfeit their entitlement to classes.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to direct the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to continue to fund the full range of AMES classes at Auburn.

PETITION.TITLE: Pulmozyme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the state of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the medication Pulmozyme.
Pulmozyme which is the first new medication for the treatment of the genetic disease Cystic Fibrosis (CF) in 30 years is being marketed by Roche Products Pty Ltd and is also known as Dornase Alfa.
Pulmozyme has been extensively trialled and shown to improve lung function, reduce lung infections and improve quality of life for a third of children and young people with CF.
Pulmozyme costs $1,125 per month and is beyond the reach of most families. It is being subsidised in 16 countries including UK, Canada, USA and most West European countries.
A Consensus Statement from CF specialists around Australia recommends Pulmozyme be listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under Section 100.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take action to ensure Pulmozyme is listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under Section 100.

PETITION.TITLE: Pulmozyme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House that the medication `Pulmozyme' marketed by Roche Pharmaceutical's for the treatment of Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is not listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme in Australia. Pulmozyme is subsidised in many other countries as it is shown to improve lung functions, reduce C.F. symptoms and improve the quality of life for many Cystic Fibrosis sufferers. In Australia the cost for this treatment is $39 per day.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully request the House to list Pulmozyme on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under Section 100 to enable Cystic Fibrosis sufferers to have the benefit of an improved quality of life.

PETITION.TITLE: Pulmozyme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

This medication marketed by ROCHE PHARMACEUTICALS for treatment of CYSTIC FIBROSIS (C.F.) is shown to improve lung functions, reduce C.F. symptoms and improve overall quality of life.

PULMOZYME is being subsidised in over 14 countries including U.K., U.S.A., and Canada. However, in Australia it costs $1,125.00 per month ($39.00 per day) placing it out of the financial reach of most C.F. sufferers.

C.F. doctors from around Australia have produced a consensus statement recommending `PULMOZYME' be listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under Section 100. It also produced guidelines for its use.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully request the House to immediately list PULMOZYME on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under Section 100.

PETITION.TITLE: The Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

PARA.TAB: World-wide, people are concerned that vital natural resources, such as trees, soil, pure air, clean water and our earth's protective ozone layer—all essential for sustaining life—have been dangerously depleted.
We the undersigned endorse the Earth Repair Charter, and pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Legislate to implement the charter's objectives as a practical solution-strategy to help end humanity's environmental, social and economic imbalances, so that Australia can lead the way globally towards achieving just, sustainable and cooperative local and national communities.
The objectives of the Earth Repair Charter are to:
Unite nations in earth repair action
Protect natural heritage and biodiversity
Respect indigenous peoples of the world
Acknowledge earth and life as sacred
Resolve conflict by peaceful mediation
Use permaculture to end world hunger
Practise composting to restore soils
Acquire health and immunity efficiency
Promote sustainable living by example
Join with others in a common purpose

PETITION.TITLE: Deua Wilderness
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention to the House that the Federal Government and the State governments (except Tasmania) signed the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) in December 1992. The policy states:

PETITION.PARA: "until assessments are completed, forest management agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value." (NFPS, page 11)

PARA.TAB: This obligation is being totally ignored by the NSW Government. A prime example is in the high conservation value Deua Wilderness in southern NSW.

Despite the NFPS obligation, logging activities are continuing in both the Eastern and Western Deua Wilderness before the required assessments. This reckless approach to forest management threatens endangered species known to exist in the area.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to force the NSW Government to cease logging in the Deua Wilderness, and all other areas of high conservation value forest in the state. This will then allow assessments to be undertaken as required by the NFPS.

PETITION.TITLE: Forest Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

PARA.TAB: This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate federal government intervention to protect the remaining high conservation value forests and other areas which support flora and fauna habitats unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives call on the Federal Government to:
comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention, to which Australia is a signatory, and immediately implement the moratorium clause in the national forest policy statement;
reap only what is sown and utilise readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;

permanently protect all old growth forests, wilderness, and other high conservation value areas, under the guardianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in co-operation with the community, conservation and scientific organisations;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and economic adjustment for affected workers and contractors;
create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands;
convert paper and fibre board manufacture to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp and cane;
encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous, plantation based tree products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources;
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

INTERJECT.PARA: RESPONSE TO PETITION PRESENTED TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ON 29 MAY 1995 BY THE HON J.D.M. DOBIE MP AND MR P. GEORGIOU MP RELATING TO THE AMERICAN HEALTH CARE SYSTEM

Various amendments were made to the legislation as the result of a Senate enquiry. Submissions were received by many groups who would be affected by the Act including doctors, hospitals, consumer groups and health insurance funds.

The changes to private health insurance remove many of the restrictions previously placed on the private health insurance system and, unlike under managed care, the patient retains the choice of doctor and hospital.
The reforms create a more competitive industry and allow for greater choice of products for those who choose to supplement Medicare with private health insurance.

Doctors may now choose to contract with health funds which allows the funds to provide cover to members for amounts in excess of the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) fee. This will result in no, or a known level of, out-of-pocket expenses for the patient.

There is no compulsion for doctors to contract with the funds. If a patient prefers a doctor who does not have a contract with their fund then the previous arrangement remains. That is, they will receive 100% of the MBS fee, 75% from Medicare and 25% from their insurance fund.

The reforms to private health insurance will in no way lead to a US style health system. On the contrary, they allow for greater patient choice when it comes to their health care and a more competitive industry, providing better health insurance products.

Mr L M Barlin

RESPONSE TO PETITION PRESENTED TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ON 26 JUNE 1995 BY THE HON. DR C.M. LAWRENCE MP
The petition relates to a request that the drug TAXOL (paclitaxel) be subsidised by the Federal Government under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) is the expert body that advises me which drugs and medicinal preparations may be listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PSB). When considering items for listing on the PBS, the PBAC is required to take into account the safety, efficacy and value for money of the preparation concerned.
For a drug to be accepted as a pharmaceutical benefit, the manufacturer must demonstrate that the drug is at least as effective as alternative treatments and that its use represents value for money.

TAXOL is currently available as a pharmaceutical benefit for the treatment of advanced ovarian cancer. An application to extend the use of TAXOL on the PBS for use as third line chemotherapy (that is after other treatment has failed) in advanced breast cancer was recently considered for a second time by the PBAC. The PBAC rejected the application because of the lack of evidence that use of TAXOL conferred benefits over comparative, less expensive drugs.

The manufacturer of TAXOL has been apprised of the PBAC's decision and advised of the data that is needed to support an application for subsidising TAXOL for the treatment of breast cancer. A further application has now been received which is being evaluated and will be discussed at PBAC's forthcoming meeting in September.
