SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have learnt today that the World Bank has decided that Australians are worth $1 million a head. Most of this, we are told, is because of our pristine environment. There is one blot on this $1 million environment that every Australian enjoys, and that is the tangle of wires and poles which constitute the downside of the information superhighway.

PARA.TAB: Much of our environment is improving today thanks to ever greater awareness and ever greater environmental sensitivity. We will not let logging companies denude hillsides purely for the sake of the dollar. We will not let industrial companies dump their garbage in rivers purely for the sake of the dollar and we will not let chemical companies spew their poisons into the atmosphere purely for the sake of the dollar, yet this government is letting telecommunications companies add to the visual clutter in our cities purely for the sake of the dollar.

I warn the government that Optus's decision to deliver pay TV by cable draped on power poles, which is now being followed by Telstra in an example of how competition can sometimes drive standards down, threatens that the information superhighway will end in a dead-end of an urban jungle of poles and wires. We have had no debate on the delivery of a pay TV service. Hardly anyone in the cities and towns of Australia is aware of the fact that Optus, and now Telstra, wants to deliver pay TV by the cheaper, nasty method of overhead cable. This is the biggest sneak attack since Pearl Harbour. It is an absolute outrage that this government is allowing these companies to get away with it.

I have to say that I am not against pay TV. I just think that pay TV, if delivered by cable, should be delivered by cable underground. It should be delivered by cables which enhance our life and do not detract from our life. We have more than enough clutter overhead. We have more than enough space junk in our cities already; we do not need any more to deliver us pay TV via cable.

Last month, Optus Vision wrote to Manly council in my electorate announcing that, in the terms of the various laws and regulations governing telecommunications, it proposed to roll out pay TV cable within six weeks. The council wrote back seeking further and better particulars. Optus wrote back one of those pro-forma fill-in-the-blanks letters that could have been written to any council in Australia. In fact, it gave no details whatsoever. Manly council is trying to formally object, under the provisions of the telecommunications code, to the roll-out of Optus Vision pay TV cable.

I have to say that from these telecommunications companies there has been a most unfortunate lack of openness. For instance, I wrote to Telstra earlier this year seeking information on where Telstra would be trying to deliver pay TV via overhead cable. I got this response from Telstra:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposals for aerial street cabling are subject to notification and consultation obligations contained in the telecommunications national code.

In other words, what Telstra was saying was, `Don't you worry about overhead cabling, because it is all governed by the telecommunications national code.' Austel have recently written to the Kuringai council—this letter has been passed on to the Manly council—saying that this is not the case at all. In fact, Austel have said:
Where no agreement can be reached as regards construction of a tower or similar installation, Council is able to require the carrier to refer the issue to the Department.
That is what Telstra was implying in their letter. However, Austel says:
. . . that provision does not apply where the proposed infrastructure relates to cable. In the latter circumstance—
that is to say, where the proposed infrastructure relates to cable—
the carrier is obliged to refer the issue to the Department only where the installation is, in the carrier's opinion,
.likely to give rise to an environmental objection . . .
.likely to raise substantial environmental concern within the community, and
this is significant—
.the carrier agrees that the effect upon the environment will be or is likely to be significant.

There we have it. There is complete open slather for these companies to roll out cable absolutely anywhere they like, and the local councils cannot do anything about it. This is an absolute outrage. It shows that this system of rules that the government has in place is completely meaningless. It shows that Austel is a watchdog which does not even bark let alone bite. It shows the need for the government to get serious about telecommunications regulations straight away.

PARA.TAB: Optus Vision have agreed to meet with local members of parliament plus Manly council on 3 October. But according to Austel, Optus Vision, or indeed Telstra, have the right to roll out cable whenever they like. I warn Optus Vision that, if they were to decide to do that before this meeting, they would be guilty of a very serious breach of faith with the Manly community.

This problem is not, in the end, with Optus or with Telstra or with Austel; it is with the government. What the government should do is halt this roll-out of pay TV cable until some important questions are answered. Firstly, the possibility of co-location needs to be thoroughly investigated. Secondly, it needs to determine whether the government is prepared to allow two pay TV cables to be hung from the same sets of power poles, thus doubling the overhead clutter. We then need to work out when the electricity utilities plan to go underground with their wiring, if ever. Finally, what contribution are these telecommunications companies going to make to the cost of this? Only after these issues have been addressed can or should pay TV cable be rolled out.

I am not against Optus; I want to make that clear. I believe that there should be a level playing field between Optus and Telstra. The fact is that Telstra have conduits under most suburban streets. Optus should be allowed free access to those conduits to put their pay TV cable there. Telstra claim that there is no room in their conduits. Quite frankly, Telstra's claim cannot be taken seriously. Telstra cannot be trusted on this matter any more, it seems, than the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) can be trusted.

Most Telstra conduit is 50 millimetres. The sort of cable that both companies are running out at the moment is 17 millimetre cable. There is certainly room for two 17 millimetre cables in the existing Telstra conduit. I call upon the federal government to investigate this matter. If it is technically feasible, the federal government must direct Telstra to make their conduits available to Optus. The fact of the matter is that that conduit is not owned by Telstra, which is entirely funded by the taxpayer and owned by the federal government. That conduit is owned by the Australian taxpayer. It must be put to the use of the Australian taxpayer and not simply to the commercial interest of one company called Telstra.

Telstra has a very privileged position in our society. I think it had better be careful that it does not abuse it. We read in the paper this week that there are 103 executives in Telstra today who are earning more than $100,000 a year. There are 148 members of this parliament who earn less than that to run the country. There are eight Telstra executives who earn more than $500,000 a year. That is eight Telstra executives who earn more than the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Telstra had better be pretty careful about the liberties and the licences they appear to be taking with the Australian public.

A story in the Courier-Mail points out that residents objecting to a mobile phone tower could not proceed because the 12 law firms they approached—all 12 of them—are on Telstra's list to get briefs. So none of them would act. The fact is that the problem is not just with Manly council. North Sydney had a vote with the recent mayoral poll. Seventy per cent objected to overhead cabling. The Shoroc councils of the North Shore and the peninsula councils are all objecting to overhead cabling for pay TV. I put a question on notice about this issue. I think it is absolutely vital that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) does not neglect this question on notice like he has neglected all the others.

TALK.START.PARA: —We certainly heard a potpourri of ideas there. I remind the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) that his side of parliament did not support the recognition of local government. I find it quite audacious that he should come into this House and suggest that local government should have more rights when his side does not even recognise that they exist.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk about a grievance today. That grievance is the disservice being done to Australia's youth by the federal opposition. We should not ignore the job that the opposition is doing on our youth. We have seen the job that it has done in talking down the economy, in talking up interest rates and in creating a lack of confidence in Australian families, who have now enjoyed 16 quarters of consecutive economic growth. By constant harping, the opposition has had a major effect on those families who do not enjoy the confidence that they should at this stage in our economic cycle.

The disservice being done to our youth is caused by the constant whingeing of the opposition in claiming that the government is not doing enough for the youth of today and the unemployed, particularly those who have little or no job skills. The opposition is always long on rhetoric but short on fact when it raises this argument. Selective memory is a wonderful thing. Members of the opposition are endowed with it in great abundance. They overlook the fact that more than 600,000 young Australians now attend our universities and that all undergraduate courses are HECS-liable, so they do not have up-front fees. They overlook the fact that the retention rate in high schools throughout Australia has escalated to record levels under this government. I can quote the figures because—

TALK.START.PARA: —They're starting to drop though—remember?

—There you go again; you cannot resist the opportunity to let the young people know that the opposition wanted them to work for $3 an hour. That is what you wanted. The youth out there know that, if you strike it lucky and the press continues to support you at the next election, that is what you will be asking them to do. Apart from your industrial relations policy that you probably have tucked away somewhere that you got out of some medieval epistle, you will be asking them to work for a measly sum that will be less than unemployment benefits.

PARA.TAB: The opposition either does not know or is completely oblivious to the success rate of labour market programs. They rarely speak about the jobs that have been created in record numbers by the Keating government. This evening I would like to mention a particularly innovative project that the Hunter Valley Training Company has been involved in. Last Wednesday in Penrith yet another example of the government's commitment to finding jobs and reducing the level of unemployment was unveiled by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free). This was the skills express mobile training system. It comprises mobile classrooms fitted out with state-of-the-art computer equipment which is used for providing hands-on training for the unemployed in areas where access to such equipment is not normally available.

This mobile training system was the brainchild of one of their staff. It comprises a couple of semitrailers, pantechnicon bodies, fitted out and fully airconditioned. These are available at short notice to go anywhere in the state of New South Wales. All they need is a power supply and they can provide immediate training facilities for people in the most remote parts of New South Wales. They are already booked for 200,000 training hours over the next three years. I am sure that the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) would be most interested because I know that in the next few weeks one of these will be going out to the coalmine at Ulan. While that may not be in his electorate, it is certainly getting fairly close to it. It will provide training for the people who work at the mine. This is the response of a government that places training above many things. Yet we see an opposition that continually tears away at the confidence of young people.

I was a teacher for 29 years in the secondary system in New South Wales. I know that one of the greatest things that we can give the youth of Australia is confidence—confidence that the skill and knowledge that we impart in the schools will be of use to them and will provide them with a job and a future career. That is why the constant harping from over there really does take effect with our youth. On the one hand, they can see the training that is being offered and the innovation that is appearing but, on the other hand, they hear members opposite constantly dragging at their confidence. They do not know which way to turn.

Fortunately, these mobile classrooms will be able to take training to all parts of the state. It is named skills express, which is very suited. Three units have been set up at this stage. Two of them have multiple uses. They are mobile classrooms. As I said, they are fitted with computers. One of them is a specialist facility that has been set up as a workshop where hydraulics mechanics can be taught. Of course, the sky is the limit as far as the ability of these mobile rooms to impart knowledge and skills is concerned.

The Hunter Valley Training Company is a success in its own right. It was established in 1981 during depressed economic conditions. Of course, we can mention who the federal government was at that time. It was used to train 299 Bayswater power station apprentices. The opening date for Bayswater was delayed and the company had two options—to release the trained apprentices to become unemployed statistics or formulate an employment policy. It chose the latter. Fourteen years later, with a large degree of government assistance, its staff number over 1,000 and its training policies and techniques are high in demand throughout the Hunter region and beyond.

Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, I am sure that you are aware of the values of the Hunter Valley Training Company in your own area. It has the ability to place apprentices where that workplace environment is not immediately available. It has trained in excess of 3,000 young people in over 50 different trades. That is the beauty of such a training facility. I am very proud that it is an initiative and that it has received the continuous support of the government. This facility, combined with regional divisions in Maitland, Wollongong, Coffs Harbour, Sydney, Port Macquarie, Lismore, Tamworth and the Shoalhaven, is offering an enormous resource to the young people of New South Wales.

Training methods include modular formats and skills audits. Hunter Valley Training Company personnel are considered to be the best in the industry. They have wide experience directly with hands-on skills in industry. Most of the trainers have come directly from industry and they know the skills that are needed. In 1990 the Hunter Valley Training Company branched out into training for industry and the public. They also host training for apprentices employed by other firms. The skills express is the latest project of the Hunter Valley Training Company. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I talk about my grievance, I would like to make a comment about the grievance of the previous speaker, the member for Paterson (Mr Horne). He was talking about training programs and complaining that the opposition is concerned about young people—
—You're not.

—He was saying that it is our comments which are sapping their confidence. The real reason that young people's confidence is being sapped is that, after 12 years of Labor, 28.3 per cent of them cannot get jobs. In my electorate the figure is 40 per cent. The real reason is that the overall policies of this federal government are discouraging young people. I wish that retention rates would continue to go up. I welcome the retention rates going up. The fact is that young people are now saying, `If I study hard, the fact is under this government I only end up on the dole queues anyway. I can't get a job.' That is what is sapping their confidence—this high unemployment rate amongst young people. It has nothing to do with the opposition. Woe betide any opposition that did not tell the Australian parliament what the policies of this government are doing to young people. We will continue to let the Australian people know that the policies of this government—with its huge overseas debt, high interest rates and a whole range of other factors—are deadening the Australian economy so that jobs are not being created at the rate at which they should be.

PARA.TAB: I rise to make some comments about Australian families. The reason I rise to discuss this is that many people in the coalition are concerned about family life. Over the weekend an article appeared in the `Focus' section of the Weekend Australian entitled `The disappearing family'. Several articles looking at families, family values and so on have been appearing in newspapers around Australia.

I noticed that today in the parliament a dorothy dixer was put to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin), through which the minister wanted to defend the government's social welfare policies. No doubt the minister was stunned by what was written by people in the Weekend Australian. The commentary which accompanies the article states:
Social engineering in Australia is a mishmash, with conflicting goals, muddy rationales and perverse outcomes.
But the social system does not reward or encourage marriage, sometimes undermines the nuclear family, and often erodes the work ethic and keeps people on welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess the minister was really stunned by the fact that the system is now being criticised by various people in the media. It is no wonder that the minister is getting up in the House defending its social security policy and families.

PARA.TAB: The interesting point about the article, which was under the heading `The disappearing family', is that the family which it talks about is not actually disappearing. While you find some commentators saying that the family is disappearing, it is interesting to look into the figures to find out exactly what they mean. The commentators talk about the normal family, the traditional family or the nuclear family. However, when you pin it down to a definition, they are actually talking about the normal or traditional family as being married people with two children. Now that is about 15 to 20 per cent of the population.

The commentators do not regard the traditional normal family as a couple with no children. They do not regard a married couple with one child as being traditional or normal. They do not regard a married couple with three children as being normal or traditional. They do not regard a married couple with four or more children as being normal or traditional. They do not regard a married couple whose children have grown up and left home as being normal or traditional. They do not regard brothers and sisters living together—they may not have married—as being the normal or traditional family. If you have your grandparents living with you, you are not a normal, traditional or nuclear family. And so it goes on. This is just an absolute nonsense.

Another very interesting factor is that, even though we hear about the high divorce rates—which probably is true, depending on your view of these matters; it certainly has increased in Australia—the fact is that 83 per cent of all first marriages are still intact in Australia. Eighty-three per cent really is a very high figure. In many respects I think we can dispel the idea that people are giving up living in family structures, because they are not. They are continuing to live in those structures although there may be fracturing at the edges of it. Certainly, there has been an increase in single parent families and so on—we know the hardships which they go through—but the debate is really about whether public policy in this country should encourage families, marriage and stable relationships. I believe it should because marriage is very important to the nurturing processes of our young people. I believe that if you have strong families, you have a strong nation; if you have weak families, you are going to have a nation which is also weak. The feature article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Compared with 30 years ago, it is easier for women to raise children without men, and for men to escape the burdens of fatherhood.

PARA.TAB: The weakening of that link has hurt children. Multi-generational studies—

SPEECH.PARA: and this is what is interesting—

in Sweden, Britain and America all seem to show that, compared with their peers of the same economic class, children in lone-parent families do less well in school, get into trouble more often and have more emotional and health problems. They are also more likely to become single parents themselves.

What is emerging from empirical evidence right around the world—it is not being said by members of the coalition or of the Labor Party—and what we have to address as a country is that children who are not nurtured in secure family situations with a male and a female role model for them are creating difficulties within the country. This is the concern.

PARA.TAB: Can we as a nation try to put together policies which underpin family life and actually encourage family life more strongly than what we are doing today? I believe we can. It is interesting to point out that, on 22 August in the Australian, we also had Bettina Arndt making the comment that the evidence suggests that a good divorce is not better for children than a bad marriage. Again, she is referring to the empirical evidence coming through from our universities, our social scientists and so on. We are now challenging the last 20 years of generally held views.

I know that, in many respects, it is politically incorrect to argue this way in the parliament. But what is coming through from our social scientists in the United Kingdom, Europe, Canada and the United States—I have been to Israel and talked to people there as well—is that, as far as government policy is concerned, there has to be an underpinning of the importance of marriage and stability in that relationship if we are going to nurture our children and give them the best start in life.

There are many studies that we can look at, including studies here in Australia, which outline just how important that stable relationship is. I do not have time to go through all of those studies. I will just give one example. In 1992 there was a study conducted of 409 young people in Western Australia's Longmore Remand and Detention Centre. It showed that only 19.6 per cent of those children lived with both parents and 75 per cent did not live with their fathers. The study showed that juvenile destructive behaviour was closely related to family experience. In other words, if we can hold our families together we are going to have less crime. Governments now must make sure that there is more money involved in parenting courses and marriage preparation courses. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Victorians continue to be burdened by a state Liberal government which now leads the list as the biggest taxing and the biggest spending state government in the Commonwealth. I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) on the manner in which he has exposed in this place the enormous burdens that the Kennett government has put on ordinary working families. The Kennett Liberal government is really one with a warped sense of priorities. It displays a great concern for waiting lists at gaming tables but it does not show much concern for the waiting lists of the sick in our hospitals, and in that I include the Geelong hospital.

PARA.TAB: While it slashes funding to kindergartens, it spends millions of dollars on consultants. While it slashes funding to hospitals, the Premier gallivants around the world like no other Premier in Victoria's postwar history. This Premier has been overseas once every three months since he came into power. That is more than any Premier in any Labor state government in the postwar period. The government over which he presides has spent more money on consultants in the last two years than any state Labor government since the Second World War.

Since 1992 we have observed some very disturbing features of the processes of government in the state of Victoria, and I want to pick up some of those issues in this grievance debate tonight. Since 1992 and the election of the Kennett Liberal government we have seen a massive assault on Victorian families. We have observed massive increases in taxes and charges, which have brought an additional burden to Victorian households of something in the region of $1,500. That particular burden has been matched by a reduction in essential services. Along with that, the industrial relations policy, which has been endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) here in this parliament, who is a great sympathiser of Jeff Kennett, has seen many working families have their wages and conditions slashed.

More insidiously, there has been an introduction of a climate of fear and intimidation to workplaces in Victoria. The approach that has been taken at the federal level by the Labor Party in government contrasts very sharply with the intimidation, fear and confrontation which has accompanied the industrial relations system that has been introduced by the Kennett government. Perhaps even more insidiously, we have seen a massive assault on the rights and liberties of Victorians.

We have seen in legislation financial disincentives for individuals to pursue their legitimate rights and claims under that legislation. We have seen a curtailment of widespread rights to appeal in Victorian legislation. I had a conversation with a member of the legal fraternity recently who came to me absolutely outraged. He was a rather conservative gentleman, quite upstanding in his local community, and he had a documented list of the legislation that had been passed by the Victorian parliament under the Kennett government which had made this massive assault on the liberties and the rights of Victorians.

It does not end there. When we look at the processes of government in Victoria, the democratic structures that have been built up over time in this great state, we see the Kennett government has effectively removed a structure of government with municipal amalgamations with the appointments of commissars—commissioners, as they are called by the government, but by the people they are called commissars.

We have seen a centralisation of power in Spring Street with the strata of democratically elected local government replaced by appointed commissioners beholden to the central government in Spring Street. This is one of the grossest violations of democratic processes and procedures in this country and in the history of federation. It probably rivals the notorious assaults on liberties that was introduced by the Bjelke-Petersen government in Queensland. But we have seen in Victoria the removal of a strata of government, a replacement of democratically elected representatives by commissioners beholden to the central government at Spring Street.

As far as working families are concerned, their living standards have been grossly assaulted by this government. It is estimated that Geelong families are now paying in the region of $1,500 in extra taxes and charges. Until recently, we had the $100 home tax that the Kennett government introduced. We have had an increase in the petrol levy of three per cent, in kindergarten fees, in gas costs, in electricity costs, in motor registration and insurance and the introduction of school fees at many state schools.

In addition to this assault on working families, we have seen the wages of some workers severely reduced because of the industrial relations policies of the government in Victoria. All this has meant that the income to businesses has declined as people have less to spend. Put on this the overlay of the advent of gambling in Geelong and in the state of Victoria, many small businesses now are feeling a real pinch.

In going to specific areas and in looking at the Kennett government's record on education, we observe an increase in class sizes, poor school cleaning and maintenance, reduced access to integration programs, the closure of many schools, reduced careers counselling services and increased fees for parents. Among teachers there is poor morale. There has been a loss of remedial maths and English teachers and a reduction in student welfare counselling resources. The Kennett government's legacy to the people of Victoria has been a deliberate run-down of the educational infrastructure of the state, a teaching profession that is beset by reduced morale and students who are suffering reduced opportunities.

In the area of health, I ought to impress upon this House the importance of the Geelong hospital as a regional service centre. It has been one of the most efficient hospitals in the state but Kennett cutbacks have put the financial viability of the hospital in jeopardy. Public confidence in the hospital recently was called into question with revelations of extreme financial difficulties at that institution.

Over 300 hospital jobs have been cut, the budget cuts have been in the order of 18 per cent to 23 per cent, and 50 beds have been closed. We have seen increases in waiting lists, early discharges of patients, linen and bedding shortages, poor staff morale, overworked staff with no end to their workload in sight, poor heating at the hospital and, of course, a commensurate increase in the number of voluntary workers who are being called in to assist the hospital.

As far as rail transport is concerned, we are now beginning to reap the whirlwind of massive cutbacks in that state in the transport sector. As far as the port of Geelong is concerned, the Kennett government is hell-bent on selling the port of Geelong to private interests. This port has recently clocked up some very good profits. It has a high level of reserves. It is a community asset that ought to stay in public hands, but we all know that the ideologues at Spring Street are hell-bent on selling this very important community asset to the city. I could go on at length but there will be a day of reckoning in the Geelong region for this government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said about the issue of youth unemployment in recent times. It is an issue of great concern to politicians on both sides of this House and one which all political leaders cannot choose to ignore or to hide. Today, I want to highlight the problems of youth unemployment in regional electorates like my own and to put forward some positive suggestions about the way in which it might be tackled.

PARA.TAB: The August 1995 regional unemployment rate for teenagers—that is, 15- to 19-year-olds—in the Wide Bay-Burnett area of Queensland was 42.2 per cent. That takes in my home town of Bundaberg and the southern half of my electorate. At other times, it has been almost as high in the northern part. That means that more than one-third of the young people between the ages of 15 and 19 living in my electorate are looking for a job and cannot find one. This is well above the Queensland average of 20.6 per cent. As unpalatable as this figure might seem, it reflects the great difficulties being faced by young people living in regional Australia and trying to enter the work force.

Two weeks ago the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was in Bundaberg selling the virtues of Working Nation. With a general unemployment rate of 14.9 per cent in the Wide Bay-Burnett region and 6,000 people in Bundaberg and a further 2,000 people in the Gladstone area receiving unemployment benefits, the minister was keen to talk up the job prospects and advantages of Working Nation.

This is not inappropriate. I recognise it is the responsibility of the government of the day to provide unemployment and training programs. While I have reservations about some, I actively promote others. We must all promote and encourage opportunities for job growth and for skilling the Australian work force. The acid test of these programs is how many real and sustainable jobs exist at the end of the government subsidised period.

In fact, the minister laid the challenge to create 5,000 new jobs in Bundaberg by the end of the year. It sounds a bit like an election promise, does it not? Nevertheless, I will be the first to congratulate the minister if this can be achieved. But to make this challenge cynically with an election in mind will carry with it its own rewards, especially in a region with high interstate migration and population growth, a major building industry and industry supply slump, a crippling drought and a parlous lack of government infrastructure spending in the region.

On the same day in my electorate, the employment minister opened the new premises of one of Australia's most progressive group training companies, BACAS. As a founding member of the board of that organisation, I well understand the importance of structured training and apprentices.

The recent report on group training by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training described group training as one of Australia's best kept employment secrets. I for one believe the government should continue to fund and support core activities of these organisations which are providing a valuable role in coordinating and targeting training in our ever changing workplace.

This in turn is improving the job prospects of many young Australians. One of the great successes of group training has been the placement of many of its clients. If you like, it meets that acid test. BACAS currently has 200 young apprentices and trainees on its books—an achievement we are quite proud of.

On the day following the minister's visit to my electorate, the shadow minister for youth affairs, Senator Campbell, and the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) visited Bundaberg as part of the coalition's national youth road tour. We hosted a forum at the Bundaberg campus of the Central Queensland University at which about 40 young people, students and youth workers, attended to share their views on matters of concern to youth in our part of Australia. These included youth crisis accommodation, the increasing incidence of sexual abuse amongst teenagers, public transport and youth unemployment.

On the issue of youth unemployment, when the minister's exhortation of the previous day to create 5,000 jobs in Bundaberg was raised—it was raised in quite a benign way—it was met with peals of cynical laugher from the audience. Such was the commentary of youth.

Some of the employment concerns that had been raised included the lack of real full-time job opportunities, even after a training program; the frustration with accessing certain labour market programs—some lamented the fact that they had to be out of work for 18 months to access them; the lack of part-time employment, especially for students looking to supplement Austudy payments; the criticism of employers for discriminating against young people on the basis of age—it is cheaper to employ a 14- or 15-year-old than an 18-year-old; the axing of the JPET program for homeless youth in Bundaberg and leaving those people to the whims of the already overloaded DEET case management regime. They were just a few of the comments made by young people at the youth forum.

I became despondent when one of the critics of the coalition youth forum was the National Union of Students, which, as we all know, has become an excellent mouthpiece for the ALP. Rather than support or encourage the process that enabled greater student input into the policy development program, the NUS saw it simply as an opportunity to make a political attack on the coalition—I might add that they were not at the forum; this was all in the media afterwards—everything from the champagne socialist joke to the clothes we supposedly wore, and they even got down to the 1993 youth wage.

I think it is unfortunate that the NUS could not forget its own political connections and for once think about advancing the plight of the people that it claims to represent—namely, the students. Here was an opportunity for students throughout Australia to tell a group of politicians what they really felt about issues that affected them directly. They certainly did that at the Bundaberg forum, which was opened by the vice president of the local student council, presumably a NUS member. There was very little liaison between the national body and the local body in this exercise.

Earlier that week the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the shadow cabinet were my guests in Gladstone. While in the harbour city, Mr Howard and shadow education minister, Senator Hill, met with representatives of the Central Queensland University Student Union from both Gladstone and Rockhampton. This was in stark contrast to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) snapping at students in Adelaide to get a job. It seems the NUS is happy to roll over and have its tummy scratched by the government rather than face up to some of the real issues that concern its members.

In the recent state election there was a letter in one of my local newspapers from a so-called student representative claiming that they had no choice but to vote for Labor. What a cop-out. Have they forgotten about the meddling with HECS and Austudy?

Despite the low student population ratio in central Queensland, which is about 60 per cent, the region continues to be under-funded in terms of real university places. Even with the budget allocation of 4,200 new places for Queensland institutions over the next three years, Central Queensland University does not get its fair share. In fact, our allocation is a mere 420 extra places for 1996-97, of which 100 were previously announced by the then minister, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley).

So, in essence, CQU was allocated 320 new places out of this year's budget which, when you spread them over five campuses over two years, amounts to very little going into each campus and falls well short of expectations. While these university places are principally allocated to areas of high population growth, I believe there should also be a special preference given to areas with high unemployment. This would have the benefit of lifting the skills in the region as well as increasing employment opportunities for the young people affected.

As the minister for employment correctly stated recently, youth unemployment ultimately affects all of us, not just this generation but future generations of Australians as well. Youth unemployment is by no means a simple problem. Rather, it is a complex problem that requires a range of responses, some of which I have tried to outline today. Ultimately, the key to sustainable job creation is greater economic growth, appropriate spending on infrastructure, which is abysmally lacking in central Queensland, and micro-economic and taxation reform to enable businesses to expand and to take on more staff. These mainstream economic reforms, together with structured and targeted training, will improve the outlook of many young Australians.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate today to take the opportunity to once again place concerns before this parliament relating to a very important issue within my electorate: the Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek. This is a subject which I have raised in debate on the floor of this parliament time and time again. I raise this issue again today because of the continuing misapprehensions circulating in my area over Sydney West airport and the malicious glee that certain individuals now seem to have in stoking them into the fears that some people have now sadly begun entertaining.

PARA.TAB: The people of south-western Sydney are no more an ungrateful community than any other part of Australia. They have the same willingness to applaud government when it does something smart, just as they will exercise their right to complain when an issue is perhaps not being dealt with as they would like. The people of south-western Sydney want more jobs, an improved transport infrastructure, and all the other benefits that will flow on from Badgerys Creek, but before that they want answers—answers which this government must provide.

At the moment, we are faced with two major questions which my constituents, and those in my colleague's electorates nearby, want addressed. How will the flight paths at the airport, when they are determined, affect those individuals, and why is the airport currently intended to operate on a 24-hour basis? I have never seen the need for an airport to operate on a 24-hour basis. As I have said before in this House, if Kingsford Smith airport can manage to operate at a profit with a night-time curfew, then surely any new airport to be built in Sydney's west can do so just as well.

The people surrounding Badgerys Creek have exactly the same desires for night-time peace and quiet as those in the inner city. Surely they should be treated with the same respect and consideration. Yet, while we in the government are doing our best to allay concern in the community, and while we have continually said that issues such as the airport's flight paths will only be determined after extensive independent analysis and community consultations, we still have elements—disreputable, malicious elements—who choose to continue spreading misinformation for their own self gain. I believe that if we in the Labor Party are indeed the `true believers', then those people who are spreading these rumours are the `true deceivers'.

We have certain individuals within my electorate, I kid you not, who are cheating the people of south-western Sydney into thinking that somehow a vote against Labor in any upcoming federal election would mean a step towards halting all airport proceedings: not a delay, not a pause, not a cessation of work, but a complete and unadulterated halt. The people who are spreading these untruths have become very prominent in our communities for this fact alone. Some of them have even gained seats on our councils in the recent local government elections. Perhaps these people have been talking about it so much that they have even fooled themselves into believing that such an eventuality could manifest itself. Well, I think it is time that I once again put them straight.

Their pipedreams are not based on fact. The Sydney West airport cannot and will not be stopped. It is up to us to make sure that when it does start being built it is developed thoughtfully and in consideration of the people of south-western Sydney. That is what this government is doing.

On the other hand, a federal coalition government means the fast-tracking of Badgerys Creek without consultation: no delays for them, no pauses and certainly no involvement of the community. For the coalition, the people in Sydney's west are, and always have been, used as `fall guys'. When the coalition's traditional voters on the north shore and the eastern suburbs start getting upset over an issue, more often than not Sydney's west is pointed out as a useful target for any undesirable development. This will occur when and if the coalition ever comes into power. This is not going to happen again.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), a person I have quoted many times on this subject to highlight the opposition's policies in this area, was clear in his intentions over Badgerys Creek in recent conversation with the mayor of Marrickville, Barry Cotter. Mr Howard told Mr Cotter that the coalition supported `the fast-tracking of Badgerys Creek'.

There is no room for any sort of different interpretation of a comment like that. The Leader of the Opposition's intention is clear—crystal clear: no new environmental impact statement, not even a supplementary EIS, to which this government has committed itself. Mr Howard stated that the opposition will rush at developing Badgerys Creek like a bull at a gate if the coalition wins the election; not for the sake of the people of south-western Sydney, and not for their economic or social benefits, but for those of his blue-ribbon constituents.

The Leader of the Opposition is concerned that the present government is not moving fast enough. In July he wrote that the Labor government has `demonstrated a clear lack of commitment to this particular project'. I find that puzzling, particularly when one reads the budget papers and finds that an extra $762 million is intended for allocation to the project. If that is an example of lack of commitment, I would like to know what is commitment.

I also believe that what the Leader of the Opposition sees as a `lack of commitment' is actually the government's unwillingness to condemn the people of Sydney's greater west to an `airport hell' as the Sydney Morning Herald so colourfully put it recently. We want to make sure that it is done correctly. We are not about to make knee-jerk decisions to make life easier for a few of those silvertails in the electorate of the member for Bennelong, and in so doing punish the people in Sydney's west. We are approaching this project with forthrightness based on solid community consultation.

The Leader of the Opposition has even had a letter published in one of our local newspapers, not addressing the issues that would interest them about Badgerys Creek—because we all know where he stands on that—but about the `airport noise crisis', as he put it, at Mascot. He says that the present government has `turned a deaf ear' to the people of the inner city. This remark was published in a paper in my electorate.

Far from it!. The government is about sharing the load and that is why Badgerys Creek is being built: to act as a supplementary airport to Mascot. The Leader of the Opposition wants to fast-track Sydney West airport and he wants it operating at an international capacity as soon as possible. He has even said that he will force airlines to base themselves at Badgerys Creek to guarantee its viability. He does not want to balance the operations between the two Sydney airports; he wants the people of Sydney's west to bear the heavier burden, just as all coalition governments have desired in the past.

But it is not just the Leader of the Opposition and his party who are working to deceive the people of south-western Sydney. Certain elements in Sydney's inner city are also involved. These people continue to make the trip out to our areas, gather at our local airport meetings and then attempt to sabotage what is normally a level-headed exchange of concerns and information. On the one hand, these people—professional spoilers and stirrers, as I like to refer to them—have been campaigning vociferously not only to have Mascot's third runway shut down, but to have the entire airport's operation halted as soon as Badgerys Creek begins running. Then they have the gall—and I believe hypocrisy—to come to our meetings and attempt to coach members of our community on how to stop Sydney West airport going ahead. Talk about two facedness and deceit!

The people of Sydney's west deserve much better than this. The concerns of members of our community are genuine and the federal Labor government must treat them as genuine. That is why the Department of Transport, in conjunction with the Federal Airports Corporation, has today opened to the public an information centre on the airport's intended site to help alleviate any worries and to give answers to questions raised by the population at large.

Information at that centre, situated on Badgerys Creek Road, will be updated regularly and experts will be on hand seven days a week to talk to members of the community about anything concerning the airport. There are even plans to organise a mobile centre which will tour the popular shopping areas in the region giving out information and working to alleviate any worries that may exist.

We want to get Sydney West airport right. We must get Sydney West airport right. We are working to cut through the clouds of rumour circulated by people who either refuse to hear our words or who are no longer capable of sitting down and looking at the facts objectively. As the federal member for Prospect, I have raised—and will continue to raise—the concerns of my constituents over the flight paths for Sydney West airport and the proposed no curfew policy. I am committed to making sure that the decisions the government makes are taken with the best interests of the people of Sydney's west at heart. I can assure my community that I will continue to pursue their concerns until we have the answers that we want.

Most importantly, I will not shirk from standing in this House again and again to expose the hypocrisy of certain individuals—those `would-be leaders of our community'—whose sole reason seems to be choosing Sydney West airport as a topic of debate not only to promote themselves but for their own self gain. I despise them for their actions. I condemn them for the fear that they have generated among the people in the electorate who ask where and why Sydney West airport is going to be developed. These are normal questions being raised by individuals. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity today to speak in this place about an issue which has outraged many people in my electorate. On 14 June, the French government announced that it would resume testing nuclear weapons at Mururoa Atoll, bringing to an end the moratorium that had been observed since 1992. As June drew to a close, letters and calls opposing the resumption of testing continued to flood into my office. The message was clear: stop the bomb. Opposition to French nuclear testing is well-founded. The tests have the potential to release radioactive waste into the surrounding environment, they are an exercise in colonialism and they have the potential to weaken international commitment to the treaties controlling the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

PARA.TAB: In late June, I began circulating a petition opposing nuclear testing in our region. In early August, my petition was presented to the French ambassador. It contained nearly 10,000 signatures from the people of Adelaide. Throughout July, the French government had remained unmoved by international opposition to plans to explode nuclear weapons under the lagoon at Mururoa Atoll. Stronger action was needed.

When speaking to people who had signed the petition, so many inquired, `Will this do any good?' or `What else can be done?' As a mother concerned for my children's future and the future of their generation, and indeed determined to see that in fact something else could be done, I joined the group of Australian parliamentarians who had decided to travel to Papeete to protest against the French nuclear testing. This group came to be known as—and in fact carried a banner proclaiming the name—Australian Parliamentarians for the Pacific. The group of 35 came from all parties from both the federal parliament and also state parliaments around Australia.

We arrived in Papeete at 3 a.m. on the morning of 2 September. At 9 a.m. on the same day we gathered at a central point with parliamentarians from Italy, Brazil, the United States, Japan, Germany, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Ireland, Austria and New Zealand. We joined with international delegations and local people to march over a four-kilometre stretch along local streets to the French High Commission. The temperature was in line with a very hot Aussie summer day, but with 85 per cent humidity thrown in. But, complete with wide hats, drinks, sunscreen, banners and Australian flags, we covered the distance in good humour. It was estimated there were several hundred international participants and, in all, about 4,000 people taking part. I was particularly touched by the warm reception given to us by those who stood by the roadside or who came out of their homes as we passed.

While not boasting any real talent, we did sing Advance Australia Fair, Waltzing Matilda and a hastily-worded song to the tune of Frere Jacques which we even managed to sing in parts. It went something like this: `Jacques Chirac, Jacques Chirac; you are sleeping, you are sleeping; warning bells are ringing, warning bells are ringing; stop your bomb, stop your bomb.' I think John Ryan from the New South Wales parliament can take most credit for this number. The protest march was very peaceful, and I was later told that members of the media contingent filming from a bridge as we came down the road confessed to `not having a dry eye amongst them'.

Following the march—and, I have to say, after some fairly intense negotiations—I managed with some of my colleagues to personally deliver hundreds of letters of protest to the French High Commissioner. Throughout the march I had carried letters from hundreds of school children from Adelaide as well as letters from Archbishop Faulkner, Archbishop George, the Council of Ex-Servicewomen of South Australia and the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. At a later rally I was able to read from John Howard's letter, which I now put on the parliamentary record:

SPEECH.PARA: To the People and Nations of the South Pacific.
The decision by the French government to resume nuclear testing on Mururoa Atoll is one that has outraged Australian people.

As the leader of the Federal Coalition which represents a large number of these people in our parliament, I am writing to express support for your efforts to force the French government to abandon testing at Mururoa.
The South Pacific is not a vast expanse of empty ocean in which distant nations can undertake the activities that are too dangerous or unpopular to undertake in their own back yards.

It is your home, the place from which you derive your livelihood and your culture and the French government's determination to proceed with testing at Mururoa Atoll despite your opposition must be loudly condemned.

The decision to resume nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific is also contrary to the spirit of the recent Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review and Extension Conference and undermines attempts to finalise the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
Both of these Treaties are crucial elements of an emerging nuclear weapons control regime and again, the French government must be condemned for jeopardising this regime.
As a nation on the rim of the Pacific, we are your neighbours and it is in this spirit that members of the Liberal Party have travelled to Papeete.
My federal parliamentary colleague, Trish Worth, is the spokesperson for these members and I have asked her to present this letter of support to you.
The Federal Coalition will continue to do all in its power to influence the French government to abandon its decision to explode nuclear weapons at Mururoa Atoll.
Yours sincerely,
John Howard,
Leader of the Opposition.

The following two days were taken up by negotiations to establish an international network to continue the protest that we had begun and by meeting with residents, including the Archbishop of Papeete. I am hopeful that the international network will work well.

PARA.TAB: While there was some discussion as to what role Oscar Temaru should have in this network, it was finally resolved that he should be interim chairman for the next year and that Senator Bruce Childs should be secretary. I commend Senator Childs for the role he played in these negotiations. The network is to be known as Parliamentarians for a Nuclear-Weapons-Free World, and it adopted the following as its charter:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be a network of Parliamentarians co-operating on a continuing basis as a network to exchange information and plan action including meetings from time to time to achieve a primary purpose of the cessation of all nuclear tests and the dismantling of all nuclear weapons.
To achieve the above purposes Parliamentarians will use all the existing political and parliamentary associations including the IPU and the UN in addition to the initiatives in their own Parliaments.

We left Papeete in the early hours of Tuesday, 5 September, only to find as we left the plane in Sydney that the French government had exploded its first bomb. This was devastating news, as was the television coverage of the riots in Papeete. It had seemed such a peaceful place. I had walked alone and unafraid in streets that I then saw ablaze. Isolated by international opinion and protest, President Chirac has somehow managed to blame others and, in particular, Australia and New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: When I first began campaigning against the decision to resume nuclear testing in our region, it was fashionable among cynics to suggest that the efforts of people such as myself would inevitably be in vain. In retrospect, I think the cynics have been proven wrong. Certainly the French government has already exploded one nuclear weapon too many. However, there is evidence that France will not proceed with the full eight tests as initially planned, and this is a step in the right direction.

I believe the international anger that has been brought to bear on France has shown that nations, even nuclear powers, will be held accountable for their actions by the international community of which they are a part. The message that has been sent loudly and clearly, not only to France but also to the other nuclear powers, is that the non-nuclear nations—among which Australia numbers—are deadly serious about seeing the implementation of a set of international treaties to control the proliferation of nuclear weapons.

The integrity of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and its ability to thwart the emergence of new nuclear powers is entirely dependent on the existing nuclear powers observing their side of the bargain—that is, showing `utmost restraint' in regard to the development of their nuclear capacities. The cessation of testing of nuclear weapons is the foundation of this `restraint'. France's belief that it could, with impunity, conduct testing as a prelude to signing a comprehensive test ban treaty has been shown to be completely misguided and, in the process, the commitment of the other nuclear powers to a comprehensive test ban treaty has been strengthened.

TALKER.NAME: Ms CRAWFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The visit today by the students of Boonah State High School causes me to rise to my feet on a grievance. The drought in their part of Boonah Shire, which other members of this House may not realise, is quite severe. Boonah Shire has been affected by drought for the past four years, and indeed its major water supply, Moogerah Dam, is totally dry. Irrigation has been cut to all farms in the area. This has led to very substantial problems, particularly given that the area is noted for the growing of potatoes, carrots and other small crops, and for its horticulture. Also, it is quite a sizeable pig producer, and the cost of grain in the area has in fact meant that pig production has been depleted.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the problems were expounded on a visit to the area by Senator Bob Collins when he met with a range of growers. People were very grateful for the fact that this government has spent $1 billion to date on drought relief. While people are grateful for the money and recognise that they would not have survived without it, the only real answer is rain. Over the weekend we saw parts of Sydney and other places receiving rain, and it is then we realised the very serious social problems that drought brings with it: industries are diminished and the work which can realistically be done in the community is brought to a halt.

However, there was a bright light through the week at Boonah when the machine shop at the state high school was opened. This is something the community has wanted for a very long time. It provides a range of opportunities, not just for the young people in the school but also for the community at large, to participate in the development of skills—
