DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Johns:
That the bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Mr Reith had moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "whilst not opposing the provisions of the bill and whilst recognising that this bill provides some improvement to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, the House is of the opinion that, even as amended, the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act remain a disincentive to job creation, that they impose a very heavy burden on business, particularly on small business, and that they were enacted without proper prior consultation".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Industrial Relations and other Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and oppose the amendment moved by the member for Flinders (Mr Reith). This bill, in substance, provides for application for relief under the unfair dismissal provisions to be heard by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is the objective of the legislation to make these unfair dismissal provisions simpler and more effective.

PARA.TAB: In short, the summary of the bill is that all applications will commence in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission rather than in the Industrial Relations Court; that the option of binding arbitration by the commission will be available where parties agree; that the unfair dismissal provisions of the act will not apply where there is an alternative available under another law that satisfies the requirement of the ILO's termination of employment convention; and that the Industrial Relations Court will be required to consider all the circumstances of the case in deciding what remedy, if any, should be given. They are, in effect, the substantive provisions that relate to unfair dismissal.

The key to the law of unfair dismissal is getting the balance right, and the government believes it has got the balance right on this occasion. That view is supported by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which makes this positive comment on the bill:

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome this bill, which implements the federal government's recent commitment to amend procedural fairness laws, to specifically recognise voluntary arbitration by the Industrial Relations Commission in the act, to provide that applications are made to the commission, not the court, and to preserve the operation of the more realistic state systems.
The bill has also been welcomed by the MTIA, the Metal Trades Industry Association, and the ACTU. So some of the major players in this area are supportive of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Unfair dismissal and industrial relations bring to mind my own state of Western Australia and some of the unfair dismissals that have occurred there in recent times—the unfair dismissal of the member for Moore, Mr Filing, from his endorsement and the unfair dismissal of the member for Curtin, Mr Rocher, from his endorsement. There is clearly a link between the unfairness of their dismissals, the industrial relations legislation of the Western Australian government and the industrial relations aspirations of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the federal opposition.

It is important to go through a forensic study of those industrial relations laws, including unfair dismissal laws, which the Leader of the Opposition has committed himself to. I noticed a few weeks ago in the parliament the Leader of the Opposition doing his level best to extricate himself from the handcuff that he had attached himself to so far as the Western Australian government's industrial relations legislation is concerned.

It is interesting to go through a bit of forensic analysis of what the Leader of the Opposition has committed himself to, and when he committed himself. In the Australian of 20 June, Alan Wood, in an article entitled `West's IR reforms a time bomb for Howard', makes the following comments:

If John Howard thinks the worst of his political problems in Western Australia are now behind him, he had better think again. The West Australian Minister for Labour Relations, Graham Kierath, has lit the fuse on a time bomb that could blow up in Howard's face . . .

The explosive is in the form of proposed amendments to Western Australia's industrial relations legislation, in particular amendments aimed at the operation of unions, which Kierath calls his "second wave" of industrial reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: In 1995, the focus is likely to shift to the west, with . . . the message "vote Liberal federally and this is what they will do to you".

SPEECH.PARA: He also says that from an analysis of the Western Australian industrial relations legislation it seems that it is likely and destined to play a key role in the forthcoming federal election campaign, due in the next six months or so. We have seen Mr Howard commit himself to those industrial relations laws of Western Australia. The West Australian of Saturday, 29 July said `Howard: WA is our model'.

PARA.TAB: Before I continue on in that guise, it is interesting to see some analysis of the unfair dismissal provisions of the Western Australian legislation contained in the current legislation in place in Western Australia. That legislation is made up of two pieces of legislation—the Workplace Agreements Act and the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act.

An analysis by a couple of well-known QCs in Western Australia of those two pieces of legislation and their effect is worth taking some note of. Mr Rene Le Miere QC and Mr Ian Viner QC—a former Liberal member for Stirling in this place—have given a joint study of this legislation. In the course of their study, they say:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation does not protect prospective employees who wish to be employed pursuant to an award rather than a workplace agreement in circumstances where the prospective employer requires that they enter into a workplace agreement as a precondition to employment.

The legislation does not protect employees who have entered into workplace agreements in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept less favourable terms and conditions of employment in a new workplace agreement.
In other words, you get the sack if you disagree. The opinion goes on to say:

The legislation does not protect employees in circumstances where their employer threatens to dismiss them from their employment by notice, in accordance with their contract of employment, for the purpose of compelling them to accept the terms and conditions of employment in a workplace agreement proposed by the employer, except in the situation where an employer has not previously entered into a workplace agreement. Whether the employee is actually protected will depend upon the particular circumstances.
The opinion concludes:

The legislation does not protect employees if their employer dismisses all its work force by notice, advertises their jobs and then employs only those persons, including the former employees, who are willing to enter into a workplace agreement on the terms and conditions specified by the employer.

You can see the harsh and pernicious terms that apply in the existing legislation in Western Australia—what is known as the `first wave' of the state government's legislation. As will become clear, that is the precise policy which the federal opposition leader has committed himself to.

PARA.TAB: To get some indication as to how pieces of Western Australian legislation have been received, the West Australian of Wednesday, 21 June, under the heading `Kierath plans flawed', says:

SPEECH.PARA: Major aspects of the Court Government's proposed second wave of industrial legislation are provocative and unworkable, according to the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

PARA.TAB: Labour Relations Minister Graham Kierath's plans would bring the community pain in exchange for marginal benefits, chamber labour relations director Brendan McCarthy said yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: A quote from Mr McCarthy reads:

PARA.TAB: "Why legislate knowing something is not going to work? Because it is unworkable and because it impractical, it would be bad legislation and we are opposed to that," Mr McCarthy said.

SPEECH.PARA: That concerns the second wave. We have heard the learned opinion of two QCs, including Mr Viner, on some aspects of the first wave of legislation, and we have heard the views of the chamber of commence on the proposed second wave. An editorial in the West Australian on the following day, Thursday, 22 June, says:

It should be a clear signal to him to think again for the sake of industrial stability when both the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Trades and Labor Council denounce his legislative proposals as unworkable.

PARA.TAB: But Mr Kierath has shown a hidebound resistance to calls for change to controversial parts of his so-called second wave of industrial legislation, despite the blunt rejection of them by the most affected parties.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The community will not support laws that are unfairly one-sided in their application—or appear to be based on vindictiveness rather than need—regardless of whether unions strike over them.

SPEECH.PARA: So the view of the second wave of legislation in the editorial of the West Australian is not unlike those of the chamber of commerce—unfairly one-sided and appearing to be based on vindictiveness.

PARA.TAB: So with all this out in the public arena in June of this year, we find that the Leader of the Opposition visited Western Australia in July of this year. In the West Australian of Saturday, 29 July 1995 we find the big story which handcuffs the federal opposition to the Western Australian industrial relations legislation and proposals—`Howard: WA is our model'. The story says:

SPEECH.PARA: A Federal coalition government would mirror the industrial relations policies implemented by the Court Government in Western Australia, Federal Opposition Leader, John Howard, said yesterday.

PARA.TAB: "I would like to see throughout Australia an industrial relations system that is largely similar to what the coalition Government has implemented in Western Australia," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to refer to a comment:
We are pleased that the Federal (coalition's) industrial relations policy will be modelled on what we have successfully implemented here.
That is, of course, a quote from the Western Australian Premier, Richard Court.

PARA.TAB: So we have the handcuff firmly applied. Just in case members opposite might think that the West Australian got it wrong, in the Western Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry bulletin of August 1995 there is an article which says that Mr Howard praised the industrial relations policies instituted by the WA Liberal government and promised to develop a similar environment at the federal level.

With his eyes open and in full knowledge and understanding—we assume—of the first wave of legislation and the proposed second wave, the Leader of the Opposition has handcuffed himself and the opposition to the Western Australian model of industrial relations legislation. In August this year in an article in the Australian we find further developments in the forensic expose. The article by Nigel Wilson states:

Western Australia's industrial relations laws—touted by the federal Opposition leader, Mr Howard, as the template for a federal Coalition government's workplace reforms—are already regarded as the most draconian in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: The West Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has warned the Government Mr Kierath's proposed changes would produce "very marginal gains" and are "threatening and provocative".

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wilson's article goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard told a lunch in Perth last month the State's industrial relations laws were the model for the federal Coalition and that he believed a federal Coalition government could adapt them so that up to 79 per cent of Australia's industrial relations activities would be covered from the national capital.

In the audience were chamber executives who, while endorsing the existing WA industrial laws, have pointed out that Mr Kierath's proposed changes could damage both local business and Australia's international reputation.

SPEECH.PARA: There we find over a period of almost three months—June, July and August of this year—the federal Leader of the Opposition clearly committing himself, and it being perceived that way by people in Western Australia including the Chamber of Commerce, to that particular model and regime of industrial relations legislation. This is picked up again in the West Australian on 17 August under the heading, `Bosses question industry reforms', in a story which says:
WA industry leaders have raised concerns about Labor Relations Minister Graham Kierath's planned industrial reforms with the Federal coalition.

PARA.TAB: WA company chiefs . . . told Federal Opposition industrial relations spokesman Peter Reith at a meeting in Perth last week . . . about the State Government's proposed reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: The story goes on:
Mr Reith has refused to comment on the effect the proposed law could have—
The article continues:

PARA.TAB: The pressure on Mr Kierath to reconsider some of his plans continued this week, with the revelation that the WA Chamber of Mines and Energy and the Australian Mines and Metals Association had written to him outlining their concerns about the proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on, interestingly, to report Mr Kierath as saying that he rejected speculation that the federal coalition was pressuring him to delay or change his industrial plans, saying he outlined his proposals to federal opposition leader John Howard when he was in Perth a few weeks ago. Mr Kierath said that Mr Howard had supported the plans wholeheartedly. That was on 17 August. That comment by Mr Kierath was repeated in the Sunday Times of 20 August. Mr Kierath is reported to have rejected the same claims about federal coalition pressure on him, saying:
I've had no warnings at all. The only discussions I've had is with John Howard . . . and he seemed very supportive of the principles.

To August this year we find the handcuff to the Leader of the Opposition. It has been confirmed by the state Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Kierath, that not just the first wave but the second wave is supported by the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's been sprung?
—The Leader of the Opposition has been sprung on this in the parliament. The Sydney Morning Herald of 24 August reports:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, told Parliament that Mr Howard had effectively endorsed the West Australian legislation—which has yet to gain Cabinet approval—as a template for his own policy.

He based this assertion on comments made by Mr Howard during a speech to the West Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry in July. Mr Howard said: "We are going to provide at a national level the sort of flexibility that the Court Government has provided at a State level, and until you have that flexibility operating at a national level . . . " Mr Howard said later that the endorsement related only to the reforms already passed by the West Australian Government and did not refer to the so-called "second wave" reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not what we find in the forensic evidence and that is not what Mr Kierath is reported to have said the next day. The West Australian says:
Kierath denied yesterday the Federal coalition was distancing itself from his controversial second wave of industrial reforms.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kierath told The West Australian 10 days ago that Mr Howard supported the major elements of his proposed second wave after he explained them to him when he was in Perth last month.
"He (Howard) said what constitutes the second wave . . . are things the coalition feel very strongly about and agree with wholeheartedly," Mr Kierath said then.
He also said Mr Howard was happy with his reasons for going ahead with the two proposals criticised by the WA Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: There we have it. It was brought to a conclusion by Nigel Wilson in the Australian when he said, `Liberal IR reforms go too far and too fast.' So the federal opposition is handcuffed not just to wave one of the Western Australian legislation but to wave two as well.

PARA.TAB: Just in case anyone was under any illusions as to the effect of wave one of the legislation, the effect of the Workplace Agreements Act, which was passed by the Western Australian parliament in 1993, is that under the act an agreement entered into by an employer and an employee, provided it meets certain formal requirements and is registered by the Commissioner for Workplace Agreements, will set aside all state award provisions that would otherwise apply to the conditions and wages of that employee. The regime created by the act has had an extremely harsh impact on employees and contains a number of serious flaws.

Let us look at the adverse and harsh impact that piece of legislation has had. The minimum conditions of employment enshrined by that piece of legislation include 40 hours of work at a weekly rate of pay of $301.10, which comes to an hourly rate of pay of $7.53. When you go through some of the common awards you will find how inferior those minimum conditions are to those award payments. Under the shop assistants award, for example, the comparative information is for 38 hours of work with $401 being the weekly rate of pay, or $10.55 as an hourly rate of pay. For fast food, grade 1, the award is for 38 hours at $396.60, or $10.44 as an hourly rate of pay. For a clerical assistant, grade 1, it is 38 hours for $374.80, or $9.86 as an hourly rate.

So you can see that the effect of the legislation is to drag those award conditions down. You know what the policy of the opposition is: it is precisely mirrored by the Western Australian legislation. Their policy and approach in this area are precisely the same as they are across the board; that is, bash the worker, slash wages and conditions, and leave no effective award safety net in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —People listening to this broadcast could well be forgiven for thinking that we are standing in Western Australia, that it is midafternoon and that we are in the Western Australian parliament, because the contribution from the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) has done nothing more than focus on what he sees as the Western Australian legislation and what he imagines—quite wrongly, as indicated by the shadow minister for industrial relations—to be the link between the federal opposition and the Western Australian government.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that we are standing here in the federal parliament, looking at the Industrial Relations and other Legislation Amendment Bill, and indicating that the opposition is not intending to oppose this legislation. I bring to the House the words of the shadow minister for industrial relations. In moving an amendment, the shadow minister indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill and whilst recognising that this Bill provides some improvement to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, the House is of the opinion that, even as amended, the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act remain a disincentive to job creation, that they impose a very heavy burden on business, particularly on small business, and that they were enacted without proper prior consultation.

That is a very different scene from the scene painted by the honourable member for Perth, who spent the 20 minutes of his speech focusing entirely on the Western Australian legislation. Mr Deputy Speaker, you, in common with the shadow minister at the table, have heard all of the comments from the member for Perth, the member for Lilley (Mr Swan), the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) and the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor). They have left all listeners with the impression that all the opposition seeks to do in industrial relations is to get people to work for less and make it easier for employers to dismiss them. In one word, the government has painted the picture that all that the opposition stands for is exploitation.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow minister for industrial relations indicated by his comments, he is not seeking to oppose this legislation; he welcomes sectors of it. His great concern about the legislation is precisely the same as it was when its unamended form was introduced in the House, and that is that it is a disincentive to employment. It runs counter to job creation.

Yesterday I had the shadow minister for industrial relations in my electorate. He was there to address a very successful branch function. Because we had an hour and a half to spare I thought I would take him to some of the most labour intensive industries in my electorate and let him see for himself what happens in labour intensive industries in Australia. I note that the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) has entered the chamber. He will be as aware as I am of the dilemma that labour intensive industries face.

Along with the opposition shadow spokesman on industrial relations, I stood with people who were picking citrus fruit in the Wakeley area who were there as contractors, who were there choosing to work on a Sunday because the weather suited them and they had a particular family program that meant that Sunday was a more convenient day for working than were other times of the week. They were happily part of the team determined to fuel the emerging export industry in export quality citrus. They freely indicated to the shadow minister for industrial relations the employment arrangements they had entered into, the contract arrangements they had entered into, the opportunities they saw for employment for the entire family in what they were doing and the arrangement they had with their employer, which reflected the very flexibility that the member for Perth was so critical of.

While it would be easy to give the impression that the opposition is seeking changes to the present unfair dismissal laws simply for some cheap political reason, or seeking to make it easier to exploit workers. The reality is that this is not the case, and this view is not held wholly by the opposition. Mr Carr, the Labor Premier of New South Wales, said about these very provisions:

SPEECH.PARA: There are kids going without jobs because of the way the unfair dismissal provision works in federal law. There are kids with good training, good education, who are not given employment because employers won't take them on if they know that down the track, whatever the circumstances, it is very difficult to effect a dismissal. The European experience makes it very clear: if you make it complex for employers to vary their employment levels down the track, they won't take on the employment to start with. The federal provisions—
this, by the way, is a Labor Premier speaking:
are a handbrake on employment growth. I want to revise the federal law. If we can, there are going to be more employers taking on young people who would otherwise be unemployed.

Reflecting on just what Premier Carr was saying, the government has made some changes to the unfair dismissal provisions which are not being opposed by the opposition. In spite of all that has been said opposite about the opposition's attitude to industrial relations, the reality is that we are supporting these provisions and saying two things: first, with great respect—we told you so. We indicated all this would be necessary and we were ignored. Secondly, you can go even further than this in introducing flexibility into the labour market, to pick up the words of Premier Carr, `giving the opportunity to young people to be employed'.

PARA.TAB: There has been no recognition from participants opposite in this debate of the valid claims that the opposition has made that the existing unfair dismissal provisions have fuelled unemployment, have been a deliberate disincentive for people to employ people. This has been our cry, ignored by those opposite. In place of that recognition, we have had from those opposite nothing but constant carping and criticism of what they perceive to be the opposition's industrial relations policy; nothing but misrepresentation of what we stand for; nothing but the constant cry from Labor Party members that we in some strange way represent only the employers and would stand for anything that we could get away with that was exploitative; nothing but the impression of an enormous chasm between our attitude and what they are proposing. That is absolute nonsense.

There is one thing that joins both the government and the opposition in the industrial relations debate—one thing that determines that every opposition member is as anxious as every government member to ensure that employees cannot be unfairly dismissed or unreasonably exploited—and that, Sir, is simply this: we are all parents. We all have young people seeking employment. I am the parent of a 23-year-old and a 20-year-old, currently still students and, as students, seeking to have employment opportunities to enhance their current income. I feel as bitterly about anyone exploiting my children as anyone over the other side feels about exploitation of theirs.

My children, who work in the hospitality industry as well as being students, are involved in some way in an industry that has relatively little status in union terms and leaves itself open to exploitation. I get indignant if I feel that they are running the risk of being unfairly dismissed or of not being as realistically paid as anyone else. I want legislative proposals in place that ensure that all employees cannot be exploited. That is my commitment. It is the commitment of the shadow ministers on the front bench and at the table; it is the commitment of the opposition. We do not want an exploitative society, for exactly the same reasons as the government members do not want an exploitative society. We do not want people unfairly paid. What we do want—in common, by the way, with the government, though rarely recognised—are job opportunities in Australia. What we have had, as Premier Carr has clearly illustrated, are unfair dismissal provisions which have been maybe unintentional but nonetheless are an effective disincentive to employment, making it harder for our children and all Australians to get secure, well-paid jobs.

A great deal of time in this debate has been spent focusing on Western Australia, and on what was seen to be the second wave of amendments that the government in Western Australia was proposing to introduce that would in some way make Western Australia the area where everybody would be exploited. The shadow minister for small business may no doubt want an opportunity to comment on this as well. As I understand it, this raft of so-called second wave provisions in Western Australia provides initially for secret ballots before strikes are entered into. In a democracy, is it such a terrible provision to introduce the proposal that before you enter into a strike—not that you should be denied a ballot; that would be terrible—the ballot that you conduct should be conducted in secret? That is nothing more than the heart of democracy.

It does not matter whether those who propose that our present democratic system should be changed so that we no longer have compulsory ballots are right or wrong. As far as I know, no-one proposing changes to the present democratic system in Australia is proposing that we should do away with secret ballots—with every one of my family members having the right to vote in an election as they see fit and unknown to me. Precisely the same provision ought to apply in industrial relations, particularly before people choose to go into strike mode.

Let me reassure the House that as someone standing here as an employer, anxious to have employees who are happy to work for me and keen to be productive, in common with the vast majority of employers I am not offended by the hourly rate. All I want to know is that I have a productive work force. I do not mind where that rate is struck, as long as what they are producing exceeds the rate I am obliged to pay them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's all relative.

—It's all relative, as the shadow minister for small business indicates. We as an opposition, frankly, are totally committed to ensuring: all employees have the right of appeal against any dismissal that they may face; all employees have the right to ensure that they do not have to face harassment or discrimination in the workplace; occupational health and safety conditions are maintained; a minimum wage; and holiday and sickness benefits are kept in place.

PARA.TAB: Our reputation in industrial relations is something we are happy to stand beside. While we have been so anxious in this debate to in some way blackguard the Western Australian government, let us not forget that in Western Australia currently we have the lowest unemployment rate in Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it is a little unfair of me to end on that note because I opened on this debate berating the member for Perth by indicating that it was inappropriate to focus on the Western Australian legislation given that this debate was all about the unfair dismissal provisions under federal law. But I stand here and restate the opposition case: we are supporting these government amendments. We have nothing for which to apologise. The focus of our entire industrial relations package is to keep in place those very provisions that as parents we would want for our children, but to remove those things that are an unreasonable disincentive to employment.
The closer we get to lowering the unemployment rate across this nation so that it reflects the unemployment rate in Western Australia, the happier I will be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Mrs J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally support the comments of my colleague the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), particularly in relation to Western Australia. I do not think you can overlook and separate out the two issues. The fact that Western Australia does have the lowest unemployment rate of any state in Australia I will leave for you to cogitate on.

PARA.TAB: This Labor government has foisted upon the small business community one of the most draconian and discriminatory industrial relations regimes imaginable. It is anti-employment, anti-investment and anti-business growth and has been overseen by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), who has absolutely no credibility in the business community in respect of his consideration of a review of the unfair dismissal provisions of the act.

The unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act have been the cause of considerable controversy since the law on unfair dismissals in Australia was changed by the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993. Indeed, Ian Spicer, chief executive of the ACCI, summed up the government's IR reforms perfectly in February this year when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we also have now in Australia a new growth industry; the so-called unlawful dismissal industry, spurred on by the current deluge of claims, now being received at a rate of around 150 new applications each week.

There have to date been over 5,000 dismissal applications lodged placing considerable burdens upon individual employers in responding to these claims. More importantly there is now significant evidence that the operations of these termination provisions are interfering with improvements in the labor market by frustrating company decision making processes regarding employment creation.

Those comments were made in February. The total of unfair dismissal claims has now risen to in excess of 10,125. The impact on and cost to the small business sector has escalated in the same proportions.

PARA.TAB: Small businesses have been confronted with exorbitant, vexatious and outrageously expensive claims for unfair dismissal by employees who, in many instances, had been dismissed for perfectly satisfactory and rational reasons. The provisions are universally agreed by employer and business organisations to be restrictive and biased and to place too much weight on process rather than principle and practicality.

I was informed by a small business proprietor who visited my office only last week that one member of his staff reported her suspicions that another staff member was stealing stock from the shop. A few days later, the owner himself caught the individual in the act of stealing, yet he was too paralysed by the fear of an unfair dismissals claim to do what he should be legally able to do to protect the profitability of his business, boost the morale of his honest staff and maintain his own integrity.

He should be free to instantly dismiss employees such as the one he described to me, yet this government's legislation prevented him from doing so. This is one of thousands of similar stories all over the country. The labor government's bad legislation has hindered the application of good management practices, is reducing business profits and viability, is increasing business costs, is reducing employment prospects as employers react to their experiences in dealing with the flow-on effects of the unfair dismissal provisions, is reducing the confidence of small business proprietors, and is increasing the uncertainty of owning and operating a small business in Australia today.

Has the government done any economic analysis of the impact of these unfair dismissal provisions? Has the government considered the cost to government outlays from employers' reluctance to increase employment opportunities, or from the changes to employment profiles, as more employers seek `safer' ways to employ?

The quality of employment opportunities in many small businesses has declined and the ministers responsible have never expressed any concern at all—neither the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) nor the Minister for Industrial Relations. They are more intent on ensuring that their mates in the ACTU are satisfied than with providing real and sustainable employment opportunities for Australia's unemployed, of whom there are still in excess of 800,000

The ironical aspect of these unfair dismissal provisions is that they have been enacted by the same Labor government that has overseen the rise in Australia's unemployment to in excess of one million Australians at its peak. They have demonstrated that their union mates come first, and then employees, employers and finally the unemployed.

Unfortunately, the arrogance of the ministers concerned is such that they could not see the damage that was being done to the confidence of Australia's small business sector. The government has successfully sown the seeds of doubt into the minds of the country's predominant employment sector.

With massive unemployment and under-employment around Australia, this is one of the most disgraceful acts that could be perpetrated by a government that is forever making soothing noises about its concern for the unemployed. The imposition of these draconian dismissal provisions has been condoned by the small business minister, Senator Schacht, who has repeatedly refused to listen to and act on the concerns of the small business community.

His silence and inaction on the concerns of the small business sector reflect the fact that he has never had the responsibility of employing people himself. Neither the small business minister nor the two ministers responsible for the shambles that passes for the government's industrial relations policy are used to the disciplines and pressures of operating a small business and being totally responsible for providing the livelihoods of other people.

It is completely different to the comfortable existence these ministers are used to experiencing, where the cheque for the week's salary just keeps on appearing in the bank account. Small business proprietors do not have that luxury. The Yellow Pages Small Business Index Special Report in September 1994 concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a sizeable concern amongst small business employers about the provisions in the new federal government industrial relations legislation relating to the termination of employment. This is spontaneously identified by small business employers as a significant barrier to taking on more staff.

These provisions have resulted in excess of 10,125 claims for unfair dismissal since the introduction of the unfair dismissal amendments, a huge backlog of unresolved claims that are clogging the court system, a loss of valuable management resources in the prosecution of these claims and enormous financial loss to the individual small business concerned. But, most importantly—a point that has been lost on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the ministers responsible for this fiasco—there has been a loss of confidence by employers and a lack of willingness on their part to employ.

PARA.TAB: The coalition understands the crisis of confidence in small business in the community at present and believes that profit should not be a dirty word. Reasonable profit should be the reasonable expectation of people who are prepared to put their family home at risk and to put their all into running a small business and employing other Australians. It is the foundation of confidence that is reasonable profit. It is a foundation of confidence, investment and employment growth.

We must be very clear why we are debating this legislation here today. It has nothing to do with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) or the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns) suddenly seeing the light on the road to Damascus and recognising the legitimate concerns of small business employers. It has everything to do with the big hand of the Prime Minister clearing the decks for an early election.

On 21 June, when the Prime Minister delivered his humiliating rebuff to his mate the Minister for Industrial Relations, he was simply desperate to get rid of some electoral baggage that he knew would be a major issue in the forthcoming election. He was belatedly acknowledging the well-founded criticisms and protests of major employer organisations and individual employers.

The amendments in the Industrial Relations and other Legislation Amendment Bill have been introduced to thwart an embarrassing employer campaign in the lead-up to the next election. Employers should carefully scan the skies for other backdoor measures that the government will try to introduce to overcome the embarrassment of this backdown. Remember the l-a-w tax cuts; one blink and they were gone. But it is very obvious that the ministers' hearts are just not in the process of these amendments. Their staunch support for the previous legislation is testament to that fact.
My colleague the shadow minister for industrial relations, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith), stated on 21 June 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: I have run a long and constructive campaign to highlight the gross deficiencies of Labor's unfair dismissal provision. But as recently as 31 May, Brereton accused me of running a campaign of total misinformation and asserting that his provisions had got the balance of policy right.

The commitment of the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations must also be questioned. During question time in this place on 7 June this year, the assistant minister arrogantly treated with contempt Australia's chambers of commerce when he said that he had spoken to a number of chambers around Australia who indicated this. I will quote the minister's words in this place:
They say the game is now over because employers are learning that there are reasonable ways in which they can dismiss people.

While the minister's response in question time on 7 June grossly misrepresented the position of the Australian chambers of commerce and was simply a fabrication of the minister's imagination, the reaction from the business community was swift and expected. The headline in the Australian Financial Review on 13 June told the story. It said in bold headlines `Business rejects claims on dismissal legislation'.

PARA.TAB: But some of the quotes from Australia's small business leader put the lie to the assistant minister's outbursts:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chief Executive of the NSW Chamber of Commerce, Mr David Taylor—
David has just sadly retired—
said Mr Johns had not discussed the matter with him and he believed the legislation continued to be a major impediment to reducing unemployment.
He said:
Small business is dead scared of the federal industrial relations laws.
He went on to say:
There has to be fairness for employers and employees. At the moment, employers fear dismissals will lead to an enormous payout or reinstatement—
of employees that have clearly not done the right thing.

PARA.TAB: At this point, I would like to state that two weeks ago it was my privilege to attend the industry farewell for Mr Taylor, who has retired from the New South Wales Chamber of Commerce. On behalf of the coalition and Australia's small business community, I place on the record my thanks to David Taylor for his contribution to the development of Australia's small business sector, particularly in New South Wales, and wish him well in his future.
I will return to quote from the Australian Financial Review regarding the assistant minister's comments:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chief Executive Officer of the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr David Edwards, said he was "totally mystified" by Mr Johns's comments.
Mr Edwards went on to say:
I can't think of any chamber of commerce, or even a single business, that is not worried by the legislation.
He also said:
At a workshop I attended last week, unfair dismissal was raised as the crunch issue for small business in Australia.
As the largest chamber of commerce, I am surprised Mr Johns has not checked with us—

before making his statement. Personally, I am not surprised at the lack of consultation by members of this government. This outburst by the assistant minister is symptomatic of a government that is no longer in touch with the reality of business in this country today.

PARA.TAB: But it gets better. The Australian Financial Review article quoted Mr Bert Evans, the chief executive of the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Johns hasn't spoken to us. Employers are scared and angry and are reacting by not putting people on.
Finally, the Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry stated in the same article on 16 June in the Australian Financial Review:
. . . the QCCI has certainly never given Mr Johns or any Cabinet member any indication whatsoever that the chamber supports the unfair dismissal legislation.

In fact, quite the opposite is true. QCCI has been a consistent critic of unfair legislation federally and in Queensland because of its negative effects on employment and its unfair approach to the issue of dismissals.

The government has elevated spinning on statements that are blatantly without substance to an art form. Too frequently this goes unchallenged by industry and the community. It must have been awful for the assistant minister to get such a solid thump on the ear from the business community on unfair dismissal provisions. With a performance like that one, it will be a long time before he loses his learner's plates.

PARA.TAB: Industry groups around Australia have expressed cautious optimism that the amendments in this bill will overcome the barriers to employment created by the government's ineptitude. It would help if the ministers responsible were genuine in their concern. But, unfortunately, the political expediency that has surrounded the introduction of these amendments suggests that there is good cause for considerable doubt.

The bill, in relation to unfair dismissals, is more concerned about process than practical and fair outcomes for employees and employers. The coalition and others support the fact that dismissals have to be fair. But they must be fair to all parties. It is a partnership. We are not back in the dark ages. We are not living 150 years ago when employers were seen to be like old Scrooge, who gave employees a rough time. We have moved very much forward from that. In today's commercial reality, in contemporary Australia, we have a very different arrangement. It is a partnership. If the trade union movement in this country is going to remain relevant, it has to catch up with that fact. It has to help create a situation of win-win rather than set one party against another.

This country has problems to be resolved. We have a current account crisis. We have a highly competitive global market to confront. Unless we have a trade union and ministers in government who are prepared to help employees produce the very best results, this country is headed for a bleak future.

The bill, in relation to unfair dismissals, is more concerned, as I said, about process rather than practice, and that has to change. In summary, I reiterate the important fact that the only reason we are debating this amendment is that the Prime Minister was running scared when he overruled Minister Brereton on the unfair dismissal provisions. In fact, he announced it at a lunch in Sydney at an international meeting of small business people. The Prime Minister announced it, not the minister.
I support the amendment moved by my colleague the shadow minister for industrial relations. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill and whilst recognising that this Bill provides some improvement to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, the House is of the opinion that, even as amended, the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act remain a disincentive to job creation, that they impose a very heavy burden on business, particularly small business, and that they were enacted without proper prior consultation."
Mr Speaker, I thank you for your indulgence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to revisit on behalf of several distraught families in my electorate a matter that has previously been addressed by the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) and the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) in this place. I speak of the drug pulmozyme. We have already heard from these two members that thousands of cystic fibrosis sufferers could benefit from the listing of this drug on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Cystic fibrosis is a crippling disease which affects children, usually reducing the life expectancy of its sufferers to less than 30 years. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has said in this place that she will not move to help the sufferers of this disease by facilitating the listing of pulmozyme on the PBS. Currently, families who need pulmozyme are paying around $1,300 a month to supply their children with the treatment. I do not know of many families in my electorate who could afford that without financial assistance.

PARA.TAB: To use the drug currently, a family would need to find over $15,000 per annum for each child with the disease. It is all but impossible in families where more than one child suffers, unless they are lucky enough to be part of a very wealthy household. I suspect that the minister has been a bit busy with other things to be able to give her full attention to this matter, but in the very limited time I have available to me I would like to try to implore her to realise just how important access to this drug is to some Australian families.

I would like to read a letter from one of my constituents. It is a letter which sent a shiver down my spine when I read it and, as they read it, I hope the minister or someone on her staff might think about the pain and anguish that is being suffered not only by the children who have this horrible disease, but by the families of the sufferers—in particular, the parents, who feel impotent in trying to save the lives of their loved ones. There are hidden sufferers; these are the hidden sufferers. Yet they could be helped by helping the children they love. Parents and grandparents, like the Taylor family, the Rosario family, the Challen family, the Weddell family and the Chandler family, to name just a few in my electorate, have suffered. The letter I wish to read is from Mr Ray Taylor of Banff Court in Duncraig in my electorate. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir
I am writing to seek your support in obtaining Pharmaceutical Benefits listing for a new product called Pulmozyme which will benefit people with Cystic Fibrosis (CF).

CF is a dreadful genetic disease that attacks the lungs and digestive systems of its sufferers and considerably reduces life expectancy. My fourteen year old son died a slow, painful death from CF two years ago, an experience my wife and I will never forget nor wish to repeat.
We do not wish the same thing to happen to his little sister who also has CF.

Would you please use all the influence you have to get Pharmaceutical Benefits listing for Pulmozyme, as it offers the best hope for CF patients that we have seen in many years, and should be available to all, not just those that can afford it.
Yours faithfully,
R W Taylor.

I do not know how much anguish writing that letter caused Mr Taylor; I suspect it caused him a great deal. At any rate, the courage of people like him and his wife cannot easily be understood by those of us who have—touch wood—healthy children at home. At any rate, Mr Taylor implored me to use any influence I have to assist him. To Mr Taylor and the many other families who have written to me with similar entreaties, I would say that I am trying.

PARA.TAB: Having written to the minister and received only a standard response in the past, I have raised the matter here tonight in an effort to penetrate some of the bureaucracy that currently surrounds this particular issue. The ball is now in the court of the minister. I can only hope that she is able to address the matter. I note that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) is present here this evening. I hope that this message is conveyed. I am sure it will be. If at the end of the day this matter is not addressed, the Taylors, the Rosarios, the Chandlers, the Challens and the Weddells of Australia will continue to lose their children to cystic fibrosis, and the suffering to them and the children, and to all of those who have any association in any way with their loved ones, will be prolonged.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Attention Deficit Disorder and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to speak about a health problem in the community which is largely being ignored or, even worse, compounded. I refer to attention deficit disorder and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. They are major problems that, as the names imply, occur in children, teenagers, and even adults, suffering from lack of concentration, disruptive, childish behaviour and aggressive tendencies. Most damaging is the anti-social effect that these disorders have on society and the sufferer. At present there are a number of problem areas which require attention—that is, recognition of ways that the disorder can be treated. Obviously, the medical profession is generally conservative in its outlook and fairly slow to accept new methods of treatment. There is one called neurometrix. Parents whose children have been treated by this form of treatment are very confident that it does work, but it has been rejected by the NHMRC.

PARA.TAB: I find that in schools there is a varied response to the children who suffer from these disorders. In some schools that I have visited I have found the staff prepared to accept the responsibility of handing out medication to those children who suffer. But, as you would be aware, Mr Speaker, this is not regarded as one of the responsibilities of the teaching profession. At some schools the staff decide that it is a responsibility they would rather not have. So in those schools the medication is not administered.

Generally, we are talking about medication such as ritalin or dexamphetamine, which only lasts for four hours. The school day is eight hours long, from the time the child leaves home to when they return home. If there is no-one to administer that drug in the middle of the day, the afternoon can be extremely disruptive. If you have more than one of these children in a class, the behaviour problem is passed on to the whole of that class. That becomes a problem.

In the electorate of Paterson I have been working with a number of support groups. As the community becomes aware of ADD and ADHD, support groups have been set up by the parents of the sufferers simply to try to find out more about the nature of the disorder and about its treatment. They have done an enormous amount of good, particularly in the educative process and by exchanging information on how treatment can be administered and what sort of treatment works.

Today I have written to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) asking that she seriously consider getting the National Health and Medical Research Council to set up a working group to look into ways that the families of sufferers of ADD and ADHD can be supported in the community. What forms of help do they need and what forms of help can be supplied fairly quickly and on an even basis?

I find that in the electorate of Paterson psychiatric services are not readily available. If parents have to take their children to the nearest centre where it is available, they are probably faced with an 18-month wait before they can get in to see that specialist. One of the things that is urgently needed is the correct diagnosis. Is it a behavioural problem or a genetic problem? What has caused the disorder in the particular case? No two particular cases are necessarily the same.

This week is Attention Deficit Disorder Awareness Week. I urge all members to go to their electorates, work with the groups that are trying to find out more and consult widely with them. I ask all members to be constructive in their response to it because it is a disorder that sorely needs the attention of all members of our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to say a few words about the role of small business in Australia and in contemporary society. It is pretty coincidental that it follows the excellent speech given by the shadow minister, the member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan), just before the adjournment debate when she said that we must create a win-win situation in this country.

PARA.TAB: My thoughts were provoked a little by an article in today's Australian where a lecturer at the University of Queensland's Graduate School of Management, Dr Thomas Bramble, was telling a conference on unionism that there was a necessary condition for reversing union decline in the rank and file trade unionists. His paper shows that four of the five full-time officers on the executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions have a combined total of six years work experience outside the trade union movement. The fifth, who happens to be Mr Mansfield—whom I have met a few times and is a fairly practical fellow—has at least served a four-year trade apprenticeship.

In that one statement we can see part of the problem facing our industrial relations system in this country. We have professional industry or union politicians who do not have a lot of practical experience in the workplace. In the rhetoric that passes for debate in this place from time to time, the role of the self-employed in small business enterprises—or SMEs as they are known more accurately these days—is ignored. The traditional role over many decades of leadership, commitment and discipline that has been provided by these hundreds of thousands of small businesses throughout Australia is too often ignored.

I am acutely aware of it within my own electorate of Grey—an electorate which I keep reminding this House has amongst the lowest incomes of this country. It contains 90 per cent of the state of South Australia in area and produces some 50 per cent of that state's export income but it is very low in terms of actual average income. About 25 per cent of my electorate has a linkage with small business.

As the shadow minister said, in regional Australia we are not particularly interested in this confrontationist approach, this fear and smear campaign, that the government, including the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), likes to indulge in. We are much more interested in practical fairness and in actually getting people into constructive employment. The need for stable employment is the biggest issue facing this country; the need for stable employment that can give not only this generation but also the next generation some kind of secure and stable future.

It does not just mean recycling people through labour market programs. Even though billions of dollars have been spent on Working Nation programs they suffer from that great philosophical blockage of my political opponents: the government's disregard and lack of understanding—if not contempt—for small business. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) laughs but, if he has a look within his own ranks, he would see there are very few government members who have practical small business experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —None.

—As the member for Cowan says, probably none—we concede there might be two or three. Nevertheless, the point is that we indulge in too much rhetoric in this place when we have nearly a million people out of work. The old statement that 700,000 small businesses employing just over one person and our unemployment issue disappears rings as true today as it ever did.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is through a deliberate act of malice by my political opponents; it is just through simple ignorance and that philosophical blockage. Regional Australia is predominantly made up of low income people. Only the seat of Port Adelaide is in the bottom quarter of seats in this country by way of low incomes; all the rest are in regional Australia, and three-quarters of those seats are represented by the coalition. How is that for challenging this great nonsense that the government carries on with. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) correctly drew the House's attention to a recent court case in South Australia in which the memory of Premier Dean Brown was found to be somewhat lacking in relation to events which took place a day or so after the formation of his government in 1993. At that time when he came to office in South Australia he did so on a very substantial vote. Obviously, Premier Brown felt he could do no wrong and he had to sweep all before him.

PARA.TAB: The manner in which he did that in relation to Dr David Blaikie, the then Chairman of the Health Commission—in effect the CEO of the department of health, the Health Commission in South Australia, for which I was the minister for the two years prior to the election—was a very shabby process indeed. I think the recent Supreme Court case has not only amply demonstrated his inability to relate to the court accurately the circumstances which took place at that time, but also highlighted the extraordinary manner in which the government at that time dealt with a very experienced and senior public servant.

Rather than focus on the issues surrounding the Premier's recollection of those events and the way in which the court saw fit to criticise him for that, I will focus on another aspect of this matter—that is, the history, career and contribution of Dr David Blaikie. Although he has now been largely vindicated in relation to the manner in which he was effectively dismissed from the South Australian Public Service, what has not been effectively put on the record is the nature of his contribution over those many years and the manner in which he was effectively dismissed from that service.

David Blaikie was very much a career public servant. He had been a member of the Health Commission in one capacity or another for many years prior to becoming the chairman of that body. While he certainly possessed all the normal skills which you would expect of a senior public service official—he was a very competent manager and very experienced in a wide range of those areas—he also had some unique skills which I think particularly fitted him for the position of chairman. I certainly had experience of that during the time that he worked with me when I was Minister of Health.

Dr Blaikie was well able to move in the medical community, the hospital community and among the ancillary service providers—whatever profession that might encompass—and, indeed, in the general community, and determine the ebb and flow of events. This was not so much from a political perspective because that was not his job. That was the task of the minister of the day and should remain that way. But he was well able to understand the way in which the public relates to health; the way in which the various, often conflicting requirements of all the professions that contribute to the health industry are focused. He was able to bring that experience to bear on those problems and often reach accommodations and solutions which, in the end, furthered the best interests of the community as a whole as well as those of the health industry.

His contribution was a very important one during very difficult and trying times in terms of budgets, in terms of Medicare renegotiations. While my perspective on some of those Commonwealth-state relationships has changed somewhat in the last few years, I can certainly testify to his skill on behalf of the state of South Australia and on behalf of its taxpayers in terms of extracting the best possible deal from the Commonwealth. He knew a great deal of the background of those issues. His corporate experience, his corporate memory, was quite substantial. As minister, I often made considerable use of those skills in terms of obtaining the best possible arrangements for our state and ensuring that the arrangements that were put in place achieved the maximum advantage.

To see such a career public servant dismissed effectively within a day of the government taking over, and in circumstances which were hardly appropriate or satisfactory, brought a great deal of sadness to me, as one who knew Dr Blaikie professionally, although I might say not personally that well. He was simply summarily pushed out of the public service without any effective attempt at negotiation or discussion about his position. No charges were brought against him. No charges were ever proved against him by the government. They simply decided they did not like him. While I accept that every government has a right to choose its permanent heads and those who serve it—that is clearly a right that any government has and I do not quarrel with it—I certainly think there is every reason to quarrel with the manner in which this was done. The way in which a senior, dedicated and committed public servant of South Australia was dealt with is I think something about which the government of Dean Brown should hang its head in shame. The Supreme Court of South Australia has dealt appropriately with this matter on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —School failure, poor employment prospects, aggression, anti-social behaviour, domestic violence, criminality and psychiatric disorders all sound very much like the typical range of disorders found in some of Australia's maximum security prisons. However, these are not the exclusive symptoms of hardened criminals or the psychiatrically disturbed but are in fact the profile of health related behaviours found in at least five per cent of Australia's school-aged children—let me say that again: at least five per cent of our school children. This translates to in excess of 20,000 school children at school today are quietly suffering from a range of previously unlinked disorders which are symptomatic of a much wider problem recently identified as attention deficit disorder, or ADD.

PARA.TAB: ADD is essentially medical shorthand for a cluster of bothersome symptoms whose severity can really ruin a person's day, month, year, decade or, in fact, lifetime. Those with the disorder have a high tolerance for chaos because they are always distracted with either no priorities or all priorities.

For those suffering from ADD, their reality is different from ours. For them, their perception is real and correct. However, in our terms they are neither here nor there, nor in fact anywhere in particular. They are not in any one place but are all over the place. Because of being in this no-man's-land, they have little self-awareness and self-esteem.

This is manifest in the so-called depressed child, the defiant child, the bully or even the withdrawn child. These are understandable responses when you consider the words of expert, Dr Ken Whiting, who said of the people with ADD:

SPEECH.PARA: Can you imagine what it must be like to get out of bed in the morning knowing that for the rest of the day you would be in trouble?

Add to this the fact that 65 per cent of ADD kids have more ear infections than any other child population, and therefore short-term but recurring hearing loss; and 60 per cent of ADD kids have some bi-motor difficulty, which means they may not be able to copy simple letters or shapes from the blackboard.

PARA.TAB: Let us all understand that ADD is not the result of bad parenting. ADD is not the answer for most children's bad behaviour. ADD is not the latest yuppie disorder. It is a real disorder, a medical disorder, mainly genetically passed from generation to generation with at least four per cent of cases caused through frontal lobe injury or birthing and the often associated post-natal infection. It is a real concern on which the government in the United States of America spends in excess of $20 million annually on research grants through hospitals and universities.

They are interesting facts, but let us look at the big picture. At a political level, ADD is an issue which is not contained within any single ministerial portfolio. It is vital that all members of the House are aware that the issue of ADD spans across and extends over the following portfolios: health, education, welfare, justice, employment and children's services, just to mention a few. In other words, governments at both federal and state levels need to take into account the individual human, family, community and financial costs engendered by people who suffer ADD.

An integrated policy and introduction to appropriate services needs to be set as a priority, and there also needs to be a commitment from the responsible government ministers. ADD is not an issue to be placed in the too hard basket. In fact, as a matter of urgency, we need to identify testing programs for potential sufferers through early screening, place research dollars into both medical and university research areas, provide support services for parents and siblings of ADD, consult with education authorities on appropriate training for teachers and curriculum development to cater for ADD needs, establish both screening and treatment programs for identified adults and provide information to the wider community about the disorder as well as active ways to deal with sufferers.

Rhetoric is not the answer. Positive action and program implementation is the only way to tackle this issue head on. This is the week of ADD awareness. I join with my colleague the member for Paterson (Mr Horne) in encouraging all members of this House to take an active interest in this particular issue because it is an important issue to these children and their parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, members of the House paid tribute to the memory of the late Dame Pattie Menzies. During the debate on the condolence motion, I added the condolences of the people of Alexandra in the state of Victoria, the place of birth of the late Dame Pattie Menzies. In the course of that debate, I also noted that the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre for the intellectually disabled is located at Alexandra and that hopefully the name of Dame Pattie Menzies will remain in Alexandra.

PARA.TAB: The great difficulty is that an uncaring Liberal Party is now making the future of that centre appear very dim indeed. Only a few weeks ago I received correspondence from the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre for the intellectually disabled requesting my intervention as a federal member in respect of the actions of the state government of Victoria. This year, as in past years, the disability groups in Victoria are being hit with what is known in Liberal Party terms as a 1.5 per cent efficiency dividend. In other words, these disability groups have to make further cuts to fund this 1.5 per cent dividend. They have already had to reduce services and sack staff. Nevertheless, they have to find another 1.5 per cent.

The first Kennett budget imposed savage and vicious cuts, and we are now getting an increasing annual attack on these disability groups. I would have thought that, considering the home is called the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre for the intellectually disabled, the Liberal Party would at least want to preserve in perpetuity the memory of this great Australian lady. I would not have thought that the Liberal Party or a Liberal Party Premier would want to force this service to close in Alexandra. Yet that is the potential reality if this centre is forced to continue to make the vicious and savage cuts that the Kennett government is still imposing on them.

I notice my colleague the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) sitting on the other side of the House. I hope he is talking notes about what I am saying. After all, he is a member of the Liberal Party and can probably contact the Premier of Victoria, Jeffrey Gibb Kennett, about these matters. Hopefully, the honourable member will note that the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre for the intellectually disabled in Alexandra should not be forced to close because of an uncaring and unthinking Liberal government.

As the member for Ballarat comes from rural Victoria, he would probably know that rural Victoria cannot take much more, because the cuts are vicious. They are not cuts which are targeted at more efficient service delivery. They are across-the-board cuts. Each service, wherever it may be, is required to make the same cut. The service is not asked whether or not within the context of its budgetary framework it can maintain and provide the appropriate service efficiently or more cost effectively. Instead, it is simply told by the great centralists of the Australian political system—the Liberal Party—`You're getting less money, but you're supposed to provide the same service.'

In Alexandra, you cannot sell a house for love nor money. The Department of Conservation and Natural Resources has lost approximately four full-time employees from the office. The State Electricity Commission of Victoria office has closed. More staff have gone. In my electorate, 15 schools are being closed down. More teachers are leaving the district. If you take away the public servants and the salaries they provide to a town the size of Alexandra, you will create a mini-recession within a rural district. Those salaries will be removed from the local traders. If you reduce the number of adults living in a town, you will reduce the number of children living in a town. Hence, you will place further pressure on the schools and start losing more schools. You will get a snowballing effect.

I hope my colleague the member for Ballarat does take this message to his Premier of Victoria, Jeffrey Gibb Kennett. I hope my colleague from Ballarat asks Jeffrey Gibb Kennett to ensure that the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre in Alexandra receives the appropriate funding, that the disabled get the proper care they deserve and that the memory of Dame Pattie lives on for much longer. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The table shows that the bonds were actually sold in the month of July, more than a year before the first tightening of monetary policy in August 1994. At the time of these sales, bond yields had fallen to their lowest level for more than 20 years, and there was a widely-held view, shared by the OSF, that bonds were no longer a good investment at those yields. (In fact, yields continued to fall for a further six months.)

The OSF bought back into the bond market in February and April 1994. Bond yields continued to rise and, in June 1994, with a further sharp deterioration in the bond market occurring, the OSF decided that it should sell its holdings. It did so at a substantial loss compared with the yields at which the bonds were purchased. In common with most other funds managers, the OSF's bond market activities in 1994—the year in which monetary policy was tightened—resulted in considerable losses.

Holdings of other fixed interest securities (mainly loans to local government authorities) were sold in the first half of 1993-94, in response to strong demand for these securities by one particular dealer in the market. Holdings of indexed bonds were also reduced in the early months of 1993-94. As with conventional bonds, yields on these had fallen to historical lows and the OSF, like many other funds

ANSWER.PARA: managers, no longer regarded these bonds as good value.

PARA.TAB: (4) As a matter of policy, the Reserve Bank does not act as a counterparty for transactions by the OSF. That is, the Reserve Bank does not buy bonds from, or sell bonds to, the OSF.

It is common for participants in financial markets to use agents to undertake their transactions when they want to maintain their anonymity. The OSF is alert to possible market sensitivities regarding its bond transactions, such that some market participants might (wrongly) see the OSF's transactions as inferring something about the Bank's thinking on monetary policy. For this reason, the OSF has on occasion sought to preserve its anonymity by having the Reserve Bank act as its agent.

In late 1994 and early 1995, a number of bond transactions (purchases and sales) by the OSF were conducted using the Reserve Bank as agent. Details of these transactions are shown below. Neither the Reserve Bank nor the OSF drew any financial benefit from each other in these transactions: the bonds purchased or sold by the Reserve Bank in the market were passed immediately to or from the OSF, at identical yields. This is similar to arrangements under which the Reserve Bank acts as agent for certain other parties, such as overseas central banks and international institutions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations: Reference to the Dalai Lama

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Is the Minister able to say whether:
(a) reference to the Dalai Lama has been prohibited in the production of the UN Secretariat's 50th anniversary history of the UN entitled `A Vision of Hope';
(b) Mr Richard Reoch, a former employee of the International Secretariat of Amnesty International, was invited to write a chapter on human rights for the book;

(c) Mr Reoch included in his chapter a statement in a speech by the Dalai Lama at the 1993 World Conference on Human Rights that it was the inherent nature of human beings to yearn for freedom, equality and dignity, they had an equal right to achieve that and brute force, no matter how strongly applied, could never subdue the basic desire for freedom and dignity; and

(d) UN Under-Secretary General Gillian Martin Sorenson, Special Adviser to the Secretary General, directed Mr Reoch in writing that the lines were not acceptable; if so, (i) does the Minister support the directive, (ii) is the Minister able to say whether the directive is consistent with Article 100 of the UN Charter and (iii) will the Minister protest to the UN on Australia's behalf about the directive; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: We have been closely following the concerns raised by Mr Reoch regarding the content of a commemorative book "A Vision of Hope" sponsored and financed by the United Nations Fiftieth Anniversary Secretariat.

(a)(b)(c) I understand that Mr Richard Reoch was invited to write a chapter on human rights for the book and that, on submitting his draft to the UN, Mr Reoch was asked to remove a quotation from a statement made by His Holiness the Dalai Lama to the 1993 World Conference on Human Rights.
(d) I understand that the UN advised Mr Reoch that the quotation was not acceptable.

(d)(i)-(ii) Article 100 of the UN Charter states, amongst other things, that officials of the United Nations should refrain from any action which might reflect on their position as international officials only responsible to the Organisation.

I understand that the UN made it clear to contributors that `A Vision of Hope' was to be commemorative in nature with the aim of providing information about the goals and work of the United Nations for the general public. Contributors were also advised that the book would appear with United Nations endorsement and that the United Nations reserved a right of review and approval. Authors were advised that it was not the purpose of the book to single out individual countries for criticism. While I agree that it is somewhat over-sensitive of the UN to interpret reference to the Dalai Lama as a criticism of China, I do not consider that the directive was inconsistent with Article 100 given the explicit instructions given to contributors beforehand.

(d)(iii) The latest advice we have from the UN is that contributors to `A Vision of Hope', including Mr Reoch, have now accepted all the amendments proposed and their names will appear in the book so a protest of the type proposed would be inappropriate.

The Draft EIS was released for public comment on 20 September 1990 for a three month period, which was subsequently extended until 3 January 1991. (b) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) received 334 written noise complaints to 5 July 1995, and my office received 2566 written noise complaints in the same period.

PARA.TAB: (8) Yes.

(8)(a) (b) and (c) Monthly advertisements were placed in major Sydney and major foreign language newspapers, and more frequent advertisements appeared in the local newspapers of the suburbs being visited by the FAC's mobile access centre. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 22 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the name of the company contracted to carry out surveillance of Australia's northern coastline.
(2) Is the company Australian owned.
(3) Why does the RAN and RAAF not conduct the surveillance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Two companies are presently contracted to carry out surveillance of Australia's northern coastline. Skywest Aviation carries out fixed winged surveillance and Reef Helicopters rotary winged surveillance. From 1 October 1995 Surveillance Australia, a wholly-owned subsidiary of National Jet Systems (an Adelaide company) will progressively take over the fixed wing contract from Skywest. Skywest will cease surveillance operations on 1 July 1996.
(2) All companies mentioned in (1) are Australian owned.
I am advised by the Minister for Defence that:

(3) The responsibility for the management and coordination of the Civil Coastal Surveillance Program presently lies with Coastwatch, a sub-component of the Australian Customs Service. Defence Force support to the program consists of the provision of 1800 patrol boat days of surface patrol and response capability and 250 hours of P3C Orion air surveillance. Coastwatch also draws on Defence intelligence information and assistance with the planning and conduct of specific surveillance operations.

The concept of using the RAN and RAAF to conduct all the functions of the civil surveillance program may appear attractive at the outset but it needs to be recognised that the use of sophisticated military equipment to conduct low-level surveillance is not an efficient use of those assets and that it would be a significant detraction from their primary role.
